Much to my surprise--and rather unlike many earlier reviewers--I neither loved nor hated it; I thought it was very much just "okay." The food was good, but I don't think I would have been too thrilled about the prices absent my Groupon. The service was remarkably friendly, but I think that was in part because we were new faces and the restaurant seems to be trying very hard to elevate their image and attract regulars. The interior of the restaurant itself isn't great--the lighting is weird (sort of a muted fluorescent?), and the tabletops are plastic--but there was nothing really "wrong" with it and we were plenty comfortable.

If I lived closer to KOP, I'd probably hit it up again for takeout. Highly recommend that if you go, you either bring or at least mention the Groupon deal to get a nice discount!

This is my husband's favorite Half Price Books in Indy. Recently he has been into manga and anime, this place has an amazing selection of both. One thing he really loves is that the staff will look in the database for any type of book you want. If they find something out of state you can pay right there and it'll be mailed to your home. There's something here for everyone, please check it out!!

Wow, Zorba's Taverna  has the best Greek food that I have ever had!  This place is a gem, and you could walk right by and not even realize what you are missing.

Zorba's is on the small side, so I would recommend calling ahead for a reservation if possible.  We called at 8:30 last night, and after some back and forth in Greek between the person who answered the phone and someone else, they decided that we could be seated at 9:30.  

Since we had never dined at Zorba's before, we decided to go all out and try the cold appetizer tray and the Charcoal Platter for two.  We also got a small Greek salad (hey, we were hungry!).  Everything was delicious.  The salad was fresh, crispy, and refreshing.  The appetizer plate had two types of hummus, tzatziki, moussaka, and a few other dips with lightly toasted pita.  The platter was humongous, and was piled high with chicken, pork, lamb, gyro meat, a spinach patty, rice, and veggies.  I didn't try a single thing that I didn't love, and my other half was in a meat-lovers heaven.  

The only slight downside is that the service was a little on the slow side at the end of our meal.  Our food came out extremely quickly, but we did have to wait a little bit to hail down the bill.  Not a problem, and everyone was very friendly.  Prices are very reasonable, our bill amounted to around $45 for all of that food! 

Also, Zorba's is a BYO, so make sure you grab a bottle of your favorite wine on the way out the door!

Dinner at Muriels was the best meal I've had since I've lived in NOLA. (4 months)

They offer a 3 course dinner for $35 which is a great deal with the quality of food you get.   The atmoshpere is beautiful. I love the architecture and the history. Take a drink upstairs and relax. Beautiful view of Jackson Square from the balcony. 

I got the pecan crusted puppy drum. It was so good! and that crab hash thing they had going on under that drum was A-MAZING. I want that for breakfast with eggs! 

oh and the bread pudding?? Best in NOLA. nom nom nom

I had been wanting to come to this place for such a long time. Boy do I wish I had come sooner! It was so quaint and unique. Although the inside is small, there is also a great patio for dining. During most days, it would be fine to eat outside.

I had the casita bowl with spicy chicken. It was delicious...I can't wait to have another one! It was so fresh and authentic. I loved the queso fresca. I had it with warm tortillas on the side (included) so I was able to make tacos out of the bowl as well.

The only reason I'm giving this place 4 stars instead of 5 is because of the price of tacos. My husband had 2 little tacos and it cost $6. My bowl was only $1 more and came with tons of food. He couldn't believe how little food he got for paying $6, although he did enjoy it. Next time, he will get the bowl and just make tacos himself.

We can't wait to come back here!

I'm echoing many reviewers here, when I say to you that I think that this location of HipCityVeg wins the day with its relaxing space and plenty o' seating. See, I always feel like a moose woman in a china shop anyway, or I'm carrying a huge bag that I'm trying not to hit into people with, or I just generally have some other ridiculous issue where a tiny shop can gimme a panic. So, the point is: ahhhh spread out a little. It's the same delicious vegan fast food stylins and salads from your original HipCityVeg; now with more leg room. 

Also, here's another thing, a sidenote to all this limited seating talk. I love the hell outta that udon salad, but I'm one of these people who seem to take forever to eat a damn salad. I have felt much anxiety, self-consciously imagining that those waiting to score my seat are hissing at me in their minds, "Jeeeeezus, just will this one just take it to go already." Neuroses. So you understand what I'm saying. You can at salads at your leisure, or enjoy sweet potato fries and crispy, crispy nuggets at their peak crispiness. Or both. Makes such a difference, I tell you: a lil extra space and maximum crispiness.

Speaking of making a difference- when they take the time to griddle a little char onto that seitan in the udon salad, I love that. It really gives the protein that grilly somethin somethin. I love it that this arrugula-y salad it's an actual greens-packed salad with noodles in it, rather than, you know, a bigg asss noodle bowl with some greens fluttered lightly in. Listen, I'm all for extra noodle, but, ya know, sometimes your trying to do a thing. Anyway, I enjoy this dish, I do, even if it could use a little less dressing at times. I'm not complaining bout that though, really. So tasty.

In closing, I'd like to repeat the announcement that the Crispy HipCity Ranch remains my favorite, favorite. It cures a chicken sandwich yen for me, maybe better than a real bird sandwich, even. I have real HipCityVeg hankerings and I find myself coming up with more reasons to head West to University City. Maybe I should go back and get that masters. Hurrrrhurrrr hurrrffff...

Mona Lisa Latte :) I like the name, and I like the way it tastes!

This place is super cute! Their signature drinks are creative, and tasty. Their coffee is nicely roasted. They have teas (which are made/blended in Seattle, my home town... LOVE) and a nice pastry case! Great ambiance. Pretty stained glass over the door. 

I am so happy I found this place, I just wish I lived closer!

I seriously love this place! The cost is low but I love the food. I love being able to control what is put in my food and there are so many options when building your bowl. Then they serve you with rice, sesame bread, and soup. Every time I go, I say I'm going to do the all you can eat option which is just a few dollars more than the one bowl option but then once I get there, I remember just how much food you get and I always end up changing my mind! I highly recommend, I can't rave about the food and the service enough!

My brother loves him some waffle house. So while he visited Indy, I dragged myself there. I ordered the chocolate chip waffle with hashbrows. I liked how there was a variety of options for each dish. So you can have your hashbrows, waffles, and eggs multiple ways. My brother had the Texas Sausage melt and had his hashbrows, peppered(with jalapeños). Of course he loved his breakfast. Besides the stained cups, not too had of a place! I also wish they would have included the onions in the hashbrows, versus layered underneath them!

This is a great hotel to stay at just outside Nashville.  It only took us about 10-15 minutes to drive downtown, and it was nice being a bit removed from the rush of the city.  The surroundings were very green and beautiful, and we had a lovely view from our room.  The entire hotel was very quiet and we slept very peacefully.  I was also very pleased with the breakfast that was served the next morning.  Overall, I have no complaints and would recommend staying here!
I love this place... but they need to bring the prices down so fans can actually enjoy the game and not feel like their wallet is taking a beating if they want a hot dog or a beer.

My wife and I will end up making our plans around going here for lunch. We will literally say "hey you wanna go to Tilles park and then pick up some food at forest Perk cafe??" It is quite sad and awesome all at once because we both know we just want to go to the Cafe. They have some really great food and it is not bad price wise. 

I usually get the pick 2 salad and sandwich because regardless they serve you what seems like the same amount of salad so you really get a good deal. The Caesar dressing is really nice to, something different from your normal Caesar dressing. The 3 cheese and ham hot sandwich is awesome also. 

Also the strawberry yogurt parfait is the bee's knees. We always get the parfait, I mean always. 

I love that it is so small and you can see them making your food. Also the employees are always helpful and very attentive. 

I am not a coffee drinker so I cannot attest to the quality or taste of anything other than the food and the food is Delicious. 

Definitely a great place to stop in a have lunch. I love the outside seating also, very peaceful and they have nice tables with umbrellas. When it is not so freakishly hot we sit out there and enjoy the day.

Highly recommended.

We were really looking forward to some good ole food on Frenchmen one evening when we came across this place. It's an ok late night spot because it's open so late, but the food was not up to par for us. As someone who loves soul food, I found that it wasn't seasoned as well as we would have liked. Also, the fried chicken was extremely dry as well as the cornbread. We were so disappointed with our experience here and don't think we'll be returning anytime soon. Lastly, they ran out of bread pudding and replaced it with basic peach cobbler. That was such a bummer!

I love the hipster vibes and the paintings on the wall! The patio is a lovely place to hang out and relax under the sun! 

My friend and I didn't realize they close and reopen for dinner. While we were trying to pass time, we walked around outside. It was nice and there were colorful walls, which is great for photos if you're basic like me...

The food was amazing! After asking what was popular here (Topa topa burger and fish tacos), I ordered the Lama Burger! My friend ordered the MAC and CHEESE, and Parmesan fries. 

Shortly after being seated, our food was brought to the table. First thing I noticed was the nice plating and presentation! The fries came in a tiny metal basket and my burger was oozing with yumminess. 
The mac and cheese was the very perf creamy and cheesy, which I liked. But the BEST thing was the Parmesan fries, which were outta da world! It was slightly brown, crispy, and garlic-y! Mmm my burger was giant and the sauce was soooo good. There was fried tomato in it too. Only downside was that it was challenging to eat without getting it all over me and looking like a monster but that didn't stop me! 

I ordered the grapefruit kombucha beer. I really liked it because it was fruity and sweet! You could barely taste the alc and it tastes like sweet kombucha. Definitely recommend that! Yay def will come back soon!

Definitely WAY overrated. Also a tad over-priced. "Hipster" friendly scene though.

The wine list looked better than it was. Reminded me of the days when I first got into wine and didn't really know much other than, "there's red and there's white." And that's pretty much the wine options Tria gave; red or white (nothing special about them).

The food was EXTREMELY disappointing as well. I don't know if the chef was having an off day or what. But the food was just sloppy and not thought out. Flavors clashing evrywhere... it was upsetting.

- Roasted Beets with Bulgarian Feta Cheese: Just some beets and feta cheese thrown on a plate.
- Tuscan Three Cheese Potato Chips with Smoked Paprika Aioli: Actually doesn't come with the aioli, according to the waitress. The chips were tasty, but you only are served two chips per person.
- Gorgonzola with Fig Jam Bruschetta: Too much fig jam, not enough gorgonzola. I love fig jam too... but they slathered way too much on.
- Smoked Mozzarella, Crispy Prosciutto & Tomato Brushetta: Best dish we got. The vinaigrette on top was very good.
- Tomato Brushchetta: It looked like this dish was literally made by a young kid. The tomato was all cut WAY too big for bruschetta, making it very messy and sloppy to eat. Only good part was the vinaigrette on top.

On the plus side, we had a very prompt and friendly waitress. But I'd just skip Tria and go somewhere worth it.

As good as downtown without the downtown parking fiasco.  Love Sauce.  I always get the Duke, because BBQ sauce/chicken/bacon/mozzarella is never a bad combo.  Its not the cheapest, but you walk out needing a wheelbarrow (in a good way, of course!). I've brought bosses, friends, dates here...not at the same time...that'd be awkward.

Nutshell:  its ALLLL good.  All of it.  People are down to earth, food is flavorful and filling.  Can't go wrong for lunch or dinner.

I have yet to hire Blend personally, but have enjoyed their service and food so many times. 

Over the last year plus I have enjoyed a variety of events and food catered by Josh and Whitney. 

The decadent flavors of fresh hot doughnut holes that are simply indescribably delicious, in flavors you can't imagine.  Not just sweet ones, but savory too. 

A Caribbean 6 course pop up dinner at Pignic. Flavors I had never really tried before. 

In September they catered a Yelp MBC in my back yard. I wasn't in on the food choices or arrangements, I just provided the space. But they were great to work with. They showed up when they said they would. Finished prepping, set out the food and left my kitchen very clean. The Mexican style breakfast for 30 was one more creative and wonderful meal by Blend. 

During Reno Bites Week, a southern style feast. Complete with green fried tomatoes, BBQ, and the fluffiest buttermilk biscuits. True southern hospitality and food was so abundant that night. 

Recently they were part of an open house at the Tannenbaum event center. Blend is the company available to you if you require food at your event there. Josh and Whitney built a lovely cheese and meat table. Rich special cheeses- Brie, triple Creme, mimolette, Parmesan and other above average selections. The meat tray had choice prosciutto and salamis. The breads and crackers looked homemade. My son fell in love with their roasted red pepper spread. He wasn't wrong. As you wandered around the site, their staff brought out plates of other tasty treats to sample. 

Let's face- I might need to get remarried or find some other excuse soon to have Blend cater an event for me soon.  I have never been disappointed in anything they have served.

I went to one of the locations in Tampa and I was so happy when I found out that a location opened up close to my house so I did not have to drive over the bridge as I live in Pinellas County. I always loved their breakfast menu and I feel that there is enough of variety for anyone that attends. I have their chocolate chip pancakes and the pancakes were so delicious. Also along with the pancakes as I did get the combo I also got bacon and their home fries. Their home fries are always cooked to perfection. This is a place that my fiance and I will definitely return to and all I have to say is welcome to Largo.

I've enjoyed Mellow Mushroom Birmingham  and various places in Florida, so was excited to have one in town. I think this location took a little while to get its groove, but is now producing product worthy of the Mellow reputation.

I also love be that they now deliver. 

The kids love the pizza and pretzels and my daughter and I are devoted to the "Holy Shitake:" a white pizza with mushrooms, herbs and spiral of ridiculous truffle aioli. Yum! 
The crust in their pizza has a great chew and a lot of flavor: yeasty with a touch of what I suspect is molasses. 

Oh, and I'm a fan of the mushroom soup. It's warming, rich and earthy. Great comfort food!

I love the atmosphere and service  @ Honey's. This is one of my favorite places to grab breakfast where the food is inventive, delicious and locally grown/ purchased. If u arrive after 9-9:30 on the weekend u will likely have a wait but it is worth it'

Love me some Mazzaro's!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Wow this is a huge compliment coming from this Jersey Girl who also grew up in the gourmet food business. (Daddy owned restaurants as well as 2 gourmet stores).

What ever our craving for fine or comfort foods, rest assured it can be found at Mazzaro's!

Fresh pasta, the cheese room is to die for!, HUGE selection of wines, and not TJ varieties! BREAD, BREAD and more CRUSTY Bread. Heaven in a store for sure!

The meat and prepared foods counter alone is worth the trip. I would drive here from Trinity but now only need to head down 275 woo hoo! 

My recommendations  include any of the fresh pasta's, any bread, pick up some whole bean coffee, cheese and meats. 

Oh, and while you are there stop by the coffee counter for a TRUE crafted cup of Joe. Thank me later! The outside decor is delightful and the aromas inside divine!

My only disappointment is that they are not open Sundays: (

If you love Crab Rangoon, you must try Wang Cai's! It is unique, delicious, and each order comes with 6-8 huge pieces. They are not a "traditional" crab rangoon, but they are very delicious.

Wang Cai is a great local Chinese delivery in Greenwood. You can't beat the delivery times -- I don't think we've ever waited longer than 15-20 minutes!

I love Hollygrove Market. It has become somewhat of a Saturday morning ritual for me. 

For $25 you get two grocery bags chock-full of fresh produce. I always check out their blog and website to see what the "box" will have before I go. If you're looking to add more plants to your diet, the box is a great route to go.

Their blog also provides recipes for the veggies/fruits you might not know what to do with, so it's a good way to branch out if your cooking is in a rut.

Last week they had fresh-picked, perfectly ripe strawberries.  So good.

We ordered the lamb hummus and it was absolutely delicious!! The pitas that come with them are pretty small but super soft. I would recommend 1 pita per 2 people. I ordered the Arais (lamb sandwich), which was to die for. It was so flavorful with every bite!

The inside was super trendy and hipster. I loved the decoration. There's plenty of indoor and outdoor space. I would recommend calling a reservation if you can. I believe reservations can only be made with 6+ parties. 

The server was very attentive and checked on us often. We had a member of our table who is very allergic to nuts and reiterated this to the server on multiple occasions. Despite checking if the meal contained nuts, the meal still came with them! Eek.

This gym is great especially if you're a lane swimmin'/strength training double threat such as myself. I bring gear for both and then assess which area is busier before I delve in. 
I do wish sometimes that there was more strength training areas or possibly a ladies only area. There's been a couple times where major bro dudes have asked to sub in on my sets and then proceed to do like 15 sets.... Ummm that's not right, I always grumble to myself. 
The pool is awesome and has ruined me for 25 metre pools! They just seem too short! And most of the time, besides 6pm, there's plenty of space available. 
I wish there was a super awesome hottub cuz the tepid kiddie pool just doesn't cut it when you got the muscle aches.
When you really look at how many things/classes/areas are available at kinsmen is hard to not love it tho.
Hmm what else? I love the Moo's place and it actually has decent nutritious options available!

I love the Coventry Deli.  Like another reviewer mentioned, it should be called a cafeteria just because of the selection they offer.  And everyone really is great, very kind, and helpful.  

My go-to is the sandwich counter.  I had consulted Yelp before I ever walked in and decided there was no way a "half" sandwich would suffice for my lunch despite what was said in several reviews.. and I was wrong.  First, and foremost, the half sandwiches are just smaller portions of full sandwiches, not actually half a sandwich.  For example, if you order a whole egg salad sandwich, you're going to have a 4" tall egg salad sandwich on your hands, whereas a half egg salad sandwhich is a more managable 2-3" tall.  I eat a lot, and the half sandwich is plenty.  The sandwiches also come with a side.  I recommend the spicy potato salad personally, but all their side salads are pretty good, and you can also get a piece of fruit or chips.  

The interesting assortment of brownies and cake slices strategically placed at the cash registers are quite tasty and usually won't dissapoint.  

I found the oatmeal selection in the mornings to be too sweet for my taste, but it seems quite popular.  

Overall, this is a great place for a to-go lunch (and on occasion breakfast) where -you'll have lots of options and friendly folks.

Panera is something that I grew up with on the East Coast, and I loved the sandwiches and soups there when I was younger.  Nostalgia all the way.

However, having a more adult palate and just changing tastebuds, Panera is, in the world of sandwiches, just a-ok.  For the same amount of money you can buy a fresh, bigger sandwich at Baggins.  I do like that they have the you pick two combo - nowadays I typically get a salad and soup and my husband will get a sandwich and chips.  He will finish off about half my salad as I prefer to load up on the soup :)

I do enjoy their pastries, especially their cookies (peanut butter chocolate chip and snickerdoodle for the win!) 

This location is easy to get to, and the times I have been inside, clean.  I tend to go on off hours though so I would not come back if it was filthy during the slow times.

You always know exactly what you are going to receive at Panera, which is not necessarily a bad thing.  Their sandwiches and salads can be hidden calorie bombs if you are not careful!

I've lived in the area for almost thirty years and this was my first time eating at Tortugas! Recommendation came from a friend who has been here. She knows I love Mexican Food so I was interested in it, I didn't think Tortugas could be as good as my fave, El Limon.

Strike one, the hours on Yelp and on their sign said they were opened at 4:30- when we arrived, the lights were off and it was dark. I really was irritated with that. There is confusion with the info on the website versus the menu. The web says they offer drinks and cocktails etc, the menu says it's BYOB - ummm so which is it?! I asked the server and its BYOB, they offer one free margarita a certain day and time range but I honestly forget what the server told me. I don't drink, so I don't care. I do want other Yelpers to know about the drink situation- remember it's BYOB.

The server was a young lady with strawberry blonde hair, extremely friendly and attentive. They served us delicious chips and a side of luscious pico de gallo. It was fresh, with just the right amount of heat, diced onions and cilantro.  My order was three enchiladas one cheese, chicken and beef with rice, no beans. The rice was tender, moist and flavorful- no dried up peas and carrots either that seem to be the standard in Mexican Rice.  The chicken and steak were delicious and tender, it was shredding right from the fork.  I didn't detect much seasoning though in the meats. The cheese enchiladas was stuffed generously with cheese.  My friend ordered three cheese enchiladas w rice and beans.  

The delicious food and kind service made me forget about the restaurant being closed when I showed up. I would definitely come back again! This may very well replace El Limon as my fave! Can't wait to bring my family here soon.  I think the meals are a little more thank what you would expect but it's worth it- the quality is there!

Keep up the great work, Tortugas!!

Good food, good music, good drinks, friendly waitstaff, clean bathrooms. What more could you want?

We loved the intimate atmosphere and the fact that everyone has a good seat for the music. The menu is mostly small dishes with a few entree size options. We shared the scallops and the Creole burrata which left just enough room in our bellies for the pièce de résistance....the Johhnycake Cobbler! Stone fruit baked with a johnnycake crust and served with a berry ice cream. It was seriously delicious!

Our server was so friendly and the jazz trio that night was great. Overall, it was our favorite meal for the whole week in NOLA and definitely worth walking down to Frenchmen Street for.

I'm so glad to see Bluestone in King of Prussia, it's a welcome relief from the unrelenting Dunkin Donuts and Starbucks offerings. It's a small, minimalist front but they have a surprisingly diverse menu, including a beet smoothie. 

I ordered an iced long black and was admittedly a little worried about my espresso because the barista looked very young but it was very well pulled. I love their Rittenhouse location and am glad to see that the quality carries over.

Really I'd give them 3.5 stars, but that's not an option. Given the choice of the Bottleworks or Tap Room, I'd pick the Tap Room, but the Bottleworks is a good place to go as well (I've been to both several times).  Their beer is solid and the food is decent, it just doesn't seem to be quite as good. The decor is not as inviting or cozy and the temp in there is often too cool for my taste. I do like that they clearly mark their veggie options. I had a salad and their carrot curry soup on my last visit. I wasn't much of a fan of the soup, but give them props for trying something different.  I do love their hummus!  All in all, not a bad place.

I really loved this place.  It was phenomenal!!  The only thing that sucked was the service downstairs on the particular day I went.  The people behind the counter were RUDE.  I went upstairs for a drink with much better service. 

They have a great selection of wines to choose from.  They also have (which I love) a create your own meat and cheese platter.  You pick what you want on it and they weigh it and plate it and serve it.

The outside area is huge and cozy all at the same time.  They have live music and it is just a really great environment.  I would definitely recommend this place. I will also be coming back soon.  I could spend my whole trip here and be satisfied!

I am losing the love here for sure! 5 treadmills have been out of service for over a month so now, all the cardio equipment is over crowded from people using the other stuff since treadmills are down! Ridiculous that it is taking so long to fix this! Also, I am getting bored with all the steroid kings screwing up all the weight machines. They take all the pieces off the machines to use them for purposes they were not intended for and when I want to use the circuit machines, I have to go searching for the handles and clips!! Annoying!! It would be nice if the employees could do this throughout their shift, but they are too busy eating or playing on their phones to notice! This place needs an overhaul!!!!

Guys guys guys! Indianapolis has its very own rooftop bar and lounge. Who would have thought! Granted this is not your typical highfalutin, swanky downtown rooftop lounge like you would find in NYC or Chicago, but it's still a great place to kick back on a warm summer night and enjoy some drinks and quiet conversation while looking out at the Indianapolis skyline.

My friends and I had been hanging out in Fountain Square for the evening and needed a place to wind down the night, and the rooftop lounge above the Fountain Square theater building was just the place for that. It has a quaint location and non-pretentious menu. Don't expect any crazy mixologist sort of cocktails from your bartenders. This is more of a rum and Coke or vodka soda kind of place. But we were grateful for the inexpensive drinks since we had spent a lot of money prior in the evening at some of the more nicer restaurants in the area.

I really enjoyed the soft lighting and they even have some lovely planters on top of the roof there to add to the ambience. Just take the elevator up to the top floor and you're there.

Ok, so this may be a real shocker... but just in case you weren't officially aware; my name is Christy and I love SBUX.  

Now that the formalities are out of the way...I'm sure we can agree that all locations are not created equal. Especially this new Ferguson jewel. Totally in a class of it's own. Plenty of seating options from high tops to a private meeting area equipped with floor to ceiling industrial style pocket doors. There is also faux leather and patio seating perfect for close-quarter intimate conversations over a nice hot cup of Joe. 

I want all locations to mimic this one. I seriously  haven't been as excited as I was when I experienced their virtual drive-thru ordering system since I don't know when! This SBUX is a breath of fresh air for Ferguson and I'm ecstatic to see it here.

~Christy

This was my second time staying and playing. Victoria, the owner, is the best. She's so personable and loves getting her customers setup with a game recommendation. I also appreciate the fact that she's willing to explain the game to you, which is 10x quicker than reading the instruction manuals. She's got a talent for it! 

It's a great place to arrange a get-together with friends and hunker down for the day. It's also BYO-whatever, so that's great too. They have an order book of all the local spots that will deliver, so you don't even have to leave.

Loved this place!  First off, Dane was the hostess and she was so friendly.  There were no tables available in the bar, but she took our name and tracked us down to let us know she found a place for us to sit.  Now that's customer service!  The bar was lively and had a great vibe to it.  There was a young guy, I think his name is Cameron, who was singing.  He reminded me of Michael Buble or Jaime Cullum.  It was just the right amount of music and volume for a Saturday night date.  On tap there was a wonderful selection of craft beers. 

There will be at least 2 future visits for me.  1) with my dog, because they had this really cool dog bowl set up in the coffee shop.  And, 2) to ride my bike there in the afternoon to sit outside on the veranda and enjoy a coffee, or lunch and a beer.

The atmosphere here is quaint, charming, retro, and urban all meshed into one.  I loved it and can't wait to return!  (shhhh, let's keep this place a secret!  haha)

I loved this place from the moment I could hear the music before I could even see the building! And the building made it even more special- the twinkling lights, the quaint design and the well light interior- I knew I was in for a treat. 

Inside , it was like I walked into my favorite kind of Pinterest board. Everything was sooooo sweet and charming.  

I waited in line a few minutes and drooled over the cakes and other desserts before the owner told us we could go ahead and have a seat. We sat outside, where they had candles at each table, there was a sweet floral scent in the air and there were blankets for the customers to use. 

Now for the dessert. I ordered the chocolate cake and a huge portion was brought out. It was so delicious. The mousse layers were thick and creamy.   There was a sprinkling of sea salt on top. Ohhh it was good. What else is there to say? 

Price wise- it was definitely pricey. I knew that going in and it wasn't a negative for me. The ONLY thing that got me was a can of coke, brought out in the can, was $3.  I can handle the $12 piece of cake because I can't get that delicious cake anywhere else...but the can of coke for the price was unsettling. 

No matter what, I cannot wait to go back here!  I want to just live here.

I heart vinyl, oh yes I do. Smelly, musty used vinyl gets my leg shaking. Musty used RARE vinyl gets my heart racing.  This place does that. There are two locations and both are pretty darn massive.  I could go broke in here. I could spend a life savings in here. I could spend a week in here and not see a tenth of the place. Luckily the audiophiles who work here have such a wonderful organizational ability about them and a keen sense of memory that they can always point you to the genre you are seeking. I have found some lovely rarities in perfect condition for some really good prices. I also have purchased new vinyl and they also have competitive pricing as well. 
Banana's is the mecca of vinyl I think. I have ventured in many shops across the country and this place by far takes the cake. 
What makes me even happier is that this fine establishment has been around since I was a teen seeking out rare punk and jazz recordings and it serves me into my mid 30's just the same. All ages will definitely find some lovely melodies here. 

Also, the staff are A+. 
Ba-na-nas!

We came to this facility to have my son's tubes put in by Dr. Steve Parry.  Obviously, any time your kid has to have any kind of surgery you're pretty freaked out.  However the Carondelet Surgery center staff did a good job, and we were relieved.

The facility itself is newer, and appears clean and organized.  There's even a separate play area for kids.  After checking in, we waited for our turn to be called.  Back in the pre-op area it looked like a standard hospital area.  The staff seemed very familiar and comfortable working with kids.  Our nurse had a very reassuring demeanor.  

The whole check in went quickly... and while I was nervous things were being rushed, I was actually grateful there wasn't this prolonged waiting period where our son had time and opportunity to get freaked out.  We changed him into the gown, the doctor came by and asked us if we had any questions, the anesthesiologist came by to check in with us, and then our son was off in the arms of the nurse.  She whisked him away so quickly without goodbyes that he didn't even have time to get upset... smart nurse!

They gave us a pager, and when our son was ready to be picked up from recovery it would go off.  Yay for modern technology--its just like a restaurant!

It seemed like it was less than 10 minutes from the time we handed off our son to the time the doctor was coming out and telling us he did well.  A few minutes after that our pager was going off, and we were directed to pull around back to pick him up from recovery.

Clearly this facility is a well oil-ed machine.  Efficient, organized.  I did feel a little anxious by how quickly everything was rushed around, but it looks like everything turned out well... and you have to love a place who loves your kid, right??

I have a love/hate relationship with the Bridgestone arena. 

I LOVE going to see hockey games here, I hate seeing concerts here! I understand that there are some musical groups that require a large venue for their popularity and/or stage show, but it never sounds very good to hear a live performer at this venue! The only redemption for live shows at Bridgestone is if you have seats on the floor. I have found that that helps improve the quality of the sound and experience. 

The food is horrid, bordering inedible, but if you are desperate I'd stick to popcorn. I've somehow made the mistake of eating here twice with the same results. Gross. 

Parking is pretty nuts unless you want to walk a ways, and most of the garages fill up for big events so be mindful of that... traffic is the same deal. 

Overall, great for sports not for music! :)

My friends were in town and we went looking on Yelp for a steakhouse in Franklin and found this. Wasn't sure what to expect. With the prices I thought it would be a little fancy but other patrons were there in shorts and t shirts. It creates an odd feel for me honestly. Started dinner with the crab cake - AMAZING. Really delicious. Free bread tastes like fried donut holes to me, too sweet. Salad was standard, not bad and not great. Dinner I had the naked salmon however I personally don't consider naked coming with a giant slab of butter on top.... scraped it off. Salmon was ehhhhh, salty and not my favorite. Spinach that came with it was oily, I couldn't even eat it and I love spinach. Husband on the other hand loved his steak - everyone did. I get it, it's a steakhouse so maybe not for me (a non meat eater). Favorite part was the carrot cake. It was literally like a quarter of a cake. Moistest carrot cake I've ever had, I ate around the icing but everyone loved it. It's a tad expensive (our total was $145 including tip) and again, the atmosphere didn't fit to me.  Not sure I'd go back. They also made several mistakes with our orders but they were corrected (didn't bring salad dressing, left us with meals an no silverware, forgot my friends blue cheese, drinks left at bar forever, etc). Not sure I'd try it again.....

Great place for breakfast. The staff their are great and very helpful. The price isn't bad but it's is a chain restaurant. The food came out fast and filled me up quick. Good luck if you can resist the urge of not buying anything in the gift shop. I love the atmosphere and the southern cooking is great.

My overall experience with Cactus was mostly okay. It's a great environment for catching up with friends over drinks for a couple of hours. To start, they give you an ample amount of chips and salsa. The salsa itself had a nice bite to it (I personally love spicier foods, so if spice isn't your thing, take it easy). For food, I ordered the Chorizo Pub Burger, which was outstanding. The chorizo patty was nice and crispy on the outside, with a nice juicy center. Our server was also very sweet and attentive. My only issue with this place was the bartender that was working. The ratio of margarita mix to tequila was very inconsistent, with a taste equivalent to overly sweetened lemonade with barely any alcohol. When we kindly requested the bartender add an additional shot (we even stated we were willing to pay extra if we had to), he gave us a sour attitude about it and proceeded to talk about us to his coworker. To me, that just shows poor customer service skills. Word of advice: if you're going to complain about customers, do it out of earshot next time. If there's a different bartender next time around, I might feel inclined to return because the food was decent.

I've been here on numerous occasions, in fact, it's one of my favourite spots. I love the ambiance and the customer service is always on point. I don't always have a meal but when I do I usually get the jambalaya to the point where I don't even look at the menu.... It's that good, or so I thought! 

I recommended it for my mother in law... No... Wait! I bragged about it to her and she decided to give it a try. The serving was way lighter than what it usually was, there was no sausage in it and they don't serve it with garlic bread anymore. They corrected it after we made mention of it but the experience was really disappointing! I am giving 3 stars based on that but any other time would've been 5 stars.

After I'd had my first pair of jeans for a few months, I wanted to update on how the jeans were wearing. I'm pretty happy that there doesn't seem to be any pilling or wear in the seat or along the inseam. I haven't washed them yet but I have stuck them in my freezer a few times for a couple of days after I sat near a fire and they got a little smelly. I've since gone back to get my 2nd pair, which were a skinnier leg cut. I see it as jeans that wear well and last are an investment--my last pair of chain store jeans were pricey and are already peeled and rubbed out. I am taking one star off though, because all the women's shirts are cut SLIM. I am a full busted gal, and there was no room in these shirts for the bust part. Which is unfortunate, because I love the styling and the look of the clothes. Hopefully someday there will be more space in the shirts!! Service is excellent, and friendly. I'll be back soon to check out the warby parker glasses they now have...

I've been to Picasso and Wine five times over the last two years; once by myself, and the rest of the visits with friends or family. Each time I've attended, a different instructor lead the class. On my most recent visit, the class was lead by Adam Whitney, who is not just an artist of the paint and canvas variety, but a performance artist and entertainer. This by far makes him my favorite instructor, because this experience is intended to be entertainment, and with him it certainly is. Prior to attending Picasso and Wine, I had never so much as attempted to paint artistically since using a Crayola watercolor box in grade school. Even then, I was frustrated with the lack of ability to convey a mental picture into a physical medium, and quickly gave up on being artistic. But after painting my first canvas here, I was inspired by having learned a few basics and acquired a bit of confidence, so I went out and bought my own paint supplies and began painting at home as a hobby. I have since produced some work that I like enough to hang in my home, and I am grateful to Picasso and Wine for having provided the encouragement to have fun exploring artistic expression. I really enjoy bringing people I love here to share in a fun activity and conversation, and maybe (hopefully) they too can come away from the experience with a newfound sense of accomplishment and inspiration.

This is my local branch and I am there often to ship packages or to pick up packages that were too big to leave or that required a signature. The staff is always friendly and helpful and over the years I have gotten to know several of them. One lady in particular always asks about my children and I ask about hers (we both have two boys and she has watched mine grow up). I love walking into a business and feeling like I have a personal relationship with the people working there. 

This branch has a pretty large selection of USPS merchandise as well as shipping containers, etc. They have a self-serve kiosk and mail boxes on site for rent.

This is your typical neighborhood bar in the suburbs.  When visiting my hometown over the holidays I frequently visit here as it is in a great location and perfect place to meet up with a group of people. The bar area is not huge but has a nice atmosphere. They have a great draft and bottle list. The beers can be pricey but they great variety they have makes it worth it. On my last visit I got a pomegranate beer of some sort that was fantastic. My friends ordered chocolate martinis which they loved.  There is also a dining room with lots of seating options. I recommend this for families or large parties.  The menu is huge often times overwhelming. The have entrees and typical bar food of hoagies, burgers and pizzas.  My favorite is there ovals which are specialty like pizzas but often with no sauce. On our last visit we got the chicken cheesesteak oval which was fantastic-all of their cheesesteak hoagies are delicious as well.

Indeed....I am the Dutchess of said Dunkin Donuts, so I should have something to say about it, right?  Umm....it's a chain store that sells donuts and I like donuts?  Okay, kidding aside for the next sentence or three, I'm never going to slam a Dunkin Donuts in TN.  I'm a northeastern er and having DD move into our neck of the wood was a BFD.  Krispy Kremes are lovely, but for the cake donut afficianato, they just don't cut it.  The location is small, has a drive thru and is clean and well kept up.  They don't have butternut donuts (Esquire magazine's professed "ULTIMATE DONUT" - I agree with that - but they have a good selection on weekends.  If you go past 5 pm, its pretty sketchy in terms of selection.   It's a win for Bellevue if not a great step forward for mankind.

Oh, how I wish we could do half stars.  This place doesn't quite deserve 4 stars.

I decided to try El Camino Real on a Tuesday night since it's impossible to get a table on a weekend (see my review of Bar Ferdinand). 

Walking in last night ECR immediately endeared itself to me.  Cibo Matto was playing! Throughout the whole night there was a super fun mix of 80's and 90's music. It was great. Of course it's neither Mexican or Texan, but great nonetheless.  We are in Philly, after all.  I even got the pleasure of watching a server dance like M.C. Hammer. 

The food was delicious.  The pig wings are a stellar idea. Their blue cheese is super strong. The pig wings aren't spicy at all, just wonderfully cooked. My friend and I ordered the brisket sandwich and the short rib sandwich.  We both joked about how the kitchen seemed to throw whatever toppings they felt like on the sandwiches.  The sandwiches are huge, thanks in part to the thick sliced toast. None of the sauces were very hot, but the fries are super spicy. I eventually gave up trying to eat them. 

The place has a great selection of drinks and food.  It's really hard to decide what to order if it's your first time there. The service was decent, if a little slow towards the end.  

The reason I really want to under-rate ECR is how our leftovers were handled. My friend and I both asked to have our food wrapped up.  We each had half of a sandwich, a plate full of fries, and sauce. So the server packs it up, puts it in a plastic bag and places it all next to my friend.  Now, I think I need to state two things.  One, I was in the bathroom when my friend asked to have the food packed up so I don't really know if something was said and misunderstood. Two, my friend is male and I am female (and super pretty! just kidding). But you can imagine my surprise when we get back to my place and attempt to divvy up the food. 

They use the foil containers that fold over a cardboard top. So they aren't super easy to open and close. The first container is our sauces in two plastic containers. Weird, and annoying since it's a waste of packaging.  The second container was only fries.  Both of our fries, combined! The third container was the top piece of bread to each of our sandwiches.  And finally, the fourth was the bottoms to our sandwiches. I'm not sure why our server decided to combine our meals in so intimate a way.  Maybe he assumed we were a couple and heading to the same place?  Even so, that's pretty brazen, and totally out of the norm. 

The place is so popular on Yelp, I really wanted to love it. But in the end, I was just weirded out by their packaging of the leftovers.  Weird.

There are many of these bars on Bourbon Street.  We loved the mix of music at this one and the MC or DJ (whatever you call him) made this bar a hit the night we went and we danced all night - I think maybe even on stage....  Pretty much a dive but we loved it.

Like many stores that line Baltimore Avenue in West Philly, Mood Cafe is privately owned and a sister store to Desi Village and Desi Chaat House. I have frequented Desi Chaat House more often because they have more variety of chaat, but Mood Cafe has more lassi options. I really like their lassi because it isn't that sweet, and my favourite is cardamom lassi. It has a slight tanginess from the yoghurt and just the right amount of cardamom flavour. It's actually really refreshing to drink on a very hot day. Mango lassi is very good also, once again with just the right sweetness and enough mango flavour. This time I ordered Kashmiri chaat and asked mine to be medium spicy. I love eating chaat during the summer months because it's refreshing and kind of helps my appetite when you don't want to eat anything. Just in case you don't know, chaat is one of the favourite Indian street food with all kinds of possible combination of veggies, crunchy Indian snacks, fruits, sauces, and yoghurt. The potential of combination seems endless. 

Mood Cafe is rather small for an eat in. They do have limited chairs and tables. I chose to do a take out (which most times seems more convenient). The service is really friendly and pretty efficient. I think they over made their mango lassi they gave me the extra portion in a small cup! If you are new to this area of West Philly you can choose to eat in, or take your food and drink over to Clark Park and have a picnic!

On beautiful days I love to wander through this "mall".  Today was no exception. 

Had to pick up some cards and a gift for a friend.  Parking isn't difficult depending on day and time.  I usually go to the back and park in the covered parking.  In tucson that is a great feature.

There are a variety of stores and restaurants here so you can find just about anything you are looking for.  Yes, most stores are more expensive.  But they aren't Target.  Don't expect them to be.

Go here.  Do some window shopping.  Bring your dogs as they are welcome and enjoy the views.  A nice relaxing Sunday.

Let's start with what this place does well:

1) Food: The menu is simple... and when you have a simple, short menu, you better do it pretty damn well... and they do. The tacos are simple, affordable, and delicious.

2) Friendliness: You'll see a lot of the same bar staff here as you will at Radio Radio... same folks... and they've always been very fast and very friendly. When we got our food here, the cook even brought out a bunch of homemade hot sauces for us to try... and when we said that we loved spicy things, he went back and got even spicier stuff... and he gave us some free chips to sample all of them. Very friendly and helpful.

3) Atmosphere, this place has a great feel to it. The right amount of antique combined with the right amount of modern.

Now, the limited amount of things that could be improved:

1) Seating: I'd never been here before, so a sign that says 'Seat yourself' would have been handy.

2) Wait staff: Except for the little type face on the little menu at the table that says to 'Order at the Bar'...there is no indication that there is no wait staff.

Minor details, but I prefer not to show up to a restaurant and wonder about the logistics.

All in all, a great place to grab a quick bite to eat, especially if time is of the essence and you're catching a show afterwards in Fountain Square.

What a fun little place! Before I forget, the pickles. Don't forget the pickles. They are so good. It was a great dining experience all around, and service was outstanding!  The inside can best be described as sort of funky country chic.

We shared a burger, an appetizer, and two milkshakes. The saison mushroom burger was excellent, and the pesto was really perfect for a burger.  We had the aubergine for an app, and let me just say I love eggplant. It didn't disappoint though!  The butter pecan shake was absolutely fabulous. 

I will certainly be visiting again!

I am so disappointed to have to give Red Kings 2 a 2 star rating... All other past experiences here have always been great -- the food was delicious and the perfect amount of spice & kick, the griddle meats were fried to the perfect amount of juiciness and crunch, and the cumin dishes were just mouthwateringly fantastic... but tonight, such fond food memories are gone.

Pros:
-- Unusually quick service... normally there would be a ~15 minute wait time for our food to arrive, but tonight it was out to our table within 5 minutes of us placing our order (not sure if the speediness contributed to the lack of flavor in our dishes)
-- Rice here is really good. They steam it with the right amount of water to produce perfect, white fluffy rice grains.
-- They have a new menu that has a lot of pictures (great for individuals new to Szechuan cuisine) 

Cons:
-- Cumin Chicken had no flavor, whatsoever (the onions had more flavor than the chicken)
-- Boiled Beef was way more oily than I last remembered it. I remember the dish being more soup base with chili oil as a flavoring agent and/or enhancer. This time around, it seemed the beef and cabbage were just sitting in a bowl of chili oil and no soup broth.
-- They have lowered the standard spice level they once cooked at...

If this is the new quality standard Red Kings 2 cooks at, I am greatly saddened. My housemates and I loved coming here for warming food during bitter, cold nights. Now, we will have to look elsewhere for delicious, late night eats within Chinatown.

Tiffin is one of the best places in the city to get Indian food (along with New Delhi and sometimes Palace at the Ben). And the fact that they have kati rolls on their dine-in menu  for Tiffin Etc. doesn't hurt either.

I was a bit confused as to how the menus worked when I first walked in, but that was cleared up after I figured out that people do take-out and seating is upstairs, where we could order from Tiffin and Tiffin Etc.'s menus.

We ordered a papdi chaat to start, which was pretty good (chaat is one of those things that I love eating, but then I realize that it's not that hard to make). When I saw kati rolls on Tiffin Etc.'s menu, I was giddy. Kati rolls are basically constructed of roti that may or may not be fried with eggs and then wrapped around tasty filling of your choice (hopefully). I really don't know why I get giddy when I see kati rolls on any menu, but I have to try them when I see them. (I have this same knee jerk reflex towards papdi chaat, masala dosas, and sometimes samosas. Yea, I'm into unhealthy Indian food.) I got the shami kebab kati roll which was great! My friend ordered his dish and a Masala Pepsi; obviously he didn't enjoy it because he didn't like the mix of cumin and salt in his Pepsi. But it brought me wonderful memories of India :)

I'm not sure if they still offer diners both menus, but I would definitely order at least one item from the Tiffin Etc. menu; besides the pizza options that I didn't try, I think Tiffin tries their best to offer street/vendor type food here in Philly.

Guess I've ended up going to more chains lately... I try to be open-minded! This place is pretty good. I think I went to the one in Fort Wayne a while back and it involved country music, so I was hesitant to go here. But my boyfriend really wanted some fresh crab legs, so on we went.

The atmosphere is pleasant, casual, and fun, especially on a sunny summer day by the window, where you can look outside and see the lake right there. There is also outdoor seating as an option, but I generally prefer eating indoors by the window.

The crab (dipped in butter sauce, yum) was possibly the best I've ever had even though our server didn't ask what seasoning we wanted, so it was unseasoned. I love the crab shell opening tools they give you. The Garlic Mussels appetizer was also delicious - maybe a bit overcooked, but delicious.

The service could have been better, since we were not asked about seasoning and only refilled waters once towards the end of the meal. But overall it was a good experience and I would not mind going back.

This is probably one of my most fav places to go play games back in college.   Tho I'm more an adult now (lol), I still enjoy the arcade.  It has gotten pricier than I remembered.  We no longer get tickets cause everything is now put onto the players card.  The games are newer and it looks great in here. But the food is not something I would come to D&B for.  We were hungry after the game at the superdome and decided to eat here instead of at the stadium.  We ordered the bacon wrapped shrimp and steak pasta for me and ribs/chicken wing combo. Let's dive in. 
The pasta dish was super bland.  I had to add salt to it.  Normally I don't even like to add salt to anything ever.  The pasta was soft. The steak medallions were slightly over cooked and the bacon was tasty.  I love the added spinach with my pasta topped with fried spinach.  I miss the blackened chicken pasta! For dessert, we had the Bookie. 

My husband said his ribs were tough to eat and the buffalo wings were too salty.  It's as if the buffalo wings just came out of the oven.  They use bottled ranch instead of making their own.  The fries were soggy as well.  

The Bookie tower for dessert was ok.  They did break the tower down so we can share.  One brownie/cookie topped with a bluebell vanilla scoop of ice cream. You can tell that they had just microwaved a frozen Bookie.  It was hard to eat after a few mins. 

But our server was sweet and provided excellent service. She checked on us constantly as she walked by. Overall we would come back for the games but not for food.

Just as good as I remembered it being in Pittsburgh!

I'm super excited that we got a Primanti Bros here in town. The sandwiches are always so tasty and I love that of the 3 locations that I have been to so far, the consistency is the same and always delicious, no matter which shop I stop into. If you haven't had a sandwich here yet: take heed. These bad boys are HUGE. Like I'm talking size of your head for one half huge. I suggest the capicola and cheese, but no matter what you get, I'm sure you'll be lovin' on it because everything is just too good not to!

Thank you to you lovely Philadelphia Yelpers for this recommendation! Sbraga was a great place for this "party of one" to belly up to the Chef's Counter for the $49, four-course prix fixe menu. The atmosphere is dark, contemporary, and lovely. Great for a nice date, a pre-theater meal, small groups, or post-theater drinks (if space is open at the bar).

First Course- Foie Gras Soup (with Rose Petal Relish) Wow! So many things going on here, this soup was amazing. Very rich and delicious. FYI, watching the chef's crank out what looked like a delicious Beet Tartar, after Beet Tartar, this was a hard choice to make, but I'm glad I did.

Second- Grilled Salmon, sprouts and Vadouvan. I live in a "Vadouvan" down by the river! My excellent server for the night (she was always on point) described Vadouvan  as an Indian curry-like set of spices. This was a good dish!

Third- Meatloaf, Charcoal Potatoes, scallion and Romesco. Lovely presentation, this one got big ups in Yelp reviews, but I just think it didn't live up to the hype. It didn't wow me, it was just okay.

Dessert- Dirt Pudding with homemade Gummy Worms. Since I was basically overlooking the dessert station of the Chef's Counter, I saw a lot of desserts go out. I actually almost ordered off menu after I saw a dish of what looked like three scoops o f berry sorbet on a bed of Pop Rocks go out (off menu). But the Gummy Worms alone, were worth ordering this nice dish. So citrusy, they cut through the chocolate of the Dirt Pudding well. 

I loved Sbraga, and there were so many other good looking dishes on the menu, it will get a return visit!

I had plans for a tea date with my bestie when we both realized we were starving. What were we thinking, anyway, getting tea at noon on a Sunday? Clearly what we wanted was pizza. So pizza we had!

Famoso wasn't that busy, surprisingly. Well, busy but not crazy. We snagged a high table, started gabbing, remembered that we were hungry, then went up to place our orders. I love the lunch-sized-pizza-and-soup combo, especially since their tomato bisque is one of my favourites in the city. I ordered up a soup-plus-pizza-with-some-fancy-Italian-name-combo and then we got back to the gabbing.

The food came out pretty quickly, soup first, then pizza. It was nice and hot, and of course delicious. My pizza (a white pizza) came with arugula and prosciutto, yum! To be honest, it wasn't my favourite pie of all the ones I've tried, but I was still pretty satisfied. Don't even get me started on the soup. Yuuuuum.

And last but not least, gelato for dessert. Bestie and I grew up eating lemon gelato and playing on the swing set in her backyard every summer, so it was only fitting that we both had lemon. While my hubby might make fun of me for only liking the most "boring" flavour of gelato on the planet, I prefer to consider myself a gelato purist. Either way: delicious.

I have no idea why this place has 3.5 stars. It is one of our favorite places to dine in Nashville! 

We are from California and this place makes us miss San Francisco. I love the hipster servers and the healthy food (salmon burgers). Speaking of health... the bacon here is Bentons and amazing! One of the few places in town that serves Benton's bacon. Their avocado/bacon burger is delicious and so is their locally grown beef. 

The service here is awesome as well. I went in one day with my dog and did not want to leave him in the car in the hot Nashville weather so the Burger Up people let him sit out in the patio with me. They even brought him some cucumbers and water. So sweet of them! It really shows they want to make their customers feel comfortable and welcome. 

We will always be going back.

I really wanted to like this place. They put peppers in EVERYTHING. Every single side including the cornbread was chock full of peppers which I hate. 
The pulled pork itself was delicious, tender not fatty. 
We were there around 5 on a Sunday. They were packed. We ate with dirty plates of the people who sat at our table before us bc service was so chaotic. When the server brought our food I asked for utensils and she looked at me like I had 3 heads and walked away. I did not know it was self service on the silverware. How would I I'm a tourist??? If you like peppers you'll probably love all of the food. Just wasn't for me. Go outside of meal rush if you want any type of service. And for heavens sake get your own silverware.

Stopped in here earlier this week for a bite to eat with my lil sis and her bf. Nicely decorated, wonderful service, and decent food.  I arrived a little late so my sis and the bf had already devoured most of the calamari. They seemed to enjoy it. I managed to sneak one bite and I thought it was fine - not outstanding but not bad either.  Wines were well priced and I sipped a lovely glass of pinot noir with my meal. 

My sister and I both started with caesar salads.  Salad was standard but good. My sister tried to order the lobster ravioli but they were out.  Her second choice was the seafood linguine and she was pleased.  I didn't get to taste but I from the looks of the sauce splashing around I think it could have been reduced a little more. Her bf ordered the chicken tortelloni and he devoured it - meaning I didn't get a bite. Again I thought the sauce could have been a bit thicker but that's just what I gathered from the appearance.  I went with the veal scallopine picatta.  I absolutely loved the roasted veg on the side and thought the sauce had a pleasant lemony caperyness to it (yes, I made that word up). The veal I thought was okay but if I were to order the dish again I might go with chicken.  We all shared the tiramisu for dessert and it was another standard but tasty dish.  

We were there 5:30/6ish and were the only ones in the back dining room at first but as we were finishing up the room was getting more crowded.  This place looks like it caters to an older crowd as we were the youngest table in the restaurant.  

All in all - decent food but I'm not sure I'd go out of my way to return.  If you're in the area though it is definitely worth a visit.

HipCityVeg is a great place for meat lovers to try something outside their comfort zone. I love meat, all kinds of meat, so I didn't think I'd be satisfied with an all veggie sandwich. Govinda's is good, but after eating their chicken cheesesteaks again and again, you'll realize that you're just eating bread (seitan) with bread (the bun or wrap) with a small helping of peppers. The focus is not on the seitan or soy meat but on all of the delicious, wonderful ingredients that are married to it. For fast (or speedy) food, this is really good. The Crispy HipCity Ranch is also delish. The Bella Bistro is a big portabella mushroom sandwich. Many vegetarians will claim that portabella mushrooms taste almost exactly like beef. It doesn't. It's good, but to call it beef would be insulting to both beef and mushrooms. The Bella Bistro is a nice, hearty sandwich filled with plenty of red onions and artichokes, a couple of slices of tomato (from possibly a small beefsteak tomato), arugala, and olive tampenade all in a big multi-grain roll. Be forewarned, your breath will stink of onions when you're done, but it's sooo good. The Fajita Wrap with its blackened soy chicken, peppers, onions, pico de gallo, and avocado is a little more forgiving. The use of intense flavors in both sandwiches masks the fact that you're not eating meat. The Buffalo Bella is another yummy. I find myself ordering the Philly Steak quite often these days because of its delicious mix of soy meat, mushrooms, and onions. The Jerk Caesar Salad is my only nonfave so far. There's too much salad compared to the protein portion. Give this place a try. The servers are friendly, which makes the wait in the occasionally long lines bearable. It's not exactly a sit-down place as there is limited seating, but on a warm, sunny day, I can think of few places around Rittenhouse Square that can provide you with a more satisfying sandwich that you can enjoy while sitting in the park people-watching. My only gripe is they took away the Kid's Steak from the kid's menu. Now I can't really introduce my little ones to the wonderful sandwiches here since they're not really sized appropriately for kids.

It took me a while to finally try the Buddy brew in Hyde Park. I wasn't disappointed! The coffee is really good! I love the decor and clean inviting atmosphere.  Hyde Park Village has been really improving a lot lately. I also love supporting locally owned businesses.

I've been in the Hyatt Regency before because Ruth's Chris happens to be one of my favorite restaurants, but I've never had an opportunity to stay overnight. I needed to extend my December staycation, and the Westin didn't have the appropriate rooms available for all of us. So one of my friends went on Priceline and got this 4-star Downtown hotel for approximately $70 after taxes for several December nights.

The good:
*Front desk was efficient and effective. I was not the primary roomholder, but I didn't have any trouble checking in. However, we needed to actually extend this staycation extension also without the primary roomholder, so it was a bit tricky to change the name of the room over to another person. They handled it with aplomb. 
*We got connecting rooms without much trouble.
*The rooms are comfortable, clean, and nice. It's a solid hotel room. Some rooms have a straight on view of the Arch (not ours). 
*The bathrooms are nice in that they have an extra sink outside of the main bathroom. I love that kind of stuff. But they were kind of stingy on the towels. Three bath towels for a two queen bed room? How does that work out?
*They have amenities galore if you've forgotten toiletries at home...and believe me, I had. It's also a really nice touch that when you call for them, they call you by the roomholder's name. 
*Really nice 24 hour fitness center including water, cold wet towels, and earphones. 

The bad:
*It's not that quiet. I was reminded of my college days in Chicago...all night, I heard the traffic even though our room was facing 4th instead of the highways.
*Parking is $28 for valet, $8 for self parking. Rumor has it there is a $3 garage north on 4th, but we never found it. We usually did street parking because we were gone all day and back after 7 PM.
*Internet is $10/day, but free in the hotel lobby. 
*Obviously, since it's a nice hotel, the attached restaurants have pretty high prices for average food. They are a couple of choices from Ruth's Chris to Red to a sports bar (which does have a free foosball table) to Starbucks. 
*They do take a while to clean a room. I'm not sure why. One day, we came back to find them cleaning the room, so we decided to go out for a late lunch. Three hours later, they were just finishing up the room. 
*The key cards stopped working midway in our stay. Only the roomholder could get them re-activated so that was a pain to recollect all the keys for her to go downstairs to do so. 

Check in is at 3 PM, check out is at noon.

I hit up Katie's Saturday evening for some pre pub crawling munchies.  This was imperative in sustaining my abilities to drink throughout the evening!

Since our upcoming pub crawl was a "tacky" theme, and we were dressed full on redneck, we decided to sit outside as to not draw too much attention.  This attempt really didn't work since me (Sissy) and my husband (Bud) started a conversation with everyone who walked by.  Everyone seemed to get a big kick out of us...though some didn't know if it was a joke, or if we really talked and dressed like that.

Anyhoo...

Service and food were both great.  Our server had fun getting in on our redneck act, inquiring as to when my baby was due, fussing at Bud for being an alcoholic, etc.  

I immediately checked in on Yelp and got a deal for 10% off of all appetizers.  Winning!

We decided to just share some appetizers.  We got the crawfish beignet.  I would say this is more like a calzone vs. a beignet because it wasn't fried, it was baked.  Nonetheless, it was delicious, though pretty pricey at $12.95.

We also got the Boudreaux pizza.  With garlic cream sauce, tender cochon du lait and roasted garlic, it's one of my favorite things on the menu.

We finished our snacking off with an order of crabcakes.  I thought the cakes were just o.k., but my other friend loved them.  I really enjoyed the Remoulade sauce.  Bud thought the sauce tasted like thousand island dressing...but he's a redneck and this was his first time to the big city, so what does he know?

Next time for Katie's will be for the brunch, which has bottomless mimosas for $15.  Again, winning!

Lovely landmark that is significant to Alton! I remember as a child coming here and recently came back to check it out. Looks a lot nicer and very clean. It's currently under construction. No trials or hiking area. J

This is just a beautiful space when there is nothing going on. Statues, large shade trees, benches, a place for bikes. Now, with events that happen here make it a GREAT space. I've been here for a few events. The last was the 2016 BBQ and Blues Festival (Saturday). I saw and heard some great musicians. They had venors with super art and craft things, tee shirts, booze and beers. Some great places had food, but i didnt have a chance to sample. 
THE MUSIC: Jon Cleary and the Absolute Monster Gentlemen were awesome with their blues New Orleans tinged sound. It rocked, it had soul, it had feel. The crowd was into it and jammed along. 
The headliner was Taj Mahal.  He is an old timey blues man, a multi instrumentalist. It was soulful, and laid back. Just beautiful to the ear. 
There was an artist on stage who painted a portrait of Taj during the set. It was auctioned off for charity after the set. 
I love the fests here!

I had my first, and most likely last, experience with hot pot at Urban Shabu. I went in on the Groupon deal with a few coworkers who wanted to be ~adventurous~. The restaurant is located in one of those bizarre Chinatown strip malls that looks totally abandoned on a weekday evening but that is probably bumping on a Sunday afternoon. 

There were only a couple of other tables occupied when we arrived and it stayed that way the whole time we were there. The only way to describe the decor is a little bizarre, but that doesn't really matter anyways, right?

Like I said, it was my first experience with hot pot. The waitress dropped off a little paper pamphlet with each of us that turned out to be the menu. It was broken into different sections of broth, veggies, meats, etc. I had no idea how to fill it out and had to ask her for advice. We each ordered our own thing in our own little pamphlets, but when the plates and plates of food were brought out, there was no distinction between who ordered what. That was mildly frustrating as some of the items were unique and not everyone could tell what was what. 

I didn't love my broth. I didn't love the experience of having to cook everything myself and wait. I didn't love smelling and feeling oily. I didn't love the piles of raw meat and seafood on the table. It was just an overall unsettling dining experience and one that I am not eager to repeat any time soon. Plus, we still ended up paying about $30 each even after the Groupon. No idea how that happened. Free parking in back, if you're so inclined.

I think it's a well-established fact that Narberth is the "cutest" town on the Main Line. That said, this movie theater is living proof.

From the outside, it seems kind of quaint in a vintage sort of way, which holds true when you walk inside as well. However, the actual theatre rooms are like any other modern theatre rooms you would expect. Additionally, there are only four movies being screened at any given time, so you have to hope your top choice is playing.

The price is a bit outrageous, but that's to be expected for the Main Line. Sure, it's just as easy to wait for movies to stream online these days, but you're paying for the experience! What's a trip to the movies without popcorn, right?

I actually really like this movie theater and love to come with my friends every once in awhile. There are lots of cozy restaurants and bars nearby so it's easy to make a dinner-movie-drinks night possible. Parking is effortless as well.

Went here on a spring saturday afternoon. There was a line out the door but got my food in about 10-15 minutes. I tried the vegan steak, sweet potato fries wit aoli sauce and ziggy burger. I am not a vegan/vegetarian. The vegan steak tasted like it was vegan. It was just OK. I guess i am biased in the fact that i live in the heart of south philly where there is a pleathora of chessesteaks and i LOVE cheesesteaks!! Dont expect to eat the same stuff you get a tony lukes. The ziggy burger was ok too. What I did like was the sweet potato fries. I wouldnt go out my way to come back here but that is just my preference because i dont normally eat this kind of food. Staff was friendly. You may have trouble finding a table but you can always take your food and sit at rittenhouse square park.

I love Asahi Sushi. I should preface this review by stating that if it involves mayo, a fryer, or fruit; I can promise you I'm not interested. I don't eat fancy rolls. Fancy sushi for me, is a unique fish that I haven't had before. 

Asahi's fish is fresh. As a result, the flavor is full and rich and the texture is perfect. Their house salad isn't the best that I've ever had. Their seaweed salad is good as well. I also really enjoy their vegetable tempura and the Japanese pickles.  

If you are a nigiri sushi fanatic, ask the sushi chef what he recommends. The other night he suggested monkfish liver. It was really good. He's also got my boyfriend and I hooked on this amazing tuna and bonita. One of the rolls that we do enjoy here is the salmon skin roll. Crunchy and delicious. 

No one eats here. I don't know why. As a result, the service has always been really great! I don't think that they are slower than any other sushi restaurant. 

My ONLY problem with Asahi is that they are located in Belle Meade and it's a small hike for us to get over there. It's probably for the best. If they were closer, I'd probably turn into a piece of sushi because I'd eat here everyday.

I've always wanted to ride on a cruiser along the beach. If that's what you're looking for - come here and rent from Wheel Fun Rentals!

Pros:
Plenty of bikes (cruisers have 3 speeds, mtn/terrain bikes - whatever you prefer)
Bikes for families (seats 2-4 adults and 2 small children or a puppy in the front)
Location is prime
2nd hr free coupon on a near by downtown info table (i love finding coupons)
Baskets & Helmet options (no extra charge)

Cons:
Service is slow 
Returning our bikes too around 10-15 min

My 1+ and I went on our Santa Barbara coast biking journey - leaving it open ended as to how long we'd keep the bikes.  After 2 hours - I was done haha.  So the coupon for the 2nd hour free worked without any problems. 

If I came back, I'd definitely rent from them again!

So this is the 22nd ballpark I have visited in the MLB and I really have to say this one this one is up there as a fun one. There is so much space in the concourse it is unbelievable. I love the standing room area under the concourse where you can just eat what you got and not.miss the game. There's a bunch of game stuffs in the right center field.area, I'm presuming for children as it involved stomping on some DDR like.machine and there was some trivia thing too. There's all sorts of restaurants in the bleachers area and lots of souvenir shops. The ushers and staff were very pleasant and friendly and.helpful.  I also must say the Philly fans are great.. bless their hearts, their team is the worst team in MLB  this year and the fans were still out there in the rain cheering on their Phillies. Oh yeah, and the liberty bell thing lights up and rings if they hit a home run or win which was cool, but kind of not cool.since they beat my.cubs. haha.  Oh yeah.. they also have these phone charger things in left field but all of the chargers were broken ! What is wrong with some of you people who don't know how to insert a charging device into your phone gently ???!  Oh yeah, and one more thing., the reason it's not five stars is because Of that blasted "get loud " nonsense that flashes on the screens every time there are two strikes. Seriously, Philly, you should know when to get loud without a video board telling you. Shame on you all .

I feel a little guilty giving this place 3 stars when everyone seems to love it so much, but oh well!

So, to begin, we managed to find parking quite easily in the underground parking garage. We actually found a spot right next to the elevator that took us up to the entrance of the museum, so that was a good start to our visit! Parking would have been quite expensive for the garage, but the museum validated our ticket so that we could leave the garage for free - another plus :) On the negative side, I thought the admission tickets for the museum were kind of pricy: $15 for an adult ticket? Not outrageous, but a bit more than I expected for a pretty small museum.

Anyway, we paid for our tickets and began our visit with the "Reel West" special exhibit. This could be a generational thing (I'm in my early 30s), but I thought this exhibit was super boring. It seems like this exhibit, which includes various mementos and outfits from old Westerns, would be interesting to older people that grew up watching the relevant TV shows and movies, but it was not interesting to me at all. Maybe just an issue of personal taste, though.

Our next room contained some really nice paintings of Western landscapes and Native Americans as well as a few interesting sculptures, so that improved my mood quite a bit. Unfortunately, the neighboring room was under construction or something, so we likely missed out on some other good pieces.

We then went down to the lower level of the museum, but it didn't seem to contain anything interesting, so we journeyed up to the top (and final) floor of the museum. There was definitely a lot of content up there, so I'm glad we checked it out! First, there were at least a couple of rooms dedicated to one particular Native American artist - unfortunately, I was not a huge fan of his work.
