Once she described the pear dessert I was sold. And AGAIN, I was blown away by its magnificent deliciousness. Perfectly sautéed pears with mascarpone whip, 2 tiny gluten-free cookies in a sauce so superb you'll wanna slap yo mama! After taking the last bite I was immediately saddened it was all over. The dessert was small enough to satiate but not good enough to leave you wanting more.

Finally, Tasha was an excellent server; very informative, knowledgable of the menu and perfectly personable. I took myself on a tour and was in awe of the wine cellar located on the second floor. Andre invited me inside to take a gander and even allowed me to snap photos...I appreciated his hospitality. 

I'm eager to return for the Skatewing dish; hopefully it's not gone by the time I make it back. I love this place for so many reasons but I'll stop here I'm way over my word count.

~Christy

Only slightly more expensive than your typical fast food joint, the delicious burgers and exceptional fries are worth the drive to Sherwood Park. They are NOT stingy with the fries, oh boy do they give you a lot. I'm not a big fan of the cajun style fries but if you love spicy go for it. Unlimited toppings on the burgers and there are plenty to choose from.

I love this cute little BYOB with Thai and Laotian dishes that pack a nice, flavorful punch.  We were here for UC Dining Days and the dishes were great.  I had the chicken satay app with the red curry chicken, and found both to be very good.  The satay was juicy and flavorful with a great peanut dipping sauce, and the curry was very solid although it wasn't very spicy.  I also had a few bites of the triple flavor tilapia in the sweet and sour sauce, and really like the crispy, pan-seared fillet combined with the garlicky sauce.  Will definitely have to get this next time.  Most restaurants like to fry the fillet when they make a sweet and sour dish but pan searing actually brings out the flavor more and gives that delicious crispy exterior without killing your arteries.  We finished off with the mango sticky rice and coconut rice pudding.  While the mango sticky rice was very good, I liked the coconut rice pudding more because I love all things coconut and this was a delicious coconut-based concoction.  If you are in the area this week, and need to grab a bite, definitely stop in for the $15 dining days special.  It's a great deal and the food is very good.  They also have homemade beef jerky at $6/order, which I couldn't resist getting to-go; while it wasn't as fantastic as my aunt's homemade jerky, the meat was very well-marinated and flavorful and great paired with the accompanying chili paste.  The ambiance is very cozy and the unique curry soup bowls add a nice touch.  Service was friendly but we did have to ask for water refills a few times.

First, thank you reviewers! I went to this restaurant because you all recommended it so highly and it was well worth it!

This was for my birthday dinner and it has to be one of the best I've had in years.  It just goes to show you that you can't judge a book by it's cover or size!  This tiny restaurant looks like nothing much from the outside, but it's clean and nice inside.  The staff was so friendly and prompt with everything.  The food service was quick - and the dishes huge!!  

We had so much trouble picking what to eat that we'll have to go back soon and try new things.  

This was a great restaurant - even meat eaters will love it!!

Have been here twice because my hubby saw a great deal online for a season membership. Honestly, the place is not horrible but just too far away for us (2hr ride). We have a toddler who LOVES the kiddie section which is tiny (infant to age 4/5) I have never been on the big slides so I can't comment in them. The lazy river, which I usually love, has a dirty feel and smell to it. 

The outside, when hot, is actually a nice surprise. They have a dj that plays cool music by the bar. (I have only been there on wknds therefore not sure how often DJ is there) the outside has a very cute and pretty cool kiddie section (probably for up to age 4/5).
The outside also includes a big wave pool.

Overall I think it worth it if you have kids from toddler- about early teens, older would probably get bored. Try it if you don't have to travel too far. Arrive nice and early for close parking and no lines for entry. 

Oh they also have a small arcade indoors which again is cool for the ages I mentioned.

Hope this helps. I would go more often if the drive wasn't so far since we are members.

So we found our way back here now 3 months later after my previous review. The wife and I chose to eat here(vice carry out) this time and it was a little after noon. It was quite loud and there were a lot of people here, but that shouldn't come as a shock given the time of day and proximity to the base. Big menu, but we chose the BBQ pork noodle soup(her) and the chicken pad see ew(me). I really liked my pad see ew and ended up eating the whole plate. It was a pretty decent amount of food that I didn't think I'd be able to finish. My wife had the same thing she had the last time we came here, and still loved it. Our total pre tip with two soft drinks came to $25. Not a bad place at all. I believe we'll be back again, either after the lunch rush or picking up takeout.

I've been here twice for lunch.  Good food.  Love the fresh guacamole made at table side.  I've ordered #4 lunch and then the chicken fajitas.  Both good.  Service is good.  The patio seating is a nice touch.  

This place could stand a little PR.  The only reason I knew about it is because a friend recommended it and he lives on the same road as this restaurant.  Its signage is practically non-existent from the road.

Another Triple D!  The food was awesome! The decor and atmosphere are fun and funky!  Guy had the Big Jerk and Kale salad which we had and loved every bite!  It did seem a little chaotic for service and food time but we'll go back!

Casa is the only place I rent movies. I think they are the only movie rental place left in town unless you are a redboxer.  

I love walking in to the smell of popcorn and finding old movies I forgot existed, while renting new movies I'm anxious to watch as well. The customer service is always great and you can almost always get varying reviews from the peeps behind the counter.

This is definitely a place you can get lost in the aisles and not realize how long you have been there. It locally owned and has been around nearly as long as I have been alive.

It worth the visit--even if you are just looking, but like Arnold, You'll be back!

When we pulled into the parking lot, my dining companion immediately said "Looks like a wingstop".  After walking in and seeing the menu, I had to agree.  Similar concept.  I was amused to see random menu items like crab rangoon, fried pickles and Korean beef tacos on a wing menu.

I decided to order the same meal as I would at Wingstop to compare.  Parmesan garlic wings with fries and ranch dressing.  The combo was $6.99, and an extra 70 cents or so for a large ranch dressing (bummer to charge extra for it!).  Dinner companion (DC) ordered the chicken strips in the Hot Mama! sauce, with mashed potato.

The wings took 10 minutes to cook, and when they came out they looked pretty tempting.  Big pieces of parmesan, but not drowning in sauce.  Crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside, just like they should be.  The size of the wings varied pretty widely.  I had a 5 piece and 3 were what I'd consider normal while 2 were considerably smaller.  I was pretty disappointed with the taste though.  They weren't very flavorful.  Not much garlic at all, and I love garlic.  The fries were just plain fries with some seasoned salt.. not the magical awesomeness of Wingstop fries.  

DC was kind enough to let me try his boneless wings (a rarity, to talk him into sharing!!)  They were strangely thin pieces of chicken, in almost a tempura type batter.  Bonus points for that, since most breaded tenders are overwhelmingly breaded.  The Hot Mama! sauce was pretty good, started out with a sweet honey taste and quickly transitioned over to a heat.  Too spicy for me (I'm a total spice wimp) but a tasty few bites.

Overall, DC and I agreed we still like Wingstop better for now.  I'll go back, because a) it's so much closer, b)  I have a thing for fried pickles and c) i want to try out the Thai chili lime flavor.

Let's just say I had very high expectations when I read that this place was named Ben's BBQ & Beer and was not disappointed. Living in Bensalem there are a ton of chain restaurants in the area, so it is hard to find a good mom & pop place, but even harder to find a good BBQ place. The famous one is Smoken Dudes around town, and I was not really impressed by the taste or the prices, so I'm glad that we saw the sign for Ben's BBQ - which by the way is VERY easy to miss, since it is located inside the hotel and the sign is not upfront in on Street Road at all, so make sure you just pull into the Best Western Hotel after the Dunkin Donuts.

Alright, well the location situation aside, because it is kind of awkward to walk into a hotel and not be staying there, but walk into the back just to eat. The restaurant area looks like a hotel lobby that wasn't given the full permission to be a BBQ pit. I was thrown off by that situation a lot, especially because it didn't even smell like BBQ! But, loyal to my review reading, I still decided to give it a shot. There was a wonderful bartender, an older woman, who was taking our order and gave us great recommendations. 

I decided to go with the coffee rubbed brisket - because omg that sounded amazing and the hubby went with the smoked sausage which was keilbasa for the day. Let's just say if I could eat this coffee smoked brisket everyday for the rest of my life, it might still not be enough! It was melt in your mouth good, with a smokey, but sweet flavor, just perfection. The hubby's kielbasa was great flavor too, neither one of us wanted to share our plates! As for the sides, the Mac n cheese was creamy and out of this world! And the baked beans were like I've never had, also amazing. We both got platters, which were good sizes, but enough for one person on the meats. They do give you 3 sides, which is awesome, I could've probably just done with 2. 

As we licked our plates from the delicious meal, our Bartender told us the history of Ben's BBQ and how they went from a station in the corner of the lobby to a full restaurant recently. The owner also has a catering business that does well. She told us about their craft beer selection and how everyday is happy hour with $4 16oz crafts! They have an array of sandwiches and appetizers which I would love to come back in and try. The only thing I did wish they had was more ambiance, maybe some music playing or even have the volume on of the tvs in the bar. It was creepily quiet, and it would probably attract more people from the hotel. Needless to say, COME TRY THEM OUT, I can't wait to go back!

Hey now! This place has to be putting out the best Jewish deli food in the area. I already loved this place but a couple weeks ago I asked them for a half corned beef, half pastrami on grilled rye with Swiss and Russian and it was quite an experience. Not exactly on the menu but they were happy to do it.  I'm hoping they'll start calling this The Joe. 
I thought of that sandwich this morning and mentioned it to a friend and she wanted one too (she wants to go back tomorrow and get three to split between the two of us).  This time we added cole slaw which added a sweet crunch to the best sandwich I've ever had. The grilled crust is where all the flavors come together. I might dream about it tonight. Try it, you'll like it. And please refer to it as the Joe special.

When I travel up to the Great White North, I usually end up wandering around a Canadian Tire.  And I keep some Canadian Tire Money in my wallet for good luck, as some have told me that it's sometimes more valuable than the Loonie.

I have been in better Canadian Tire Stores than this one.  However, when you're on business and you're bored at the end of the day, there's plenty browsing here to keep you busy and happy.  It's also an inexpensive place to buy an ice scraper, gloves, or anything else you might have forgotten to pack or considered regarding climate differences.

The sliders, cheese fries and donuts are delicious! Sliders are juicy and made to perfection! Cheese fries have a cheese mixture that almost reminds you of a gravy texture. Non the less the taste is awesome! They have this soda called "mexi-cane"? Better than your coke! Loved this place!

I. love. this. place. 

I can't put a finger on the exact reason why...but maybe that's why it's so great. There isn't just one thing that makes Khyber Pass a great place to go to. 

Saturday was gorgeous and we set out to try new places and get our day drink on. We landed at Khyber's and were immediately greeted with a surprisingly crowded but friendly atmosphere. The beer list is extensive and exciting if you are in to the beer scene. Lots of new things for me to try and the sudden surprise that...OH MY DEAR LORD THEY HAVE PO BOYS, and lots of them! I got the cat fish po boy with a side of collard greens and the mac and cheese. Heaven. Seriously. What is better than an afternoon of funky beers over fried fish and mac with your friends.

Nothing. :)

This place as everything is freshly made. The display of the donuts were amazing as they taste as good as they look. Their salad is simple but extremely delicious. The crispy chicken sandwich was so good and well-done. I love every bite of it. The donuts are wonderful, especially the berries and cream. The price for the items are reasonable and perfect for lunch/light dinner.

I want to love this place, but really...it's just OK.

I think the only appeal is the unlimited mimosas, other than that I wasn't impressed with the selection. The setup could be better too. All the dishes were in one big room, but there was hardly any food or selection. Nothing really wow'd me, the setup and selection was kind of sad actually... Tampa really needs to step it up with their brunches. The scrambled eggs were good and so was the belgium waffle ( which you order off the menu, but it's not an extra cost).

I think people mainly come here for the crab legs and mimosas, so if that's all you want, you will be happy. There were barely any lunch/hot items as well.  I think Vegas, Atlanta and DC brunch buffets spoiled me because this brunch was not impressive or that great.The only thing I got seconds of was the pasta salad and scrambled eggs. The desserts looked good, I ordered bananas foster from the menu. Also the dining room areas are a little dark and the place feels a little dated.

Summary: The service was good. The buffet cost is $35, but very limited selections. Menu options are a nice touch since buffet is so small. Nice views of the bay. Unlimited Mimosas is the best thing about this brunch.

Great restaurant inside of a hip hotel. We had the conch croquette, steak tartar, curried goat and the mousse for dessert. The bread at the start was awesome! biscuits with chive butter. soo good. 

I had the noble gardens drink (gin, tequila, poblano, cilantro, celery, cucumber) - refreshing and interesting.

The food was very good - although we thought the curried goat was overhyped. We totally love goat, and this is their signature dish - but it just didn't do it for me.

Service is really good and coming on a weekday early made for a chill and enjoyable experience.

Stone Water Spa & Salon is the ULTIMATE retreat to relax and unwind!  In the hierarchy of luxurious-ness, it's hard to top this place!  

Service: I've gotten a mani/pedi here and it costed about $50 (I know, it's not cheap) but they DO take their time with you and give you the attention you deserve for that amount of money.  I think I was there for about 2 hours for the entire service.  For your pedicure, they drop one of those bath bombs from the Lush soap line and you get to choose the scent!!  YUM!  I've also had my hair deep conditioned and the lady was also very attentive and did a great job.  I just love the Kerastase products they use.  It's simply the best!  Their spa services are standard and it really depends on the person you have and what you're getting.  

Ambiance: This place is huge!  They have their mani/pedi station and salon on the first level and all their spa services on the second.  Be sure to CLEAR your schedule when you book an appointment here.  You want to take your time in this place and you'll feel so relax and good about yourself that you won't want to do much for the rest of the day (except for shop, maybe) or you'll feel so energized and refreshed, you'll be super productive when you get back to work!   

Location: It's located inside Plaza Frontenac so you know this spa is going to be a bit pricier than most.  It'll be easier to get to if you try to look for parking by Saks Fifth Avenue.

With all the stellar reviews I decided to stop in recently and order sesame bean curd and a pizza roll. The family that runs the restaurant were all very kind and gave me s free can of soda. The restaurant was clean and decorated with handmade flowers crafted from beads. It was entertaining to study them and try to figure out how they were made while waiting for my food!

I had high hopes for this restaurant but have to say I felt incredibly let down by what I received. The pizza roll I ordered turned out to be an egg roll- strike one! What was most disappointing was the bean curd. It had a water downed type sauce and the flavor was unlike any other bean curd dish I had ever tried. It had a weird flavor that just wasn't good. It was sort of a watery sour sauce that I couldn't really stomach. 

I'd love to try another dish and give them another chance but the flavor was so awful I don't really want to waste any more money here. 

Nice place but order at your own risk!

I really love that they brought more acai bowls to Valrico...that's one thing we're lacking over here. In my opinion, it could of used more acai at the bottom. They don't blend it with almond milk like everyone else, so instead of a fluffy smoothie texture, its small and icy. The toppings were great and the granola (that they make in house) was tasty. Worth a try!

A great place for breakfast, big salads and take-out. My husband, who considers himself a turkey club expert, loves the one here. I would skip the alluring dessert case, however. We have yet to be pleased.

I have never had a bad meal at meadows! I have come here since I was little and would order the "Miss Piggy" every time (ravioli). Eventually i graduated to a bigger portion of ravioli. I love their pasta and sauce.. it's obviously not gourmet but it does taste good! My mom is a fan of their gyros and my dad seems to love their seafood platters. The salad bar is always stocked and has a decent variety of topping and their soups are phenomenal! I always try to go on days when they're serving cream of broccoli because it is by far the best soup I've ever had. The breakfast they serve is also reasonably priced and always a decent portion. Their omelets are what i usually go for and they are always full of flavor and very large! They also have French toast and Belgian waffles with ice cream (which is my guilty pleasure on fat days!) 

The place is a little dated. I don't think the decor has ever changed since I began coming here almost 20 years ago. It also has a strange odor that seems to be stuck from years ago when they had a smoking and non-smoking section. It never seems dirty, just a different smell. 

I don't think I've ever had bad service from here. The waiters and waitresses do seem to be juggling many tables and may take a while to get to you but they're all for the most part extremely friendly!

I had a really nice lunch at Kawa with my husband and one of my daughters last week. The parking lot is a bit tight but we were able to get a spot - it was the holiday season though, and I think it probably gets a little more hectic during a usual work week.  Something to keep in mind.

Our waitress was so sweet and helpful.  The food was great and presented beautifully - the dishes they used were all so cool that I wanted to take them home (I think the waitress was laughing at me a little as I oohed and ahhed over everything).  Loved the décor as well, from the tables to the seat cushions to the artwork on the walls. It's not a large space, but it's not too small either.  Overall, there's a really cool vibe in the place.

The food was really good - we tried a bunch of stuff.  We started with the fried vegetable spring rolls (two per order - we should have gotten two orders, or maybe they should add one more?  it wasn't enough of an appetizer for three people). My daughter enjoyed her sushi platter (it came with a nice little salad) and my husband liked his ramen soup.  I had a steak teriyaki platter which came with some really good rice and sautéed veggies (I actually ate my meal with chopsticks - first time ever!  So what if I had to stab the steak pieces!?!).  My meal also came with a cup of miso soup - it was good but I just don't see what's so special about miso soup.

We ended the meal with the green tea snow ice which was tasty - the interesting part was the sweet beans that are served along with it.  Yes, actual beans - sort of like baked beans with the sugar but not the BBQ flavor.  It was served on a bed of mangos or peaches - we couldn't figure out which.

We really enjoyed our experience at Kawa. You should definitely check it out sometime...  I think it will be around for a long time.

I love noodles so ramen is surely one of my favorites but this place was not a favorite. I ordered the Shio ramen and my friend ordered the Miso ramen, in both our opinions, they were both quite salty. It's flavorful don't get me wrong, but it was a tad too salty that made us extremely thirsty. I have  to mention what was being shown on the tv screens, it was animals that were wounded and it was pretty gross because that is not something I want to be watching while I'm eating. The workers there came out from the kitchen and was literally shouting across the room to one another, the atmosphere here was horrible. I don't think I will be returning here but it was nice to try.

*Please note that this review is for Ace Hotel Rooftop bar, "Alto". 

After Wednesday at the Square, my friends and I followed the crowd to the Ace Hotel rooftop bar for the "official after party". We were greeted at the lobby, and treated as guests of the hotel even though we were just there for the bar. We were able to go right up to the rooftop. However, there is definitely a capacity limit, because one of our friends was not allowed to take the elevator to the rooftop later on.

On the rooftop, there were lounge chairs, cocktail tables and picnic tables. It was nice and casual and the views were beautiful. In fact, the view was so beautiful that our friend tried to take a picture and dropped his phone over the ledge. It didn't fall 9 stories to the sidewalk below, but got caught in a small crevice between the building and the plant boxes. He was immediately brought to the head of facilities at the hotel who promised to do whatever he could to get the phone the next day. It was comforting that the staff knew right away who to call and even more comforting that the guy needed was available for even the slightest of emergencies. I wonder if he could have helped the guy who dunking his iPhone in and out of the pool and wondering why it wasn't turning on...I digress...

The bar area was crowded and it took a little time to get a drink, but the drinks were well made. The drinkware was aluminum and plastic, no glass in the pool area so you can walk around barefoot and carefree. The waitresses were on top of their game collecting the guests' trash and empty cups, keeping the place clean. The pool was beautiful, and is handicap accessible. 

All in all, I enjoyed myself and would love to come back on a beautiful day or evening to unwind! Maybe I'll check out the lobby bar/restaurant, or even have a Staycation and book a room!

Another wonderful lunch at A Matter of Taste.  The special sandwich of the day was Buffalo chicken.. it was almost as if I was MEANT to eat at A Matter of Taste, because I LOVE buffalo chicken!!  Oh, and while we're at it, I also love A Matter of Taste...

In addition to the half sandwich, I had the Eclectic Salad.  The mesculun greens were so fresh, the dressing was wonderfully light and sweet, and the salad had strawberries, pecans and bleu cheese throughout.  It was a wonderful bleu cheese, too - not so stinky it overpowered the salad, and was awesome with the berries and nuts.

A Matter of Taste is a gluten-free kitchen, though they purchase gluten-y breads from outside the kitchen, still maintaining their gluten-free qualification.  Their homemade, gluten-free bread is to die for.  I really need to call in a special order one morning for some loaves so they'll be ready later in the day!

I can't recommend this little place enough.

Cafe Envie is great for coffee in the morning, probably good for lunch, not so great late night. I love morning coffee and some productivity at Cafe Envie when it's not too hot and all the windows are wide open. A weekday is perfect - it draws an interesting local crowd and is just far enough from the tourist center of the Quarter. We went for some food late night once and it was slow and not so tasty. I just love the cafe so much that I'm still giving a high review. A great, easily accessible spot - highly recommend.

I'm not a vegetarian, but I do love eating here!  The prices can be a bit steep for fast casual food, but the flavors make it worth it. The chickn burger is huge and very tasty. My fiancé usually ends up getting this sandwich and I get the Philly steak (clearly a play on a cheesesteak). The food is always hot which makes me happy that it's not sitting under a heat lamp. 

The sides are a bit pricey as the meals don't come with a side, but know that the sides are large proportions. You could make a meal out of a side alone.  Always always always go with the sweet potato fries and sriracha aioli.

Mommy wow. I'm a big kid now... is exactly how I felt coming to the Children's Museum with my little lady! We absolutely love this museum and we have annual passes, so we go about twice a month :) 

We in particularly loved going two days after Thanksgiving for the Jolly days!  We went down the great big snow slide which was a blast for me and my little one! The winter wonderland was so perfect! It really was a wonderful and fit all ages. 

Lastly, our favorite part of the museum is the toddlers playscape. My little one LOVES this exhibit. It's safe and she can run all over the place and be independent. From blocks, to the music room, to the jungle gym, to playing with sand - it's the perfect storm of activity to tire my baby out right in time for nap time. 

The most awesome thing about the playscape space are the nursing mothers rooms with comfy chairs, toys and TVs for mommy to be entertained while feeding!!! So awesome and thoughtful ;)
I love the newer menu here and that it's super vegetarian friendly! The hummus and curry crackers, house salad, tofu and portobello burger are some of my favorites!

I love Sephora and it has absolutely nothing to do with the quality of the products (which is semi-lacking). My love stems from the vast assortment of beauty tools and products and the feeling I get while roaming up and down the store looking at all Sephora has to offer. 

More often than not I leave with a single mascara or a simple new blush brush (at a seriously discounted price - thank you). The products they carry vary in quality and it definitely becomes your job to sort through the waste to find the treasures. All in all, I like that they have their own line of inexpensive products and you can always find a "pick-me-up" when you're feeling a bit blue.

Positively gorgeous and worth a walk-through.

My friends and I hopped over after touring the Grand Ole Opry. We *almost* skipped the Gaylord Opryland due to the parking situation. The only lot we could find was $18, which was ridiculous considering we only wanted to walk around for an hour or so. We ended up parking across the street at Cracker Barrel and walking over. It's not a long haul, but it's not short either. (We might have been better off staying where we'd parked for the Opry, not sure.)

Once we got into the Gaylord Opryland, though, we were SO glad we came. We started in the main lobby with the waterfalls, then went through to the next section with the gazebo and gardens, then continued past the pool to the Delta atrium, with its river, restaurants, and dancing fountain. Each section was absolutely lovely, like a small (climate-controlled) paradise. Between our two cameras, we must have taken a few hundred photos.

After walking around for over an hour, we decided to sit and relax at a bar/cafe in the first section (just off the main lobby). Though we didn't try anything off the menu (because we had reservations at the Bluebird Cafe) it did look very tasty and reasonably priced.

We all agreed we would love to come back someday, possibly to stay in the hotel, possibly just to walk around at night or at the holidays when things were lit up.

We loved the service here. Our waiter was one of the kindest, most attentive servers we had when we visited New Orleans.

However, it didn't cancel out the food.

The historic story of the building that houses Cafe Pontalba (take a History Tour for that story - it's a fun one!) is rich and beautiful, but unfortunately, the food at the Cafe is not.

I had crabcakes that were much more cake and much less crab. They were semi-warm, which is something you never want for seafood, mushy, and just overall kind of boring.

The presentation was sloppy - I've seen better plating at a Waffle House.

My partner had a spicy pasta dish, that was so bland he took about four bites of it and said, "Let's just go somewhere else."

The food really was that bad - we left Pontalba and went elsewhere. We'll not be coming back.

This place is an institution, so we definitely had to visit when we were in St. Louis. We even went there two days in a row. The menu is pretty extensive and you know people love this stuff when there's a line whether you go in the morning or in the evening. I thought we'd be waiting a while because of the crowds, but actually the lines moved fast both times we were there. I got a concrete, which is basically vanilla frozen custard with mixings. It's thick and they turn it upside down before they hand it to you just to show how thick it is. Yay for thick because I don't like my frozen custard runny. If I'm ever in St. Louis again, I'd come back.

What? Huh? Eh? 

As much as I love the Mass Ave location, this spot was a huge turn off.. so loud, so suburban.. I hadn't been to this area in years and it's freaking weird.  I guess if I gave up and split for the 'burbs I'd give it another shot.

What a wonderful escape!

Our trip to Phily was for an unforeseen family emergency, but our stay at this hotel turned out to be a wonderful retreat from the everyday.  The hotel employee's went above & beyond while we were there.  They were stupendous at making us feel at "home", you can tell that they love their jobs & are treated with respect.  We loved the bedding, the decor, the soap, the lobby happy hour, and the hotels' closeness to Philadelphia's landmarks.

We are now, self-avowed Kimpton Hotel devotees!

I stayed in Boise for work for a week and I was very happy to find this place. I live in NYC where the yoga is incredible, however, I love taking yoga elsewhere and this place did not disappoint. Good classes and good instructors. My only beef would be that the noise from the restaurant underneath (which I also ate at and its very delicious) seeps up into the yoga room and can be a little distracting, guess I need to work on my ability to block it all out

While I can't speak to Elm's coffee offerings, I have had their baked goods!

Hands down best muffins & scones in Oliver! They always have delicious & unique flavours and they are made daily! In fact, while writing this, I am scarfing down one of their sour cherry muffins right now (& neglected to take a photo before doing so - I just couldn't wait!). 

Their "earlies" & lunch sandwiches sound super tasty and also have clever names like this week's Kanye Westo Chicken. They announce each day's offering on their twitter feed so you can start dreaming about your lunch before you leave the office to pick it up!

I just love this little cafe and it's location on 117 street just north of Jasper Avenue. Nestled on a mainly residential street, it feels really lovely and local. There is limited seating inside, it is mainly a grab and go place, & I encourage you to check it out!

When Mac Mart was just a food truck, this place was so hyped up. I went to the food truck festival last year and waited in line for probably an hour for this mac and cheese. I think it tasted so good because I had been salivating for it for an hour in line. 

I'll admit that the potato chip panko is unique and the mac and cheese is good, but I really think this place was overhyped. 

My friends and I went to the actual restaurant back in September and we liked it. We loved that they gave us our food in reusable containers and we liked getting to be more creative with how we wanted our mac. However, it was still pretty average, just like my experience at the truck. 

I'm not saying I'll never be back to Mac Mart but I definitely have realized how much this place was talked up! If you go in there expecting to be mind blown, you'll be disappointed.

This BYOB uses mostly organic ingredients plus makes everything in-house. I wanted to try as many dishes as possible so I opted out of the entree and instead ordered several appetizers. For our main dishes we ordered the calamari, saganaki and bureki and the lamb kofta entree. 

The Calamari was served with a side of Armenian tomato dip. It was perfectly cooked and tasted light, crispy and tender.Next up was the Saganaki- a favorite of mine. The pan friend halloumi cheese was served in ouzo and lemon sauce with a delicious caramelized fig and side salad. This was one of the best I've had...including those which were devoured on many restaurants in Athens, Mykonos and Paros.  The Bureki was served next: a fillo pastry parcel stuffed with feta and thyme drizzled with honey served with a side of roasted beats. The presentation was so beautiful with a taste to match. Crispy layers of fillo oozing with feta cheese. The Count found that the honey made it more appropriate for dessert but I loved it, especially the presentation.

The lamb kofta was served next. It was a skewer of ground lamb kofta mixed with apricot and pistachios served with a  side of pomegranate salad, lentils and Greek yogurt. The lamb was excellent filled with magic flavors. But what truly made it special were the side dishes. The pomegranate salad was so original. I've never had pomegranate served as a salad as in Iran it tends to be eaten as a fruit or juiced. The mixture of pomegranate with onions and spices was excellent. Then there was the lentil salad which was again a first for me. I mixed spoonfuls of the kabob, pomegranate and lentil salad together and found the combination to be intoxicating. The quality of the ingredients are present in each spoonful. You can tell that the chef really prides himself on his food. 

For dessert we ordered the pistachio and olive oil cake and warm chocolate mousse. Both desserts were out of this world. I really loved the pistachio cake it was light yet intense in flavors served with a side of pistachio ice cream and cherries.  The Chocolate mousse was baked to perfection oozing with warm gooey chocolate served with a scoop of ice cream. Wow. Is all I can say about this restaurant. I loved the food, the presentation and the friendly chef. Kanella offers rustic home-made dishes with fresh and mostly organic ingredients. I was very impressed and can easily say this was one of the best places I've yet to dine

New owners, so time to update! 

Pizzas aren't as cheap as they used to be, but now they are super delicious, so it's a compromise I'm certainly open to. I just wish the new owners would publish a menu. I'd love to branch out beyond just a large pepperoni pizza, but I really have no clue what to order. 
...That pepperoni pizza is REALLY good, though.

I must confess, I have committed a 
Yelp sin. Please fellow Yelpers, please forgive me. My Tropicool flavors were intensely amazing that I didn't even take a picture of them. Shame on me!

So Tropicool has popsicles, pupsicles, gelato, & coffee. Mocha Coconut, our pup, was slurping on his banana & pumpkin pupsicle. I am blaming him for me not taking pics of my gelato. His cup was even bigger than ours.  

I ordered key lime & coconut. Ny hubby ordered guava passionfruit & strawberry & cheesecake. Talk about heaven. Try as many flavors as you want. They are all good!

Everyone was super friendly and helpful working there. I loved how they were such shiny happy people.

They also have a Tropicool bus at local festivals which is where i first tried them. Locale Market also carries their gelato pops, & Yep, I have had them there too. 

Turn Tropicool, & you will never turn back!

Full disclosure: I've never taken a fitness class of any kind in public much less a spin class. I had the opportunity to take a class as part of a Yelp event. I was glad to learn beforehand that my friends who were first-timers like me were pretty much as terrified (in a good way?) as I was! 

Our instructor Chris was very funny and helpful in letting us know how to get "clipped in" and how the bikes worked. I think next time I'll be raising my handlebars, but it wasn't too much of an issue. (Look at me, talking about "next time". We'll see!) I think the music plays a big part in keeping your energy up, but you definitely have to listen to your body and not be gassed by minute 20. I had to back off a few times and sit down while most were standing, but it's not about how good you look doing this. It's HARD WORK! By the end, I was more in the groove and could withstand the climb to the summit. It really helps to have a stat board, I think. I liked being able to see where I was, and it gave me a little extra motivation about sticking with it. After you're done, you definitely feel like you've accomplished something! 

I was expecting a standalone building, but CycleBar is in the middle of a little strip in front of Meijer. I wish there were more showers (one per private bathroom), but space is limited so they do a great job of maximizing the space. 

CycleBar offers water bottles so you don't have to bring your own, which is a nice touch. If I return, I'll be sure to bring it with me. (Because, come on, you don't need more than one!) I also love the fact that they don't do memberships (nobody likes those contracts) and offer packages of rides (and specials) that you can use when it's convenient for you! I'll be spreading the CycleBar love to all of my friends!

love it.  wish this was in the location that trader joe's is in but still awesome to have it in center city.  i havent tried the hot food or salad bar, but they both seemed popular on a Friday afternoon.  Tons and tons of produce, and the prices aren't bad for the quality you get.  I bought a pound of organic mixed greens for $5.99!  I found everything I needed very easily.  The store is the perfect size to accommodate all your needs but not be an overwhelming mess.  The meat and seafood are great quality and how can you complain when they offer 5 different kinds of salmon priced from $13.99 up (e.g., wild, organic, etc.).  There were a few deals so you can def try to save here and there but not skimp on quality.  I only tried a baguette from the bakery but it was delicious!

I'm usually against Starr restaurants but I heard about the bottomless that Jones offers and figured I'd check it out. 

We came in around noon on a saturday and sat at the bar because who doesn't like getting drunk and chatting with bartenders? If you want a table be prepared to wait. 

I opted out of bottomless because I didn't want to be too intoxicated and went with a Bloody Mary instead. LOVE that you can choose what kind of mix, alcohol, and all the garnishes you want. I basically got everything which was like a second meal. My friends ordered the bottomless bellini which is a great deal. It was ~$25, they actually give you the bottles so you can pour at your own pace. They also have three different flavors of puree so you can make the bellini to your liking. My friends wanted to "get their moneys worth" so they killed 5 bottles. lollll. The bottomless is over at 3pm FYI. 

I ordered the tomato soup and grilled cheese. Both were awesome. The bread of the grilled cheese was amazzeeeee. Service was quick and our bartender was super cool. 

I'd definitely come back for brunch!!

Really love the green chile burger and SUPER happy Blake's came to Tucson.  While I do live on the southeast side, I have no problem driving thirty minutes to get one of their burgers.  The drive through is pretty busy, but they move people through fast.  Welcome to Tucson Blake's!

Love, love, Love Retrospect!!! It's my favorite vintage store in Philadelphia. Stopped in yesterday and purchased the cutest hat! Staff is always friendly. I always leave with a cute outfit. A little disappointed that they raised the prices on their sunglassez. They are now $16 :(

Second time in row I ate here and had horrible service. I hadn't been in over a year and decided to give it another try, thinking improvements may have been made. Lesson learned for me and I don't think I'll be back. I watched my server spend more time talking with other servers than waiting on tables. She also left a tray full of dirty dishes behind my chair blocking the two people on my side of the table from leaving their seats. It was there for my meal and was still there when we left. I ordered my favorite, lasagna, and it was only warm on the outside. It took 15 minutes after our order for breadsticks and salad to come to the table. It's a shame that I feel this way because we really love the food, but that's not enough for me to deal with poor service.

I always enjoy my experience at Livery. They make the best margaritas in Indy!

I recently came to celebrate with a large group and made reservations the night of. They were able to fit me in that night but we ended up waiting about an hour to get seated. It was all worth the wait! They treated our table to two complimentary bottles of champagne and our service was top notch! 

The food was amazing as always. I got the usuals: yuca fries, pork pastor, empanadas (I've tried the cheese, lamb and chicken and love them all)! I also enjoy the churros and livery margarita. The atmosphere and waiter made for a great night with friends and I would definitely recommend anyone to try this place. You won't be disappointed! 

Looking forward to trying more items on their menu!

During ski season, this hotel is the best!  

After a long day of skiing, I usually have no desire to wander too far away from the comfort of my room.  Solution to this??  Stay at the Peppermill, where a variety of foodie options, sweets, and an outdoor pool area and hot tubs stay open all year round!

I loved being able to take the elevator down to the second floor, where the outdoor pool was.  Seriously, hot water with massaging jets coupled with the crisp winter air equals heaven to sore muscles!  After skiing, the outdoor tub is the best spot around to wind down.  

Definitely love coming here!

This restaurant's rating probably suffers a bit more than it should because I was expecting to be wowed and I wasn't. Anyway, the interior is gorgeous, I love the fresh flowers and the walls of pickled vegetables.

The have a fantastic cocktail list, in fact, if i ever come back, it will be to sit at the bar and have a drink, albeit a very expensive one.  My appetizer, pork belly with a shaved vegetable salad, was very good and dressed with an incredible vinaigrette. My BF had something else that I forgot as it wasn't very memorable. As far as entrees, they all sounded fine but nothing really grabbed me. I ordered the pork, which was okay. The only standout was a fried sweet potato patty it was served with. Besides what I thought to be a not very inspired menu, the plate presentation was weak. Everything was the same color. I know that's nitpicky but it's an expensive place and I want the food to look and taste beautiful.

Our desserts (creme bruleee and a chocolate cake) were very rich, too rich for my boyfriend so I was forced to finish them for us.  No espresso, I really hate that at nice restaurants. French press is good but it's not espresso, plus it was so weak I could practically see through it.  I wasn't displeased with our dinner but I would much rather go somewhere else for the amount of money we paid.

Definitely a nice Texas meat place. 

First off, the service here was amazing. Everyone was very friendly, knowledgeable and cheerful. The rolls they bake fresh are very delicious (although I didn't particularly care for the cinnamon flavored butter). They also have roasted peanuts at every table (and also two very large barrel-fulls of the roasted peanuts at the entrance/waiting area). My parents really loved the peanuts and couldn't stop eating them.

The price was really quite reasonable since most of the dishes come with two sides. We ordered a full rack of ribs and side orders of mashed potatoes and steak fries.  The ribs were literally falling-off-the-bone  delicious. The flavor and texture of the meat and BBQ sauce was among the best I've had in a while. The quantity of the mashed potatoes was a bit disappointing since the size was the equivalent of a large spoonful in a small dish. Also, the steak fries were only average, although they were well seasoned. It would have been much better if it little was a little more crispy on the outside. 

We also ordered the grilled salmon with a side of Caesar salad and a sweet potato. The salad was very fresh and well flavored. The croutons were super yummy, although it didn't feel like they gave us enough (either that or they were just that good). The sweet potato was also very well steamed and flavorful. The only complaint is that the salmon smelled... well... fishy (not in a good way). The taste was also a little off... and definitely did not mix well with the ribs. We ended up eating only a few bits of the salmon, and thought we'd let the manager know about the potential problem with the freshness of the fish.

We asked the server if we could speak to the manager (and she immediately went to get him for us). We explained the problem and the manager immediately offered to get us another dish or to take the grilled salmon off our bill. I was very impressed with the professionalism of his manner and actions and would definitely go back (although I would probably still avoid ordering the salmon).

I strongly recommend going to this place for the ribs (and the freshly cut steaks seemed yummy too!).

Can't go wrong with the Queen's Meat Combo.  Every meal I've had here has been quite good, regardless of what I've ordered.  The Yekemem Shai tea is pretty good. The cinnamon, cardamom and cloves used in it aid in digestion, which some folks might benefit from if not used to the spices of the food.

I was very excited when my brother and his family took me here, as I always love to compare Southern California Mexican food, to Arizona, as it's a close competition. This rating leans more to 3.5 than 3, but had to round down because the food was more dissapointing than the absolute, amazing service.

Don't get me wrong... The food isn't bad, and to find a spot that does Menudo on a weekday, almost unheard of, but here El Sur does, with a blanco and a regular version. Where this was dissapointing, was there were was waaaaaaay more hominy (garbanzo beans) than actual tripe. This is sad, because the flavor was good, just an excessive amount of hominy. So if you're ok with that kind of ratio, please try, because MaMa in the back makes it right.

I also got a cabeza quesadilla. The meat was flavored wrll, but a little on the  dry side, which is awkward for such a fatty piece of meat. I did really enjoy it though.

The service was AMAAAAZING though. The waitress and waiter we're heavily attentive. Super nice. It really doesn't get much better than that. 

Maybe it's my comparison to SoCal spots that makes this place 3 stars instead of 4, but unfortunately that's the truth of things, and El Sur was put at that disadvantage.

Would I return? You bet. I want to check out the rest of their Caldos and dinner plates. My brother said the Asada plate was delicious, I may want to try a flauta or something.

Hopefully next time they change my mind, especially with Pozole ONLY on Wednesday!!!

Oh my Joy, the Children's Museum!!!!!!!!!! When was the last time I even went here??? I have no idea ! I've missed every Adult Swim event over the past three years and I don't have children, so I don't come properly equipped to handle loads of kids running, screaming and living their lives as I infiltrate my adult desires to play in a museum created for THEM! So I stay away. 

But thanks to Yelp and Sacred Journeys, I was able to go experience a taste of #TCM! I had a great time and I hope they are planning to do it again, as I will be back.

Sacred Journeys started off with a complimentary drink token, to which I indulged in some red wine. From there, the open bar was $5 for drinks (Im not sure if it was an all inclusive price...they had Sun King beer and wine). There was small table with lightweight snacks for dining, but the food and drinks were not allowed into the exhibit. Pretzels, chips, hummus and pita bread, fried wontons and spinach artichoke dip and some mini pizza bagels lined up the table for guests to cure their stomach rumblings. I admit to over indulging on the pizza bites.

I unfortunately only saw two of the exhibits, which means they either have to do this again OR I will have to go on my own and deal with the big laugh & play time of the children. Seeing two of the exhibits and not even in their full capacity just opened up the Pandora Children's Museum Box that now says I MUST SEE MORE!!!!! 

I visited Sacred Journeys, which is really incredible, interactive exhibit about five different areas of the world that people journey off to in order to celebrate their  religion. The long corridor that leads you into the exhibit has a looped video playing that gives you the synopsis of what you will see. Once you turn the corner, all colors of religion, spirituality and love shining. They even had the throne that the Dali Lama sat on in a glass encasing. Pretty cool ! I didn't see the entire exhibit as I was called away but what I did see, I loved !!! I love that the kids have a space that teaches them ABOUT religion and the differences in people, all while showing some of the most beautiful parts of the world. 

The other exhibit I checked out was the Beijing exhibit which comes complete with a replica airplane that flies you into the Beijing while you feel the vibrations of the chair and see the amazing sights that you would see out your window if you were really flying. Once you get off the plane, an entire world opened up ! There was everything, themed and precise, including a grocery store, a Saigon theater, a house, restaurant and much much more. You are really allowed an authentic experience of life in Beijing if you were to travel there. Me and my group had a ball in this area playing dress up, taking pictures and learning to write calligraphy and say hello in native tongue.

Upon leaving, we were asked to sign up on their email list. The ladies told us there would be more of these events in the future! I can't wait and hope they don't change their mind because what adult would not want to take a break from working and paying bills to go unwind with a glass of wine at the Children's Museum and be a kid all over again....in the midst of other adults !!!!

Love this place! The food here is made so flavorful and quick. My friends and I had several dishes here. I really liked the spicy edamame and the hot wok tiger shrimp. I also liked the dynamite rolls. The customer service was ok, but the food made up for it.

We are slowly but surely eating our way through the HipCity Veg menu and, as meat lovers, have been pleasantly surprised and extremely satisfied.  I'm officially obsessed with the crispy ranch "chick'n" sandwich - I don't know how they do it, but the protein looks, feels and tastes miraculously like chicken!  I have dissected it and all but looked at it under a microscope, and it's a total culinary revelation.  It even reheats well for next day lunch leftovers.  The fajita wrap is super flavorful, and the veggie burger, though not as inexplicably identical to its carnivorous counterpart as the crispy chick'n, is meaty and hearty.  Sweet potato fries are good - pretty standard - but what makes them unique is the dipping sauce, a whipped concoction of savory cilantro goodness.  The only downsides I can see are that they've been sold out of the kale the two times we've tried to order it, and there's no restroom for their dine-in customers.  But all in all, this is not what you think of as typical vegan food - it's substantial.  It's flavorful.  It's total man food (no offense to my male vegan friends).

I had to amend my review previously. Based on what a great experience I had last year, I had to come back to Tampa again this year for the same event. I was excited that I knew exactly which hotel I wanted to stay at. It was very easy to book, which I was surprised about because there are so many people usually here for the festival. It ended up being at maximum capacity when I got here. The hotel itself, is just as lovely as it was before. I think there is always something special about it being brand-new, for the first time which, this experience, of course was not. The check in process was easy. I got there a day before all of the kids so it wasn't crazy. Unfortunately Tampa was experiencing unusually cold weather for this time of year. There was no time to enjoy the pool. I still love the location, I had to work at the convention center and at the Straz Performing Arts Center. It's about smack dab in the middle so that was perfect. Also walking distance to the downtown area, lots of restaurants and such. The food in the bar/restaurant is not good but the service is ok. The breakfast in the morning is a disaster! The lady is so rude & slow. No respect! They never have anything you need & always out of coffee. The service is just not great here. It was dirty & gross. The rooms are nice-again, ask for the Riverwalk view. Expect pizza delivery menus everyday under your door. You can get a $5 Voucher or 250 SPG awards if you opt out of cleaning service. That's new from last year! I definitely took advantage of that. Don't expect anyone down at Valet to be friendly or ask you if you need help with anything either. On my way out I realized the has become a bit ghetto & run down. It's unfortunate because I liked this hotel last year & was going to book Aloft in Manhattan next weekend but went Sheraton instead.

The sun came out, it didn't snow and it was above freezing!  We took off to shop and get air, typically one of us chooses and then the next.  First stop- Harbor Freight for him for the sidewalk sale.  Great for odd tools, work gloves, tarps, all those oddities you can use year round and inexpensive to purchase. They have about every tool a guy could look for.  This has been our "go to" store for the last several years.  The best news is a location is coming to our side of town... And it's on his way home!

Nice atmosphere and the place was hopping at lunch. Parking lot is small, many cars parked on residential side streets (which I'm sure the homeowners 'love').

I've been to the Cantina on 3rd and not been overly impressed with their typical mexican offerings (enchiladas, tacos, burritos, etc.) so tried something more entree oriented - the Shrimp Al Mojo De Ajo (sautéed shrimp in a buttery tasting tomato and garlic sauce) with rice and veg - shrimp was nicely sauteed and tender, veg were nicely prepared - al dente green beans and carrots. Good dish, but nothing I will be dreaming about. Price was $11 which is reasonable for this dish but I find their prices for typical mex fare over priced for mediocre food. One complimentary basket of chips per table and you have to ask for it. Salsa is nothing interesting.

Good service.

The three and a half stars this place has right now is about right. 

I can't say it's a three, because it has some menu items that are tasty and different than other breakfast/brunch restaurants and is not a diner. I also can't say they've sold me on a four, and it's for sure not the "Best Breakfast in Town." 

I'm giving this place a four because the Bloody Mary I had was delicious and my server was extremely friendly and helpful. I also thoroughly enjoyed the toasted mini baguette that came with my corned beef hash in place of the English Muffin. The corned beef hash was decent, but not the best, and while I ordered my eggs over medium because I dislike having any runny white part, one of my eggs was not runny in the yellow part either, which I would have loved to sop up with my yummy baguette. 

This place is BUSY on the weekend. We went pretty late brunch, around 11, and still had to wait around 5-10 minutes to get a decent table. They attempted to sit us at a table awkwardly positioned next to where both servers pass by and the patrons stand to pay. We opted out of that one and waited a little longer for them to clean off a table in the side dinning area. The patio was packed and loud, and about half way through our meal a group of loud college boys were sat near us, which sped us through the second half of our meal.

Oh Momo's where to start....this was my first time here. My siblings many times here. Service was not as great as expected. We saw our server a couple times. Others had brought our food out. I would rate this establishment as a 2.5 if that was an option. 

What we ordered...

Roasted Red Pepper Hummus: absolutely delicious! The best hummus I've had in awhile! The bread was nice and warm. Downfall, they should provide more pita. 

Grilled octopus: first bite was good. Second bite wasn't so sure. Third bite...I just wanted to throw up. I love octopus but and this was something different....perhaps spoiled octopus? The only dish that just sat there because no one could eat it. 

Bacon Phyllo: I love phyllo in general, the people in my party do too! The description is BACON phyllo...and non of us were able to taste the bacon at all!

Lobster Mac n Cheese: we all enjoy this dish! Way super creamy and cheesy with chunks of lobster! Yum! For the dish we expected the noodles to be a little softer for Mac n cheese style. 

Traditional Gyro: this gyro was absolutely delicious! We all enjoyed this very much! A matter of fact it we killed this dish before all other food lol. The meat is very flavorful. And all the veggies and tzatiki were superb! 

Overall, some food was good, some was ehh. What bothered me the most was that there's a trash can right next to the soda machine with ice. The ice was not covered. The trash was next to it. I saw employees throw trash in it and some bounced off into the ice. Yuck! And very unsanitary.

I love this theatre... It's 10 minutes from my house, and we can take the whole family to the movies for less than $15.00. So, it's a bit rundown and it's far from first rate. Truthfully, once the lights are off, and the movie is showing- you'll hardly notice the faded carpet and the falling apart seats. If you're a movie buff, this is a great place to come to get your big screen cravings satisfied for a third of the price of a regular movie theatre. I've never been on Tuesday, but they have all shows for $1.50. Apparently they also now have shows after 9 PM during the week for $1.50. What a deal!!! What are you waiting for?

Mr. B's is an all round really good dining experience.  They quickly found us a table for two.  Although it was in the shipping lanes, Len was our server, and he handled us with warm professionalism.  

For appetizers we had the yummy fried oysters and the rich and wonderful gumbo.  Both were incredible.

I ordered the shrimp and grits and they were better than any I have had in Charleston.  GF had the garlic chicken and found it to be a bit salty (and she loves salt).  That was the only flaw in the evening.

She had Profiteroles And Chocolate Sauce and  whiskey for desert!  Great meal.

My husband and I went here a few weeks ago after having dinner, when I was craving something sweet. I love having dessert after dinner so this was the perfect opportunity. We opted for 3 of the minis since we had just come from dinner. At a dollar a piece they were reasonably priced and the perfect size. We got the coconut, carrot and chocolate cake. Normally I'd be all for the chocolate caramel but it seemed very dry to me. The carrot was my favorite out of the bunch. They have excellent comfy chairs that recline back. It is very relaxing. They also have beer and wine so it's an excellent place to go for a small dessert and drink. Def check it out.

The hubs & I -love- mom & pop diners like this!

I've heard Mark H. and Steve E. mention this place a few times, but we're not on Dale Mabry often. Guavaween night we finally got the opportunity to stop by for a really late dinner.

When we walked in we were greeted by a server who seemed kind of grumpy. She kept looking me over incredulously, no doubt because of my costume (I was fully clothed. I am no harlot!). Even by the end of our meal she didn't know what to make of me, aptly confused by my spot-on manners. I digress.

Pop N Sons has a great variety of affordable meal options on their menu. I settled on the country fried steak dinner and Christoph opted for the meatloaf. 

We were both pleased with the speed in which our food came out. The speed did not sacrifice the quality at all, and in no time flat we were stuffed to the gills. The only part of my meal I would've changed was how peppery the sausage gravy was on my steak. Other than that, everything was up to snuff (including their rich macaroni & cheese). 

The food is comforting here, and so is the atmosphere. This diner is a blast from the past, and even their music adds to the 50's ambiance. My sweetie & I will definitely be making a return appearance!

Definitely come here when you want to try something a little different.  Their donuts are not quite what you would expect out of a donut, but it would be the kind of donut you would want had you known it existed.  There isn't much room to move about and the lines are always out the door. (Although, trust me... the place is small enough that it isn't too hard for them to extend outward).  Personally, I thought all the donuts looked amazing and I really wanted to try all of them.  Good think I came with seven friends and we all got something different to share. 

Flavors I tried (in order of preference): 
1) Mexican Hot Chocolate - Simply amazing, their is a little bit of heat, but it isn't too strong and really elevates the chocolate. A great must!!!
2) Samoa - a little hint of sweetness and a bit of crunch; extremely popular amongst our group
3) Holy Santos - my personal favorite in terms of ambition.  I think the execution could be a little better if it were a little less sweet.  But honestly a donut with jalapenos has already won me over.
4) Huskey Boy - the peanut butter and chocolatey heaven :) (Not my personal fav... but everyone in our group loooved this!!!)
5) Gooey Butter - very creamy and rich.  Great for splitting, but there was no way I would be able to finish the entire thing myself.
6) Blueberry - pretty good, but nothing out of the ordinary.  It's your typical run-of-the-mill blueberry flavored donut
7) Blueberry Cheesecake - interesting take on the blueberry; the cheesecakiness was creamy and smooth. A little heavy for my personal taste, but it was still great!
8) Fat Steve - I probably wouldn't order this again personally. There was nothing really wrong with it. Well prepared, and basically like an eclair or long john. The only issue for me was that it was overly sweet.  (I am biased towards less sweet things personally, so take my opinion with a grain of salt.)

All in all, I loved our stop here and look forward to another one soon.  The staff is super friendly, quick, and helpful. The shop was adorable and so was the neighborhood. Definitely a great trip!

*recently edited, since I was contacted through facebook by the bad waiter I had mentioned by name. I was torn, since the service was so bad. Just be advised, you may get stalked if you mention people by name in reviews. Too bad he didn't put as much effort into his job as tracking me down personally.*

I enjoyed the food well enough; I love all things Latin kitchen, so it's hard to go wrong. Liked the salad I had with fresh hearts of palm; starter guacamole was solid;  main course, beef tamale was also also tasty. Not out of this world, but absolutely solid. The mojito was fresh and refreshing. Dessert with plantains was too complex for my taste--didn't need the flour/sugar crumble topping, but otherwise, would have been my favorite part. 

Ambience: cool.

Service: Completely friggin lackluster. We were thrilled our table became available so much sooner than quoted, but then we sat for a full ten minutes (gauged by our yelp check in time, thank you!) before I went to the host stand to see about getting someone to come over and at least get us some water.

The place was busy, but not that busy. We only saw the guy who was supposed to be our waiter after at least 5 minutes, having gotten psyched out thinking he was coming to greet us, but then turned his back on us to work with the table next to us. 

Most seasoned diners are cool with the waiter just at least ducking in for a second with a "Hey, I'm slammed, but I'll get water over here soon as possible" or something along those lines, but nope, not here.

So, when front of house staff finally alerted a manager to what was going on, she took her time about getting to us and said a quick "I'm sorry" before making excuses about what the waiter had been doing. Didn't need excuses, the apology would have sufficed. Had it been genuine. 

When the waiter finally did personally make it to the table, he was completely vacant/ no personality/ no effort to connect at all--much like the manager. Mind blowing, considering people usually love waiting on my friend and I, since we know what a hard job it is and really try to make them feel special. No chance here, since the waiter was so absent. Literally and figuratively.

My companion and I were both bummed, as we'd been so looking forward to trying this place. I'm in no rush to go back- for food that is ok and service that showed no effort to care that we were there; I am happy to spend money elsewhere. Despite decent food, the place left a bad taste in my mouth.

It's not bad.  Went there three times for this visit.  Too lazy to go any where else.  Too cold out there.  On Wed dinner buffet (1-2 stars), Italian theme.  Too salty!  I would really like someone to go taste their food, everything has to be over 1000 mg of Sodium. I have nothing good to say about anything and that is very sad.  Thursday breakfast was so much better.  More people, in fact, the dining room was bustling with people, families with babies, long lost friends getting together.  I found out later, the locals come here for the special deal!  I think they only pay local rate for the buffet if you present a Reno ID card or something.  The food was fresh.  I loved the pomelo grapefruit and the crispy bacon.  Yes, why go to buffet to eat grapefruit and prunes?  Because they were really GOOD!  If you stay for lunch, the extra bonus is that they have some sort of lamb shank or something lamb.  But by lunch time (11:00 a.m.) we were really too full to stuff anything else in our mouths.  The next day, we tried the breakfast again (remember, too lazy), the grapefruit was changed mid-way!  Darn!  The new batch was SOUR, but very juicy.  I played with it and cut out all the skin.  This breakfast was well worth it, because for some strange reason, they brought out all the "good" desserts.  Coconut creme pie, bran muffins, apple pies from their bakery.  One can only eat so much before one chucks.  Remind myself, "in moderation."  I really enjoyed their breakfast.  The eggs benedict is still salty.  Why does people ruin the food with salt?  The server are always top notch.  They walk about a hundred times to remove plates and refill drinks.  The place is clean.  If you are meat eater, plenty of it. No shrimp around if you are expecting shrimp.  Loved the music playing in the background.

I LOVE this place, especially for their boozy brunch! 

They have bottomless mimosas for $23 (what a steal), with which they provide a selection of fresh pressed juices (mango, orange, peach, pear, etc) so that you can make your own drink at the table.  

The food is good! And they have a wide variety of options such as sandwiches, burgers, omelettes, bagels, cereal.  Food is inexpensive, but was surprised to see a bagel with lox was priced similarly to the other food ($11-$12).  

Great place and will keep coming back.  The service is great and super attentive.  Plus, they don't push you out when you finish your meal and you want to keep drinking the mimosas/bellinis.  

I suggest you make a reservation, or you might be killing time in the Las Vegas Lounge (think dark, old man dive bar) next door until your name is called.

This place is family run, provides great service, is clean, and the price is right! I can't believe it's taken me so long to finally eat here! Best experience at an authentic Latin American restaurant so far in Edmonton!!!

Get the pupusas!!! You can get any mix of pork, bean, and/or cheese. My personal favorites are pork&cheese and pork&cheese&beans but just cheese is a classic. I love that you get a whole jar of the cabbage slaw and a squeeze bottle of the red vinegar sauce. They'd give you more if you want too. I like it with their hot sauce. This hot sauce has some serious heat to it so use it sparingly unless you like the burn! It goes well with the cheese pupusa cuz the dairy offsets the heat. 

I also really like the tamales. The chicken is probably the most popular but there's a corn one that is sweet enough to be a dessert. Worth trying for sure. 

I'm a really big fan of Acajutla. The family that owns and manages the restaurant is friendly, accomodating, and makes authentic Latin cuisine. The service is timely and professional while warm and inviting. Acajutla is my new standard in Edmonton... Long may their reign!

I really don't love love Ruths Chris in general, but this location in particular is a bit of a let down. The service is spotty at best, and though I understand that I am still under 30, that doesn't mean that I'm not willing to pay good money for a delicious meal. It sets me off from the beginning of a meal if servers are not attentive because they think you are young and looking for a bargain. I mean, seriously!

The steaks are usually well cooked here, but they are always too buttery for my taste. I much prefer the char on steaks at Capital Grille (if I'm looking for a chain steak place). The lobster bisque is on the salty side, and the sides are usually drenched in butter or cream as well.

For the price, you can get much better quality elsewhere. Like I said, I'm willing to pay for a great steak, but I want it to be a great steak.

The winning feature of this location is, in fact, the location.

This is the first and only yoga studio I've ever frequented. As an active exerciser with a broken ankle, my doctor told me I was allowed to do Pilates and yoga. So my relationship with Bella Prana began. There are a variety of different styles taught and info is available on their website and on MindBody.com about classes and instructors. I stuck to yoga 101/beginner's yoga, gentle yoga, hatha yoga, Shelley yoga, and stress relief yoga.

Bella Prana is a lovely, clean, calming place. There are lots of class options. I started with the new client special for 1 month unlimited class at $39. I tried as many classes and instructors as I could during that time. The studio has two classrooms. When you walk in, you sign in at the front desk on the class sheet that you are attending and then make your way into the classroom. The person at the front desk is always very helpful if you have questions, it's your first time, etc. They have water available for purchase and a water cooler. There are also two large, clean bathrooms with showers. Each classroom has yoga accessories that you may need during your class including yoga blocks, mats, yoga straps, eye pillows, bolster pillows,  and blankets. Each instructor varies what you may need but you always find out when you walk into class. Every instructor teaches a little differently. I didn't find any that I didn't like. One started getting a little "God-y"  for my taste but that's a personal preference. Carla sings in her classes and its amazing and soothing. Shelley remembers your name if you've been a couple of times and she likes to greet participants with a hug. Everyone who I met has great energy and is soothing, comforting, and relaxing in the best way possible. Nobody forces you into a position. There may be some light touch but it is never to injure. There is an atmosphere of "do what your body allows today" ;  "don't compare yourself to others" both of which I really dig. 

Overall, a great studio. I continued on when my month was over and intend to continue taking classes. I love the way I feel during and after.

To properly write this review, I have to tell a story...

It was a fine Saturday in late July. We had ventured from Derby City (Louisville, if you didn't know), along miles of wretched Interstate 65, to Indy in order to see the Varekai production of Cirque du Soleil. We had already made reservations at another (I won't name names) steak house for 8:15 pm. The show let out at 6, so we had some time to kill...we wandered. We browsed a couple bars, having a drink at one. But, as 7:00 approached, we happened upon a place called "Mo's, A Place For Steaks". I said "hey, I bet they have good martinis. We can stop in and have a couple drinks while we wait for reservation time to roll around".

So, we went it. We were quickly greeted by a friendly hostess who seated us at the bar, where we met one of their excellent bartenders, Keith. I had one of the best Manhattans I've had in a long time, which means a lot coming from a whiskey snob. We chatted with Keith and the other bartender, Bridgette, who was equally amazing and gave us some great ideas for places to check out for fun night life activities. Then, we got some great input on our dining choices from some regulars, which led to a change in plans.

After ordering another drink, I asked the lovely hostess if we might be able to get a table, even without reservations. She checked with the manager, who gladly accommodated us. So, we cancelled our reservations at *anonymous steakhouse*, and took a nice corner table for two near the window.

We met the two marvelous ladies who would be serving us that evening, the lovely Chelsea and Ruby. They were on top of everything from the moment we sat down, to the moment we left.

First, I perused the wine list, stopping almost immediately on the glass of Caymus Cabernet, and was informed of a special 40th anniversary liter bottle they had. Guess which way I went? Nectar of the gods!

So now, it was time to actually consider food, now that the important choice had been made. We started with the Kung Pao Calamari, which was at least twice as good as imagined...a perfect heat level blended with the slightly sweet sauce over perfectly cooked, crispy calamari.

Then...the harder decision came: our entrees. But, we selected the Grilled Breast of Chicken, and the Bone-In Filet.

I don't believe in ordering chicken in any place known as "a place for steaks", but I have to say that it was mighty good. Well seasoned, cooked, accompanied and presented. It was an excellent choice for the bird lovers of the world.

The filet...was PERFECT. Perfectly aged. Perfectly seasoned. Perfectly cooked. I ordered it medium rare and oscar style, and was amazed from the first bit to the last. I was going to lick the plate and chew on the bone, but was told that was not appropriate public behavior, so...

With a steak that good, you probably could care less to hear about my side dish, but you get to anyway. I went with the sauteed spinach, which was super yummy. Perfectly cooked in a balsamic sauce.

Needless to say, I will return here on my next trip up to Indy. Next time, I want to give the scallops a shot, even though it breaks my "only eat steak at a steakhouse" rule.

So...ignore the previous review. If there were kinks before, they certainly have worked them out.

I have a love/hate relationship with this food truck. The hate mostly comes from the empty wallet after a week of Chez Yasmine indulgences. Sure, it's cheaper than any restaurant on campus, but it's also probably the most expensive food truck and relatively not filling.

The love side? The sandwiches are guaranteed to be absolutely delicious. I'm a big fan of the chicken wistar. It comes with chicken, obviously, but also has brie, grilled mushroom, avocado, and most importantly, the classic pesto sauce. The taste is phenomenal, and you leave with a banana and bottled water. 

Service is friendly if you're on the owner's good side. Unfortunately, we've yet to get on first-name basis so I'm one of the un-loved children. Though I leave like an unwanted child, I'm happy and satisfied with the delicious sandwich for lunch.

I have to say the food is a notch above mediocre, but there was absolutely nothing to complain about considering the price and the mission of Cafe Reconcile. 

The restaurant is bright and airy, the servers are very eager to help, the menu is well organized, and the food is quite good. My friends enjoyed their chicken and sausage gumbo, and I loved my fried crawfish and salad. The fried breading wasn't too heavy and was well seasoned. The side of greens and mac and cheese were absolutely delicious. 

My friends and I arrived early for lunch (~11:30) and the restaurant was completely packed when we left at around 1 o'clock. And it was a Monday. I left impressed.

As a former resident of Portland, Oregon, where brunch is taken very seriously, I felt a wave of nostalgia sweep over me during my recent visit to Honey's. It started with the swaying limbo of two dozen people waiting patiently outside the restaurant for their names to be called. We pushed open a screen door and put my name in with the clipboard-wielding, mustachioed host-guy, who looked like he'd spent his entire life in Portland and just moved to Philly this morning.
