chicken: the meat was very tender and juicy, even the white meat... which is a huge plus for me. the breading was crunchy and well fried, HOWEVER, I thought the breading had no seasoning, no flavor to it. I usually love the skin but I opted to peel mine off and just eat the meat. it came with hot sauce and some white sauce. the hot sauce helped add some flavor.. the white sauce did nothing for me, thought it was flavorless and not really sure what it tasted like at all. 

other than the food, the service was good. the ambiance was nice and casual. the space was pretty cool. they had cute, hand-colored pictures of chicken by the bathroom which added a nice personal and laid back touch.

the best part of this meal was probably the fried pickles and the company I was with. and my beer.

**** ANNA****
I have been coming to see Anna for nine months now. She had previously worked at Mia and Max, and is now at Regis, as they combined shops. I found Anna by accident and she is by far the best hairdresser I have ever had. Anna loves to do hair she knows what hairstyles looks best with the shape of your face. She takes her time and perfects her cuts and colors. In the short time that I have been having my hair done by Anna I can now walk in and tell her to do what she thinks would look good on me. She nails it every time. She does partial highlights on my hair and the color looks amazing. I now keep my hair short with a slight stack and I get compliments all the time. Please do yourself a favor and go see ANNA!!!

Wonderful little neighborhood coffee shop.  I have yet to try the food, but I would love to if it worked out.  The coffee / espresso is delicious and not overpriced.  

I do have to recommend the Vanilla Chai though- it's spectacular.  

They have plenty of space inside and out to sit and study or just relax.  I was using LaVa as a study break from my house for a little while and always felt very comfortable.  They have a water cooler which is nice too.  Baristas are very sweet.

A little note that made me like this place even more is that although they have a $10 minimum for payments made by CC- they suggested I get a $10 gift card and use it so I'll have a "free" coffee next time I come in.  I'm not sure why other places with minimums don't suggest this as well!  It worked for me :)

I've been wanting to try this place for quite some time given the stellar yelp reviews. After finally squeaking through the door last night just before 8 pm, I can now say I agree with its good reputation! It is truly a gem in the neighborhood. I love that it is BYOB. At ~6.50 a plate, Sky Cafe boasts street food prices, but the dining area is nicer than I expected given the cheap prices: it's clean, comfortable, and well-decorated. Although my friend had to take my order over the phone at 7:45 as I rushed there before closing, the waiter was patient and excellent at recommending a vegetarian dish I would enjoy. He was very helpful and polite and he never made us feel rushed.

Now, on to the food. Everything was fresh and arrived speedily to the table. My friends both got the Mie Kepiting (homemade egg noodles with crab meat). The noodles were phenomenal; a delightful and unique combination of texture and flavor. The noodles and crab meat are in one bowl, and the broth is served on the side, so you can pour it in to suit your ideal ratio of noodles: broth. I got the Nasi Urap with what were described to me as "stinky beans" (I did not find them very stinky at all, which is a good thing). The beans came in a rich, spicy, coconutty sauce that I absolutely adored. The plate came with a nest of assorted crispy fried vegetables, which complimented the texture of the beans and rice perfectly. I was a little disappointed there were not more vegetarian items on the menu, considering the many vegan options available at other Indonesian restaurants in the area, but apparently they can make several dishes to order, so I would love to come back and try a vegetarian version of the noodles if they have it.

I'm so glad I finally tried this place! I'll be back for sure.

Loved everything abt Brew D Licious! The staff, atmosphere, the coffee, the fact that they do not rush you. We had to ask for the bill and to pay, they didn't just throw the bill at us like most places would. The staff explained the menu and answered questions we had. My holla sugah coffee was freakin awesome. Chocolate and spicy, yum!! My friend and I sat up at the "bar" and had a nice, relaxed time while sipping our coffees. Love that they are dog friendly too. Can't wait to go back!

I've been a fan of Nino's for a very long time. I don't make it there very often since I moved away from p-town.

Story time:
Back in the day when they first opened  ('96-ish) my high school friends and I would go here. Often we didn't have the cash so we'd split plates. Nino (the owner) would see us doing this and would give us extra food because "growing kids have got to eat!".  

During this time my mom had cancer so when she'd actually feel like eating I'd call in a pickup order for her. He'd tell me to stay home and take care of my mom and he'd have his kitchen help run down the street to my house to hand deliver it. "Fresh food help you feel better fast 'eh?"

Several years later when one of the high school gang died suddenly my hubs and I stopped by Nino's after the funeral. After he heard what happened he refused to let us pay for lunch and then poured us two very large glasses of red wine. 
"Some times wine and a full stomach makes bad things a bit easier" 
Yes Nino, yes it does.
 
I love Nino... he's a character and a very very nice guy.

The restaurant used to be a toddle house when I moved to the 'hood. Nino redid it into a cafeteria style Italian restaurant. It's smallish with 4 or 5 tables on the inside and 4 tables on the outside. Daily he picks 2-3 dishes and makes them from scratch. Everything is very very fresh.  Watching him make the bread and dough is pretty awesome.

Of the cafeteria style dishes I love  the lasagna and the veal parmesan. 
As for the other stuff they have..OMG the philly cheese steak. It's probably not a real proper philly cheese steak since we're not in philly but so so tasty. Nino makes it fresh on the grill and pairs it with bread he bakes.
The pizza! Nino's pizza will ruin you for all other pizza. He makes his own dough and sauce. I've watched my hubs put away a whole  pizza all by himself and they are NOT small just very very good.  Nino actually knows the difference between stromboli and a calzone. Dat stromboli yo.

Extra parking on the side and rear. Does not take cards.

Mommy notes: Nino loves talking to kids. Always gives plenty of napkins. Small inside so leave the stroller in the car. Bring cash. Clean bathrooms.

Tipling place popped my old fashioned cherry. 

Came here with a bunch of friends last weekend and had a blast over "interesting " conversations and the heavy duty cocktails that flowed around us. I stopped in here before around HH time and it gets pretty crowded but we were lucky enough to score seating for 10 with no problem.
My first cocktail was the Vesper - if you are a 60 year old aka a person who loves Gin order this drink. Its vodka , gin and a twist served up. Its  very much like me potent and classy all at the same time.
I switched gears to the brown stuff on the recommendation of my boys. "Stop being such a girl"  and MTFU they yelled ... as i sipped that old fashioned i fell in love.
I think i found my new drink destination and ill be switching gears to the brown stuff more often.

Went there on a whim on a Tuesday night  and it was better than i could have hoped.  We opted for ordering 3 appetizers (like tappas) and sharing a dessert and it was more than enough for two healthy eaters.  They bring our FRESH WARM sourdough and tahini to start and it was magical.  We ordered the humus with mushrooms, the flat bread and the lamb sausages wrapped in phyllo - all were fresh, healthy portions and amazingly flavorful.  The flat bread had the perfect comb of flavors with sweet, bitter, salty and creamy.  The humus was creamy and smooth with huge chunks of warm mushrooms and pine nuts in the center - we may have almost licked the plate clean.  And he just loved the lamb sausage with the buttery, flaky phyllo dough encasing it.  But my favorite was the dessert - a gluten free orange pistachio cake served warm with cardamom ice cream.  Divine. 

The place doesn't look particularly upscale with a cute diner feel, but the food is wonderful. Service was amazing; i'm past 8 mo pregnant and one of the waitstaff came by to offer me pillow for my back - so sweet!  

We will def be back!

I have driven down Campbell Rd for years and didn't bat an eye at this joint. After anguishing over the lack of available ramen (I KNOW they aren't the same, cool your jets) joints on a Monday night due to business hours, I thought I'd give this place a try after perusing YELP. 
What. a. surprise. 
This place is a gem hiding behind a corny name. I notably know very little about Chinese food and was settled on the Kung Fu Beef Noodle dish as recommended by fellow reviewers. The establishment emphasized well-earned pride in their home-made noodles and complemented it nicely with a spicy soup base full of beef slices and vegetables. I loved it. Although a bit intimidated by the modest price, I should note that my serving was enough for dinner and leftovers.  I was absolutely delighted with this choice and am interested in trying some of their other options. Great place and worth many visits. Staff was pleasant and were delightful hosts despite my request for takeout.

Overall, the food was tasty but way too spicy at times. As a baseline, I'm generally pretty wussy when it comes to spiciness. However, it was especially bad when the waitress said our pico de gallo was mild, only to discover it to be mouth searing, eye watering, cough inducing, cry for your mother hot! The waitress said nonchalantly mentioned that a serrano pepper may have gotten into it. To the naked eye, there were no visible signs of peppers in the dish. It would be helpful if the menu included some sort of rating scale regarding the hot/spiciness levels of the dishes. Not everyone has such a high tolerance for spiciness and I am definitely one of those people!

The tamales appetizer was tasty. There were two fairly small tamales for $16. This dish was spicy as well but not as much as the pico de gallo. I was able to tolerate the level of heat in this one. The taste was reminiscent of the homemade tamales that my friend's mother makes.

I also enjoyed the quarter rotisserie chicken served with potatoes and sauce. As well as the quarter pork dish and potatoes. My boyfriend and I shared the meals and still had some leftover for takeout. Both of these meals were about $18 each. They were also served with tortillas and some salsa. 

Churros for dessert served with dulce de leche sauce was also very tasty. The churros were hot and crispy. They weren't coated in as much sugar as you would find in the amusement park versions of this dessert. I did however fantasized that the churros would've been perfect with plain vanilla ice cream.

I'd recommend this place to friends and family, especially those who love spicy foods. I definitely caution those with low tolerance for heat, this food can definitely be hot!

Hmm. I've been on a quest to find a good Italian restaurant. I have yet to do so. Caruso's is however a step in the right direction. Caruso's is not a fancy Italian joint, which is a good thing. I find all fancy Italian restaurants to be duplicates of each other. Caruso's is best described as a superior flavored Buca Di Beppo or C&O.  Sad thing is I only went there on my last night in Tucson after 4 years. I'd love to go back, its got fantastic outside seating. Especially on those fantastic Tucson nights. I can't quite recall what I ordered, but I remember enjoying the bread, the side sausages(a lot!), and the prices!

Food was delish. 

Stopped before a concert at The Ritz, it is just a block away and the perfect stop for reasonably priced fresh, healthy-ish meal before you wreck your liver.

BFF had the Bird and Pig, she loved it.  I had the Blackstar Bean Burger.  It was spicy which in my opinion was perfect.

The drinks are pricy, but well crafted.

Our service was meh.  A little slow, but we received the correct order and were informed of specials and what they were out of before we decided.

I will totally be back next time I am in town.

A very nice hotel with lovely views of the city. 

I had a nice mini stay-cation with the beau as we were at the hotel for a gala that was conveniently located on the 2nd floor of the hotel.  As we arrived, we were directed to the valet by the workers outside. Got my ticket and headed inside to check in. I'm assuming since the line was getting long, they add an extra person to guide you to the next available customer service agent. That was a nice touch. Everyone was extremely pleasant and alert. This was actually my first time in this area of the JW and it was beautiful. Our room was on the 8th floor and after spending 2 minutes how to figure out the room card and elevator we were on our way. I did find it a little frustrating having to get on one elevator to get to my room and then getting back on said elevator to the 1st or 2nd floor to hop on another set of elevators to get to the higher rooms above 22. The rooms were clean and very comfortable though and the ballroom where the gala was held was very spacious and didn't seem to feel closed in. There were over 600 people in attendance and the night went off without any problems. I also like that the hotel is connected by walkway to a parking garage as well as the adjoining hotels; makes it very easy to not worry about the elements during the colder months.
 
I will be sure to stay here again for next year's gala.

Was in town for work and while I typically stay at the Hilton Penn's Landing (Diamond Member), I had a free night at a Kimpton property that I was going to lose soon and decided to take advantage of it in the City of Brotherly Love.  I also took note that it was relatively close to my favorite pub in the city, Khyber Pass.  This location is in a cool historic part of town, excellent lobby and typical Kimpton feel/ambiance.  I did venture up to check out their rooftop bar but was beat so didn't stay for a drink.  Seems like a cool spot but without really any great views of the city.  Only issue I had was with valet taking longer than expected the next day while heading back to the airport.  I did like the texting service but 15 min turned into about 25 min and at the time I was leaving they really didn't seem that busy.  I believe it's $50 to park overnight as well which is a bit more than some other big cities I stay in such as LA and Seattle.  I didn't have an opportunity to try out their restaurant on site but I'd definitely consider staying at this property again in the future.

I love this place. They have more beers than you can try in a sitting and while that might be intimidating to some, what it really means is there will always be something you like. They have a great balance of local and national craft beers and plenty of different styles.

I expected to be most impressed with the beer menus, but I was wrong. Their food is excellent high end bar food. Their bottle cap fried pickles are amazing. They have great wings and now they even have cheese curds. 

The burgers are great. There are tons of options for toppings. Some are traditional and some get very creative.

Home Wine Kitchen was a delight on Saturday night with my hubby.  We went and sat at the bar for a little while we were waiting for our table.  When we were seated we sat near the window and enjoyed a glass of wine and beer.  The appetizers we ordered were the scallops, beef ribs and the charcuterie plate.  Wow, the charcuterie plate was amazing... there were three meats and three cheeses, homemade jam and mustard and garlic bread.  It was amazing, wow!  The scallops were also delicious, it was a small plate with 2 scallops but it was very very tasty.  The beef ribs were also amazing, but I am not a huge meat lover... my husband however devoured that plate.

I had the mackerel for my main dish and it was very good, however I thought the appetizers were better then the main meal.  I will be back to try different foods on the menu when they change it up weekly.  Delish meal!

I loved this place!!!! It was a cute/off the beaten track place.  We took the St. Charles street car to Euterpe and walked down to Magazine Street to find this gem of a place.

We wanted to order the special - Caribbean Pineapple french toast - but I think something got lost in translation as we ended up with the Bananas Foster french toast.  Took a couple bites and my palate (expecting pineapple and getting banana) was really confused until I figured out the mistake.  I was okay with this, as these were amazing~!

We also got the Crab omelette and I loved the creaminess of it - avocados and crabmeat sauce on top~ The two dishes put together balanced each other out so well - one being really sweet, the other very savory.

mm mm MMM!! I am still dreaming of the french toast - I must try to emulate it somehow in my own kitchen.

Cupcakes! How do you go wrong!!!!  This is the cutest store front!   
I happen in here infrequently as it's no where near me. However it is worth the drive!
The White Wedding is perfect and give you memories of any wedding you've ever been to where what's important...the cake!    The cake is always moist and cakey and the icing is always sweet!    I love the array of flavors, the cute pink box.  I do find that after a day or so in the pink box, they do dry out rather fast.

I adore this local bookstore. You can run into very interesting reads here and it's always fun to wander around and browse through their selection. 

They even have a kids section with a mini arched entry gate that I think is so cute and fun to go through lol. 

Definitely a place I'd love to come back to and take my visiting friends to

Sooooo good! Pure awesomeness! 

I loved this place.  It was uber packed, and we opted to order our meal to go and avoid the line for the sit down.  Even then, we were lucky enough to miss the rush! Whew. 

The cashier was great and gave us a few recommendations and in the end we went for the 2 rock crabs, a cup of clam chowder, onion rings, and steamed clams.  

Yeah...we had enough food to feed 4 people.  The crabs were cooked fresh to order and they were such a treat.  Everything was super fresh and every bite was like a bit of the ocean.  The steamed clams were amazing! White wine and garlic...so down!  Can't go wrong...ever. 

Only dish we didn't like? The clam chowder. Not a huge fan of SB clam chowder (don't judge me).  It was just too thick...and just kinda rich.  Lacked the brininess that you typically equate with clam chowder.  

Either way, the next time I'm in SB--I will most definitely make a point of stopping by again.

We were absolutely thrilled with our experience with City Barbeque and our coordinator, Megan. From the initial consultation, to our wedding day and everything in between, we were blown away by their service, attention to detail, and food quality. Most importantly, our guests absolutely loved the food we served -we heard again and again how the food at our wedding was the best they ever had. It's fun, unique, and delicious while all maintaining a classic and beautiful presentation. We even ran into a situation where our venue was not accommodating of all our guests needs and Megan and her team stepped in and filled the gaps. Could not recommend this vendor more for your wedding.

I wanted to love this place. The concept is great and admirable. b.good sources all their ingredients within mostly the Tri-State area. They use all natural and healthy ingredients. Even some of the wood trim and bead board in  the restaurant appeared to be reclaimed. I really want this place to succeed.

I had try the burger, and I tried the buffalo -- buffalo sauce, blue cheese, lettuce, tomato. The burger was pretty good but not great. A little dry, a little bland. The whole wheat bun looked really good but was also dry and fell apart really easily. The lettuce and tomato were extremely fresh tasting.

The salads looked really good and next time I'll try that. I had a blueberry/pineapple smoothie. That was a little pricey at $5.29.

The dining room is very nice, extremely clean and simple inside but gets a little smokey from the grill. I understand this is hood problem and will soon be corrected. They have been open less then a week.

I'll be back and give some other menu items a try as I really like the concept. But based on the burger, just 3 stars.

First time at a DENNYS YAAAAAAAS!!! I loved it! The food is delicious, the staff is soooo nice, it feels like talking to your cousins and aunts, they were very warm and because my sister brought baby Jordan ( 1 month old) they change the temperature so the service itself was beyond, the portions are great and also the food, I'm starving just to think of it ahhaa plus if you're having an early flight it's 5m away from airport and there's a hotel next to it :)

As of late, I've been trying to avoid writing reviews on places that I've only been to once but I really just fell in love with Kanella. After a day of training for a new job, my new co-workers and I ventured into the city with a free bottle of wine and free bottle of cider in hopes of finding a nice BYO to imbibe. We were told Kanella could be hit-or-miss, but we decided to give it a try. 

Right off the bat, everything was great. It had just opened so we had no problem getting a table sans-reservation, and the hostess gave us a table that was right by a window, albeit next to the kitchen, that gave us a nice place to people-watch. The decor itself is lovely. The banquets are lined with loose pillows, everything is done in light colors and the big windows really complete the whole comfy, relaxed vibe. Our server (I'm totally blanking on the name) was really nice, funny,  and efficient, despite him coming off as a bit spacey. 

Now, the best part is obviously the food. We shared 4 appetizers and 2 desserts for our meal which definitely left us super full. The dips of the day that we got to try were a garlic-potato, which was pleasantly chunky, a creamy yet somewhat savory lentil spread (my FAVORITE omg), and traditional baba ghanouj. The pita that it was served with was warm and obviously right off the grill. The dolmathes were also great and had an interesting spin in that it was served with raisins, giving it a sweet aspect. I wish it had come with 3 pieces, as opposed to two, but that's just a minor complain. We also had a pastry that had feta cheese and spinach, topped with honey (they even gave that honey thing that is used traditionally...the wooden one? You know? I have no idea what it's called), and it was divine. Our final appetizer was the grilled calamari, which I found delightful for being a bit overdone. Fortunately for us, the chef felt the same way and gave it to us on the house without us even making a comment on it. Finally, the deserts were AWESOME. We got a trio of ice cream which included mint, cardamom, and jasmine. The jasmine wasn't my deal, but the mint was AWESOME. It tasted like actual mint, as opposed to something you would buy out of a carton from Acme. The small pastry tasting I felt was slightly over-priced, but then again they managed to make semolina cake really good so I guess I can't really complain. 

While Kanella isn't the best Greek/Mediterranean food in the city, it's definitely up there. The chef obviously cares about the product that goes out and the staff seems to genuinely enjoy working there. It's great for all occasions, from business lunches to romantic dates. I'll be returning, for sure :]

The atmosphere...I love all the portraits and ghostly feel. Prefixed meal is the best deal and it gives you a great sampling of their food. I had a pork chop that looked like a dinosaur. Delish!
Reservations are recommended, but It's not like there isn't anything to do around there if you stop and put your name in.

We get here, and it's BUSY! Get ready to wait. Based on the reviews, and how busy this place was, I was expecting some good eats. We finally get seated, and the place has a very hipster vibe to it. I ordered the chicken and toast (I guess you can say it's their version of Chicken and waffles), and my girlfriend ordered the Beni, which is a eggs benedict, and instead of Canadian bacon they use pork belly. It took a very, very long time to get our food. The staff acknowledged this by bringing us a pastry, and apologized for the long wait. Which I thought was nice, but then we get our food. The first thing I noticed was the french toast was a bit burnt, and so was the chicken. I take my first bite, and the rosemary, and french toast was a very interesting taste I've never had, and I liked it. However it still had that faint burnt taste, but still very good. The chicken on the other hand, had NO flavor. I ask my girlfriend how her food was, and I see this look of disappointment. She LOVES eggs Benedict, and she flat out said these were the worst she has ever had. I asked her to let me try it, and the hollandaise had absolutely no flavor, the pork belly was eh, but the asparagus was pretty good, though. The waiter (who stated he was one of the managers there) asked how our food was. My girlfriend told them about her food, which she only took about two bites of, let him know about the meal. We weren't expecting anything, However, he comped her order. So, to be honest the three stars are mainly due to the customer service.

I am honestly surprised the star rating for Brio's is not higher.  I have always had a solid meal every time I have eaten here.  First, I love the decor.  It's bright & breezy.  Maybe a little loud, but nothing that would interfere with a conversation.  If you do not want to sit in the dining area, Brio's has a great bar, and their drinks have always been some of my favorites.  I could just drink their sangria's and I would be a happy camper.  You can get a full meal sitting at the bar, and they always have a game on the tv.  We went this afternoon (Saturday) and while it was busy, we got a table right away for 4 people without a reservation.  Not sure if I would try to do this during a weekend during dinnertime, as it is a pretty popular place. 
I love their flatbreads, but today we got the tomato & mozzarella caprese appetizer and the calamari.  Warning: the calamari has either peperoncini and jalapeños deep fried and mixed in with the dish.  One of my dining partners found this out the hard way.  The caprese was beautifully presented and fresh.  My favorite go-to dishes are the steak salad or the grilled salmon fresca, which has a great mix of sweet potato, asparagus, and spinach.  Both are large servings, so you get to take some home, which is a win.  The one thing I am going to ding them on is their to go containers.  I don't know if they switched companies or what, but the last 3 times I have gone there, the to go containers will NOT stay closed.  Something has always leaked or spilled on the way home.  Ask them to tape the box!  My companion got the ham & biscuit benedict.  The brunch potatoes on the side were huge, but tasty.

This must be the best Dairy Queen in the city. 
I love going here because it is always decorated in fun, seasonal things and the staff are friendly & considerate. It doesn't matter where we are in the city, if we have a hankering for ice cream, it's this location that we come to.

I needed a birthday cake for a coworker, so I called to place an order this morning. The gentleman that answered was pleasant, but wasn't able to take my order by phone, I didn't give them enough time. He told me they had lots of items in the display that were the size I was looking for, and they'd be pleased to write a message on it quickly when I came it.

There was a cake in the display that matched my needs, so May (looks like she's a manager) quickly took it into the back and wrote my birthday greeting. I was so surprised at how fast she did it, and it looked great! She was also very pleasant and seemed genuinely happy to help, but they all are at this location.

On top of that, when she gave me the recipt, she also gave me a coupon for a Buy One, Get One Free coupon that's good on a burger, Blizzard or Royal Treat.

Delicious! This is my 2nd visit, I'm sure I'll be back for more.  I found myself craving the cilantro rice.  This rotisserie style restaurant doesn't overwhelm you with too many menu choices, they do chicken and they do it well.  My first visit I had the chicken sandwich and I will say it was a little more dry than the white meat chicken breast and wing I tried today.  It was so juicy and flavorful.  I was offered a "yellow" sauce which was nice and garlicky, a nice addition to the chicken as well as rice.  I asked for a "green" sauce as well just for comparison.  The green is considered their spicy sauce.  I love spicy but I think the yellow was my fave.  Prices are a little steep but worth it for quality food.

Precinct Pizza has just become my new #1 spot in Tampa for NY style Pizza!

As a former NYCer i was real excited to take a visit here due to the NYC theme of the restaurant. As soon as you step inside i immediately had flash backs of the city as I felt like i was transported back to NYC. With familiar NY subway signs & NY sports pictures plastered all over the wall i felt at home. The walls were also covered with badges from various NYPD, FDNY & EMT departments from back home which added a cool touch to the restaurant. You could really tell that the owners put alot of time into this restaurant as there's just so much memorabilia to glance at! 

As for the pizza, I could tell the quality of the ingredients they used was fresh. when i took a bite of my slice, the mozzarella stuck to the crust causing the strands to slowly pull away and just proves the quality of their cheese. I always order my pizza extra crispy and as some places may tend to over cook my order, Precinct cooked mines to perfection! A slice was $2.65 which is not bad considering i was used to paying $2.75 for a slice back home. 

... but what really blew me away was their garlic knots. MY god these might have been the BEST GARLIC KNOTS i have ever had in my life ... maybe even better than the ones i have had in a NYC pizzeria! Each knot was HUGE & had a little burn to it which gave each piece an excellent crisp. We ordered 4 and they covered the whole basket it was served in. Not too obnoxious with being overly garlicy, it was a nice combination and went well with the marinara sauce they served it with. this should be a MUST with every order.

and the canolis ... leave the gun take the cannoli (sorry couldn't resist!)  ... I haven't had a good one since walking the streets in little italy. this one was freaking amazing. Loved the chocolate chips it was served with! A great way to cap the meal!

i also loved that each dish on their menu was named after different parts of NYC adding to the nostalgia of the restaurant. 

Its honestly been a VERY long time since ive been SO satisfied by a meal. Thank you Precinct Pizza, I will def be coming back for seconds!

The simply-named Tavern offers up some mighty simple comfort food pleasures (White Trash hash, anyone?) and elevated junk food game bites. 

That said, I'm not sure this is quite the weekend brunch place for me, due to the TVs providing all of the background noise. I'm not a fan of big TVs blaring games -- to me, this is the worst kind of ambiance. BUT... for those of you seeking a place to watch local sports and cheer on with a crowd, Tavern is the spot for you, especially if your tastes are a bit more high brow than your typical nachos. I mean, they have nachos, but Tavern's come with pistachio and goat cheese. Nice! 

I'd easily return on a non game day (or even to sit on the shaded side patio) for more of that White Trash Hash. Think tater tot casserole. I mean, really. Goodbye hangover. The egg white omelet I had was kinda blah, as the tomatoes made it seem extra watery.The "Wicked" Bloody Mary was hardly wicked, more like gentle, despite the vodka being infused with pickled things that you'd hope for on your glass. They don't automatically garnish the way you'd think. Or at least the way a New Orleanian would think. I mean... just a lime? Nu uh. Our very lovely server came out with some olives for us, which was nice. But a Bloody without beaucoup d' garnish is a naked Mary, indeed.

Extra props for three bottles of hot sauces on the table, marked X, XX and XXX. Go for the orangey habanero, as it's the tastiest of the bunch (it might be the XX). Don't be fooled by the warnings. They are there for the bland American palate.

What an absolutely lovely place. I love Christmas/holiday decor and I adore it, even more, when it aligns with the glittery, white, charming wintery-swan-snow style. Immediately, when you walk in, you sense the amount of heart, love, and attention to detail in this stunning spot. As you enter, the bakery cases are open and filled with enticing treats that are beyond beautiful, and the decor gives you a pleasant visual overload.

Cake Bake Shop has a smaller but charming lunch menu filled with quiches and French-inspired fare. I had the chicken salad croissant, which actually had glitter on it! Now, the concept of eating glitter doesn't always appeal to me, but I swear you can't even taste it. Its so out there, but coupled with the ambiance of the business, it works. You also must try one of their sparkling cocktails - mine was too beauteous to even drink and had a floating edible hibiscus!

During lunch, I was operating in a tighter time crunch to catch a flight. I really appreciated that the team was speedy with my entree and cut my piece of cake early! The French silk pie was so delicious I could cry and served beautifully. Whether you live in Indianapolis or are just visiting, you must make a visit here. Its so easy to see why its adored by locals, guests and celebrities alike.

i came here several weeks to try on wedding dresses with several friends and my mom.  I made an appointment and showed up on time.  I was told to pick our three dresses first, and she would bring them back to me, and then bring three more additionally.  When I walked in, I immediately saw a dress I loved.  The lady had me try on several dresses that were not the ones I picked out, and in the second round, I got to try on the one I had my eye on.  I guess it was okay that she had me try on styles very different than I picked, because when I finally tried on the one i liked, I knew it was the one.  I told her I would try a few more. She brought me several dresses that were significantly more expensive than the ones I picked within my budget " I mentioned wanting to try that one dress on a second time and she told me my appointment time was almost over and recommended coming back again.  My mom was adamant I try it on again and told the girl to bring that dress back.  I tried it on again and said "yes to the dress."  I ended up buying the belt one of my friends picked to go with the dress.  The girl did not even tell me the dress was on sale, only o find out at the register it was several hundred dollars cheaper(hollar!). Overall,  I had a good experience and my dress was ready to be picked up within a week!

What a lovely vintage shop. I've been to lots of vintage stores, and this place was great for several reasons:

1) They have well-organized sections according to decade, and they had some really beautiful pieces going all the way back to the 1920s.

2) The place was obviously clean and well-kept with none of that musty smell you sometimes get with a collection of vintage clothes in a confined space. The clothes were in great condition and well-preserved. 

3) The service (one nice girl at the counter) was helpful but not over-bearing and explained their rental section and terms very nicely.

4) They do rentals and clothes for purchase, and the prices for both were very reasonable. Example: One 1960s shift I had my eye on was in perfect condition for $39, and they had a selection of original and truly beautiful beaded 1920s flapper dresses for rent for around $75 per weekend.

This is not the kind of used clothing store that simply slaps the name "vintage" on their window, so if you're looking for TRUE vintage or costume rentals they would definitely fit the bill.

Maybe we got lucky with the server, but the litany of complaints about the service didn't reflect a recent Friday night experience. 

Endless chips and salsa, plus side o' guacamole, came out fast and were joined by a couple of fine craft brews (small but good selection). The guac, pico de gallo and salsa verde were all good, and they rub a bit of spice on the chips for extra kick, which was a nice touch. Is there a better app for $4 within a 3-mile radius? Probably not, but you tell me.

As others have noted, the burritos aren't what many of us are used to. This isn't a Mission-style torpedo weighing in at 5 pounds, exploding out of the foil with a delectable mess of beans, rice, guac, sour cream plus the meat of your choice. No, it's not that at all. But that's okay. I didn't have any trouble embracing, then devouring, the two svelte carnitas-filled and un-grilled tortillas. I dressed 'em up in the guac and salsa and had no complaints. And I didn't even miss the overstuffed feeling that comes as the secret side with burritos gordos. 

My vegan buddy had the veggie wings that everyone raves about, and the BBQ seitan. I tried them both, and liked them, but taking my advice on vegetarian/vegan food is really a waste of all of our time, Mr. Spicoli. So take it from Vegan Mike: he loves them.  

Excellent service throughout: attentive but not rushed. I don't know how some people got duped or upsold on the $5 rice and beans side. I know these are usually in the burrito, but the menu lists them separately with the price and indicates that they aren't ingredients in the burrito, so it was clear to me. Ambiance was nice and vibrant, and even though the place was busy, we got a booth right away. 

I'm trying to think of cons, but there really weren't any, so I'll be visiting again. And I'm looking at you, tequila selection.

Very neat theme bar and grill. The food is very tasty. Enjoyed lunch here and the service was very good. Gotta love how well the place is decorated. Not far from our house so we will likely be returning soon.

I didn't hate this place, but I guess I thought I'd be more impressed than I was. I stayed here for 2 nights for work last week, and my room was actually on the "resort side" of the complex instead of at the main building. 

The main building is a traditional business hotel. The "resort side" is a bunch of little "casitas" which are essentially individual, ground-level rooms with little patios. If I'd been here on vacation, I think I'd have been a little disappointed with thinking I was getting resort-quality accommodations, only to find the biggest difference was just being a bit more off the beaten path. There were no special amenities--not even a mini bar--and the most annoying thing for me was that the gym and the only restaurant open for breakfast were in the main building, and I had to trek over early in the morning before meetings. 

On the up side, there is a nice little pool on this side that sits right next to the lovely blue waters of Tampa Bay. There is a small sandy area with cornhole, ping pong, and hammocks. I didn't have time to lay by the pool, but there did appear to be food and drink service. The food in the main restaurant that I had for breakfast was decent and overpriced, which is exactly what I'd expect at this kind of hotel. 

Biggest WTF: no wifi in the lobby. Simply bizarre at a business class hotel.

I don't typically consider myself a fan of restaurants that serve American food but this place impressed me. I had gone a few times for their hot cider with a vanilla liqueur (holy hell, amazing!) but never had the food. A couple of months ago, we went for dinner and used a BOGO coupon with the Entertainment book. I had the risotto ($9) that had squash, pecorino and speck. So freaking good. My husband really loved his food, too. The staff was attentive and we really enjoyed our meal. With American style food, I often have a hard time finding something I like. But their menu was full of dishes that I wanted to order all at the same time!

A nice little ice cream/dessert shop next to Cocco's Pizza. There's a fair selection of homemade gelato and it's OK, but honestly you can find much better downtown. They have a wide variety of other desserts as well, including ice cream, cakes, cookies, etc. Oh, and coffee! Who doesn't love coffee with dessert? 
The decor is cute with ice cream parlour wire-back chairs, tables and a comfy couch to cuddle up on while you eat your sweet treat.
It's nice to have a convenient place to satisfy your sweet tooth instead of just grabbing a pint of ice cream at Wawa.

There was nothing wrong with the Renaissance. The location was good and the bed was comfortable. 

I have a few issues which would preclude me from going back. One is the lack of true room service. I have this thing about getting a fresh pot of coffee with a mug. I love having coffee in a robe (no robe in the room, by the way). I called down and they said there were no pots, just a cup, and that it would be eight dollars total. She recommended I come down to pick it up. So SOL there. 

I then noticed that there was a weird noise. It was white noise like an air conditioner but it was not constant. It would start at one decibel and then get louder and louder. It was as if the main air conditioning unit was right over me. I called down to ask if every room was like this. She hadn't heard of it and said she would send an engineer up. In the least,  she could move my room. That didn't happen. I had to sleep with my ear buds in with a white noise app. That's how disturbing it was to me. 

And lastly, I got a message from housekeeping. I had left my do not disturb sign when I went out and they said they would not clean the room in the late afternoon. So the next day I made sure to shut off the do not disturb sign. I was gone for over four hours (10 am to about 230). I came back and the room was not cleaned. So I give up. 

I asked for a late checkout. They said noon so I took it.  Housekeeping was knocking at eleven. 

It's the little things. I'll stay at the JW. I know what I'm getting there.

Might have secured the new top spot on my list of excellent places to write.  I love the eclectic industrial decor and mix of chairs and tables.  The 'it's fall somewhere' latte has been a delicious go-to.  The employees that I have worked with have been incredibly friendly and accommodating, and I'll dare to say that their crafted bevvies are a touch less expensive than other coffee houses in the area.  It's SO close to wear I work, also, so it makes it very, very convenient.  Parking is a bit of a bummer, though, (the lot is rumored to tow after a half hour!), so try to snag a spot on the street.

Burrito snob here. In my burrito hierarchy, Chile Burrito ranks somewhere above average but not at the top. 

I like the burritos here. As much as I love tortillas, lately I have taken to cutting them out and opting for burrito bowls to save a few calories. While some places fall short in their burrito bowl offerings, Chile burrito still manages to put together quite a nice meal sans tortillas. Having said that, I've had several of the burritos longside tortillas and these were good.

What I really like about Chile Burrito is that after you have constructed your hodgepodge of ingredients, they put the burrito on the grill for a final warm up before serving. I've yet to experience this anywhere else and it makes for a nice touch. 

Something to note, the salsa here is pure fail. While they do have a pineapple salsa like baja burrito, it is a piss poor imitation. As for the other salsas, in general, they pale in comparison to other salsa's I have experienced. All in all, you don't really come her for the chips and salsa, you come for a cheap tex mex burrito which is slightly better than average.

Wow! What a find!

Easy to miss, this restaurant is a hidden gem. Definitely pricey, but Wildflower Grill delivers some amazing food. Everything from the baked brioche to start the meal, to the Peppercorn Herb-Crusted Bison Tenderloin served with a chanterelle, fig & smoked cheddar bread pudding was amazing! I figured bread pudding should be a desert but this was an excellent addition to the main course. So tasty!

I loved Wildflower. Not cheap, but definitely treat yourself!

Very good burgers and a nice vibe. Also they have almost a whole PAGE of bourbon. I love bourbon. I do think it is kind of spendy for what you get but I did like it and I would return the next time I am in town!

Average deli place.  I would bump it to 3.5 stars, but not quite four.  It's in a good location off Clayton.  Inside the restaurant is modern, with clean lines.  The menu has a good selection at reasonable prices.  Our food was just average.  I got the 6 North Turkey club, no mustard.  Ended up without mayo too.  The avocado on it is in slices, not spreader evenly, so that was a tad odd.  I think it would have been really good had the avocado and mayo (if it was on my sandwich) was mixed together and then spread on with maybe a dash of salt and garlic.  It was average, but def missing something.  My husband had The Italian.  He didn't like it at all.  Probably should be on an Italian sub and toasted, maybe?  The chips were good-we both had the Parmesan garlic.  We love that we see more places carrying the brands that aren't mainstream.  Doritos can be found anywhere, RyeStreet brand can't.  The fountain soda drink area was a tad messy as well.  We ended up eating outside on the patio, which is basically a sidewalk looking at the parking lot, but we still appreciated it since it wasn't busy with traffic.  We may go back another time to try it again, but try something different.

I like checking out the art exhibits here. The guild is in a beautiful old building with a choke-full of character. It does not have the most visually-stimulating layout for presentation of artworks but there are two floors of rooms that can hold quite a few paintings/photographs. Just the reflection of a setting sun on the wooden floor as it shines through the lovely french doors on the first floor can be considered art enough in my opinion. Best part of visiting the guild? You can take a walk around the Oak Knoll Park, where you are surrounded by lush greeneries (in the summer) despite being so close to busy roads.

One of my favorite restaurants ! Can't believe I didn't write this review sooner. Great drink selection too! I love the calamari, salads & the bread. Oh goodness the bread like where have they been all my life ...haha. This is a must try. 

I definitely recommend the pizza ; it's brick oven style & it's delicious

St. Louis is always little slow on food trends, but I was super excited to hear poke was finally starting to arrive!

This place has been on my radar even before it opened, thank you social media. My spouse and I checked out PokeDoke for dinner one night. Parking was pretty difficult to find, but it's to be expected as this restaurant is located in CWE.

I was having trouble figuring out which of the three sizes to choose. Small, regular, or large. I decided to go with the small which came with two scoops of protein. I had two scoops of the salmon with a base of white rice. I went with the medium poke sauce, but I think I'm going to go with the spicy next time. Toppings: mango, seaweed salad, masago, green onion, friend onion, and wasabi, all topped with a drizzle of wasabi mayo.

I'm not sure I can say it's the best poke I've ever had in my life, but it sure was tasty. The salmon was pretty good, I liked the poke sauce that was used. The toppings went really well with the meat and the rice. I really just see poke as a deconstructed sushi roll, which I already love. I was really surprised as to how full I was at the end of the meal. Though I chose the smallest size, I was pretty stuffed. If I had chosen the regular size, I would've been very uncomfortable.

I thought prices were fair. A small bowl is $10, while a sushi burrito from Blk Mkt Eats was $9 or $10. Not a big difference.

I used to love coming to Penang and had not visit Philly in a long time. It was nice to see that Penang was still operating. We had a quick lunch there it was quiet in the restaurant we took a table right by the kitchen, it was interesting to see that the entire kitchen was operated by non-Asians. They were hard at work grilling satays and making rotis. The chicken satays and shrimp noodle soups were good it hit the spot.

First of all, it's called Club 21, not "Twenty One Club", and it's been a Mexican food restaurant in Tucson since I was a kid.  It's been over 20 years since I was last here. It used to be the best place in town to get great Mexican food, at least as far as I can remember through the thick gauze of childhood memories. I remember big, red-leather booths (still there but not used), a dimly-lit, yet cheerful & bustling dining room, ordering kiddy drinks from the barman, a friendly staff, and of course delicious Mexican food, especially the carne seca.  Nobody made a carne seca chimichanga like Club 21.

On a recent mini-family reunion this was my dad's choice for our first night out.  All I can say is the place has fallen on hard times. Granted, it was a few days after Christmas, but the place was dead. The interior was also looking very rundown, some of the clientele were looking a bit seedy, and the staff were cheerless (apart from our waitress, who attempted small banter).  It's always depressing when you see a once-popular place you love turn into a dive.

And not the "good" kind of dive where the food is still great. The other kind, where the food seems to have suffered too. My carne seca chimichanga was so-so.  Service was also poor. Though the waitress was friendly enough, she flubbed a couple of orders, failed to refill waters, and forgot my second drink order. (At least we weren't charged for it.)

I really wanted to visit Club 21 and find a place that had improved and blossomed over time, but what I found was a place that the Tucson restaurant scene has left for dead by the side of the road.

OK, I love trains, eh?!   And if the US was as civilized as most of Europe where you can take your dog on mass transit, I would rarely, if ever, ride on my car.  And in this equation is 30th Street Station, the transportation showplace of Philly.  It's not Grand Central, but still a magnificent edifice, way friendlier and eons more comfortable than the disgusting, smelly and dirt-ridden ant farm in New York's Penn Station. 

Entering the building is done on three sides, one of them a huge food mall.  The main room of the station is a magnificent neo-classical structure where people come and go without realizing the gem that they have overhead.  There are numerous cubbyholes in the station.  A VIP area on the mezzanine floor with direct access to some of the main platforms.  Office space galore.  A modern tie-in to the New Jersey Transit terminals.  And an overhead walkway to the parking in the ultramodern yet beautiful Cira building.  The old, former underground parking has been taken over by taxis, security and maintenance.

A definitely sumptuous welcome to Philadelphia.

My family and I stopped here recently after a Phillies game for some late night sweets.  

I had been eating fairly healthy all day and didn't want to ruin it with a giant hot fudge sundae so when I saw they had frozen yogurt on the menu, I was pretty stoked!!  I asked what flavors they had and she said "black cherry," well I was sold.  I ordered that and the rest of my family got their sundaes or milkshakes or chocolate cake (which I looked at longingly while I ate my frozen yogurt).  Despite eyeing up their desserts, I was very, very happy with my choice.  It was creamy with a tangy, sweet cherry flavor and big chunks of black cherries throughout.  

Our waitress checked on us once or twice while we ate, but disappeared for a bit when it came time for us to get our check.  We finally paid and left, unsure of how we were going to get to sleep with all the sugar coursing through our systems.  

I'd definitely come here again just for dessert but I'd love to come back and try the food sometime.

Han Dynasty is one of those Philly institutions that's an endless favorite on Zagat Philly lists or "top restaurants in Philadelphia", etc. Before I start, Han Dynasty is surprisingly not that expensive (the 3711 Market location is really nice inside!) and has really great, fast, take-out service. 

A few weeks ago, I got the beef and tripe chili oil dish. I love spicy food, but be warned, this is insanely spicy and cold! Spicy enough to split into three portions to eat when my mouth isn't screaming for mercy. Still, really good! Today, I had the dumplings in chili oil-not as spicy and a really delicious appetizer. 

I just the Dan Dan noodles for take-out though and am not super impressed...I know this is total heresy and I should just stop the review here, but the portion I got was just "meh" on my flavor scale. I've never had Dan Dan noodles before, but Han's seemed kind of like peanut-buttery noodles without any spice.

It's been at least 5 years since I've been to Mazzaro's, but I've been dying to grab some yummy food from here for a while now. The first time we tried to come on the weekend, and decided when we couldn't find parking that it wasn't meant to be. I came early today on a Tuesday, thinking I would beat the lunch rush, but it was still nutty in there! You take a number and wait, order then wait, then once you have your food you have to wait in line to pay out in the courtyard (that's only if you want to eat there). I usually ordered the caprese sandwich in the past, but I saw on Yelp people were raving about the Wasabi tuba. It definitely was good, the wasabi sauce was the perfect amount of spicy, and they give you a really nice amount of sesame tuna for what you pay. My meal and a drink came well under $10. Wish I lived closer or brought a cooler because I would have loved to bring some fresh pastas back home! I'll definitely be back for raviolis :)

I truly love Henry's PFT. I only discovered it about a year ago, and while I've only purchased a couple of little items and here and there, I love seeing all the custom couches, sectionals, and chairs ordered by other customers (they post on their instagram account). I've emailed Henry's a couple times about specific pieces of furniture I am interested in, and they are always very helpful. I haven't ordered anything yet because I haven't figured out my plan yet, but I'm excited for when I do and I know they will be of great assistance!  Some items are pretty expensive, but it's high quality, and you can custom order all the finishing on the furniture, and much of it is made in Canada.
It's a good place to go look for smaller gifts ($50 and under) as well.

Was expecting more but it was OK to entertain the kids.   Very small areas especially when people are crowded in to watch the feeding shows. The feedings were cool but just a bit too much talking going on prior to them.   They have a touch tank in the beginning with some turtles and others creatures and also one of sting rays at the end. They do not have any hand cleaning stations to use before or even after touching the animals but there is a restroom to use. There is also an area where you can pay $1 to feed the sharks which my nephew and niece loved.   The ticket also allows for the children to play in the play area next-door for free. It killed some time before going to have lunch and walk around some more.

I love this place! It's a great brunch/lunch place. The crepes are as yummy as they can be. My fav is the Nutella peanut butter, which is an ooey, gooey, sweet treat! They also have a great selection of gelatos, which seems to be a great hit, as I often see people coming in for a scoop. The coffee they serve there is the Italian Lavazza brand, and is delish! 

Also on the menu are sandwiches, salads, and pastry deserts, which are imported from Italy. The owner is a very nice lady from Italy, and the cafe's style reflects her background. It's reminiscent of any corner cafe in Rome.

As a die-hard Georgia Bulldog, of course I had some hesitation agreeing to go to a place called Gators. But, it's not too far from my family's beach house and it's on the water, so I figured, why not? My worst fears were confirmed when I encountered the University of Florida football statutes and orange/blue combos outside of the restaurant.

As we all know, though, you can't judge a book by its cover. Although there was plenty of hideous UF paraphernalia for sale in the gift shop & around the bar, there's also plenty of true alligator stuff, which I can handle. The patio is the place to be, sitting right on the water, with pelicans & seagulls sitting & waiting patiently in hopes of a dropped fry. You can also pull right up to the dock via boat & come on in for a drink or meal.

The food is OK. As a vegetarian I'm always a little more limited. I will say that while their black bean burger was fine for a veggie burger (middle of the road) it most certainly was NOT a black bean burger. (It was vegetarian, just far too light in color to contain more than a couple of black beans!) The onion rings are serious business and the key lime pie is fantastic (photo uploaded separately.)

So, despite the food not being much higher than a 6-7 out of 10, I love being right on the water and the staff is pretty friendly. I've been twice and will continue to visit when I'm at the beach.

Wow!  Wonderful new date night restaurant. 

We went here on a Saturday at 7p without a reservation - brave! But, somehow it worked out for us and we were immediately seated upstairs. They do save tables for walk-ins. The atmosphere is wonderful. Dark, warm woods. My hubby said it was a wonderful configuration for a restaurant. 

We started with drinks - my husband got an IPA and I got a glass of red wine. They had this wonderful cocktail book that explained all the drinks but the waitress was also VERY knowledgable. Drinks were fabulous, we got a second round. 

We started with the cheese sampler (3 for $16). My favorite was the goat cheese, my husband liked the "green hill."  Excellent presentation with house made crackers. 

For entrees, I got the lamb stew and my hubby got the pork shoulder sandwich. The stew had the absolutely best flavor, reminiscent of Indian but very much a comfort food on a cold day. My hubby's sandwich was just wonderfully cooked, the meat had the consistency of melted butter. The apple butter really brought the flavor together. His came with so many shoestring fries - I don't normally love shoestring fries but these were very nice and crisp but soft in the middle. 

We decided to do dessert, date cake with housemate frozen yogurt. It was good but not entirely my style. 

The service was awesome - Kirsten really knew her stuff and she was extremely pleasant. She checked on us the right amount and was very knowledgable about the menu items. The only (not very) negative point I will say is the support staff who brought the dishes didn't explain them - like which cheeses were which. But Kirsten came right over to make sure we knew! 

Our bill was $93 with four drinks, cheeses, 2 entrees, and dessert - not bad! My hubby said he was happy to spend a $100 on that meal - which NEVER happens. The entrees were reasonable ($11-19) so don't worry about spending too much unless you indulge like we did. 

We immediately began talking about when we would be back and who we wanted to come with us. What a delightful place with fantastic food and excellent staff. A MUST try.

Very simple place where you order your Chinese food and fried chicken wings to go. Ample parking here, compared to their location in New Orleans. I love their fried chicken wings. Always crispy and flavorful. Will be back soon.

Ted Drewes! Oh my GOD I love you! 

Custard! The best you've ever had in your LIFE. Go HUNGRY.

Great date night spot. Will be coming back again! Thoughtful, unique dishes + attentive service.

Food:
- hand cut truffle parmesan fries: would've preferred it to be a bit more crispy.
- carpaccio of beef tenderloin with house made ravioli: our favorite dish of the meal. fresh carpaccio and the house ravioli stuffed with soft poached egg was a nice touch. 
- roasted mushroom flatbread: second favorite dish. a lot of mushroom and arugula. would definitely order again.
- pulled slow braised short rib fat noodles: creative dish; loved the braised short rib with fresh pasta combo. but a tad too sweet and too salty for my taste.

Can't wait to come back and try all the other dishes!

This place has been on my list for a while and I finally made it in for a meal last night. It's pretty hard to go wrong on their menu, I had such a hard time deciding. In the end I went with the Pork Paperdelle and my date had the pork chop, and we did the flash fried brussle sprouts for an appetizer. All amazing. Plus an excellent drink menu, lovely atmosphere, and friendly helpful staff rounded out the evening. Plus I'm pretty sure the chef/butcher was coming around to the tables making sure everyone was happy. A nice touch! Can't wait to come back and try other menu items.

I love Macy's.. they have pretty much everything you could need to shop for. However we had a pretty awful experience at this Macy's on Saturday. First, I waited in a ridiculously long line just to get someone to grab some shoes for me to try on (there was one person working the whole busy area), and when he was my turn she looked at the shoes I was holding and impatiently went to the back and came out with half of them saying the others didn't have my size, and she was very unpleasant and rude about it. I think she noticed the shock in my face after how she spoke to me because she approached me afterward and was very helpful and chatty. Later, we went to buy some pajamas and the lady at the double sided counter ignored us and stood with her back facing us as we stood there waiting to make a purchase. When I asked, "are we able to check out here?" She said "yes just let me finish what I'm doing." So we walked to the opposite side of the counter and she said "I told you I could check you out. I did not say I would check you out on this side. You can go back to the other side" in a very stern voice. I considered putting my items back and leaving the store if I hadn't wanted them so badly. I will be avoiding this Macy's in the future because of the employee experiences we had.

HOTEL REVIEW ONLY: I am reviewing the hotel because I don't gamble and don't care for casinos.

My boyfriend and I are on a road trip and we have our two dogs. When we looked up hotels in the area, we saw that this place was dog friendly. The dogs love this place because there is the lake across the parking lot and at the end of the lake, there's a small grassy area where my dogs could go potty. It is really hard to find grassy areas near a hotel, in general.

Upon arrival, I instantly thought that this was a motel (which was what we expected for the price we were paying). To my surprise, when we got to the room, the inside was pretty nice. We even had little shampoo and lotion bottles (which a normal motel does not provide). 

If you're looking for a cheap, dog-friendly place in Reno, this is your best bet!

Wow. 

Ultimate birthday dinner! 

Went here for mine and my husband's birthday on a special trip to Philadelphia.  Whatever expectations I had prior to coming here were easily surpassed during this meal. 

The waitstaff all worked in coordination with one another and everyone was helpful and engaged. 

We started off with a cocktail at the bar.  My husband had the Sbraga punch which was sweet and perfectly balanced.  I enjoyed the South Carolina Serenade which was strong and delicious! 

We were then shown to our table where we found birthday cards for each of us signed by Chef Sbraga and were greeted quickly asking for our water preference and going over the set up of the menu. 

We tried to order quite a few different options to share: 

Truffle Popovers: One of the most delicious bread services I have ever had.  Hot and delicious.  We each had two and probably would have had more, but were glad we didn't so we could enjoy the rest of the food fully. 

First Course
Foie Gras Soup: Perfection.  There are no other words that I can use to describe the serious deliciousness of this dish.  It was rich, hearty and light at the same time, and so silky. I must love my husband because I didn't cut off his hand when he kept reaching in to steal more of my precious soup. 

Pork Belly with chili oil: Delicious and surprisingly light for pork belly.  This was a perfectly balanced dish that would have been a standout anywhere else, but I definitely won the round with the soup.

Second Course

Gnocchi, Escargot, Tom Ka Gai: We both could not pass up on this so we ordered the same dish, and in now way did I feel cheated.  This was the essence of delicious food.  Cloud like gnocchi with delicious and perfectly cooked escargot in an amazing tom ka gai broth with a bit of kick which helped to cut through the richness. 

Third Course

Spring Lamb: Delicious, though I didn't personally appreciate the raw shaved asparagus (personal preference, not a deterrent to the dish).  I enjoyed the dish, but it was not as memorable as the previous courses. 

Wagyu Beef Supplement: Wonderfully unctuous beef cheeks.  Definitely worth the supplement charge and a must try. 

Dessert

With so many interesting choices we asked our waiter for his opinion and he was quick to suggest the banana split and rice pudding. 

They were both delicious and light after such an amazing meal.  We sat for a few minutes savoring all of the interesting flavor combinations and reminiscing on one of the best meals either of us has ever had.  

The services was fantastic and we later found out that the staff had been at the restaurant from 9 am due to the PIFA street fair.  You would never have known that they had been there for more than 12 hours by the end of our meal and still going strong.  Fantastic food and fabulous service!

I will be back each and every time I return to Philadelphia which may just be more often now that I know what is waiting for me at dinner!

I love Tria.  Love love LOVE.  That should be my whole review, and you should go there immediately, but I will give a little more information I suppose.  

This place is on my block, and if I go 3-4 days without stopping by Tria, I get a little bit sad. 

First - their happy hour.  5-7 Mon-Thur, 2 wines, 2 cheeses, 2 beers, changing daily.  This is a great way to try new things.  

Second - their staff.  Extremely educated on the menu, they can describe each item and make recommendations.  They're not pretentious, even for my sad friends that only want "sweet wine" or "light beer" they are patient and make suggestions and let them try different things that they might like.  

Third - their Pistachio Herbed Ricotta with Lavendar Honey Bruschetta.  Order it immediately.  Do not pass go.  So.  Good.  

I could say a lot more about this place.  I love it.  Yes, it is a little pricey, but for the ambiance, diverse & changing menu and knowledgable staff - totally worth it.

I was super impressed with how friendly and attentive service was during my most recent visit. The food is still as good as I remembered it to be. We tried something new this time - the spicy marinated chicken with veggies. It was a stew like dish made with bone-in dark meat chicken, potatoes, peppers, onions, and carrots. Honestly when I saw it on the menu, it did not appeal to me. I'm so glad my boyfriend ordered it because it was soo good! I also love that I can bring my vegan friends here - there are plenty of vegan/vegetarian options. This is definitely my favorite Korean restaurant in Philly.

So I'm torn on this review...The place is pretty large and has a lot of seating options (which Laura W mentions). It seems to have a pretty strong following since it was really busy on a Thursday night (although it was the day before July 4th and there was a Phillies game on). 

I was with a party of 15 people and the food did come out quickly and all at once. I ordered their chicken parm sandwich which was awful. It tasted like it had peppers on it and I had to play "find the chicken" in my bun. But, everyone else seemed to LOVE their pull pork sandwich. I saw 5 women eat the whole thing. That's got to say something, right? 

I think I'm going to have to take Jeff back there to try it. Perhaps I just ordered the wrong dish?

I love this place! I mean if I could make a brewery this would be it. First the location is a little weird but they have a great outdoor space that can't be beat. Plenty of parking available as well. They had about 8 beers to either get a taste of or a larger pour. Between my husband and I we pretty much tried everything and it was all tasty. The beers are unique and full of flavor. They had a good mix of light beer, lagers, and porter type beers. Also it's super nice that they offer food. Their menu had a couple different options and we got the pretzels and cheese curds. The amount of pretzel sticks were insane! The mustard was delicious that it was served with. The cheese curds were also really yummy. We ordered the savant blanc to go which was beer aged in wine barrels and it was great! Maybe my favorite. We also got a couple other bottles to go. This place is really awesome and I cannot wait to return!

Local ice cream shop in a small town. I love supporting the local mom and pops stores so I came here expecting great things! Frosty Boy have decent soft serve ice cream in vanilla and chocolate flavors. They do have a weekly special flavor as well so keep your eyes out for those! I was disappointed that they do not offer sprinkles, only dipped or crunch toppings. An ice cream shop without sprinkles! What?! I was shocked when the cashier told me this. But milkshakes are good and have a thick consistency to it. The strawberry milkshake actually tasted like strawberry and not artificial flavoring. They have a large selection of food if you want to swing on by for lunch or dinner. Overall, it is a decent ice cream shop but nothing too special.

+ Super knowledgeable trainers and staff 
+ Passionate, friendly people at this gym
+ Top-notch Crossfit 
+ Amazing online resources

I started Crossfit on a whim because of a "why not" moment on Groupon. Why not? Perhaps since I've started, I have never been this sore in my life, nor have I ever had any desire to jump rope until I pee my pants. Why yes? Crossfit at The Lab is FUN. The coaches and your fellow gym rats are PASSIONATE people. They love what they do and it really shows. 

I was hesitant to try Crossfit due to all of the things I heard about how it can cause serious injury (rhabdomyolysis anyone?) due to overtraining and pushing oneself too hard in the name of competition. Not here at The Lab. You go through a 3-class "ramp-up" to get you acquainted with the basics and to guide you through proper form so that you can be familiar with the basic movements before you venture into a regular class. The trainers are so knowledgeable and so invested in helping you achieve your potential - everything from correcting your form to staying late after class to answer your million and one questions. Everyone is kind. No one is judgmental. I have never felt so welcome to a gym, as a newcomer or not. 

It's super inspiring to see people of all levels and expertise training alongside you. Not just because you happen to be a weenie and are benching only 43lbs (including the barbell lol) because it's only your first real-deal post-ramp up class. Ogling the people doing handstand pushups while you are struggling to finish your damn regular pushups is inspiring. At least it is to me. If you're into that kind of thing - seeing what others can achieve and knowing that with some hard work and sweat one day you can get there too.
I LOVE the Smiling Elephant! The place sure is small, but that's what makes it cozy inside! The staff is so friendly, and the menu has healthy options. Definitely recommended!

Wow! This place is very worth five stars. It actually makes me rethink what five stars is. The place is a little expensive for a burger place but we'll worth every penny. Don't come here looking for McDonald's.
I had a delicious beer called rogue dead guy. For an appetizer I had the mac and cheese bites, which were great, but a little over fried. Then the burger came out, and I jizzed in my pants. Cooked to perfection; medium, like I ordered. The staff was friendly and even though the place was busy, everything came out quickly. 
Overall, I would come here again and again, and recommend this place to anyone. Yes, anyone, because the even have veggie burgers. Be prepared to love this place.

If you love scents, soaps, cheesy things- you'd love this place.  I was busy smelling soaps and playing with cutely designed products.  Additionaly, the owner was super nice and told me to check out their in-progress website (which I haven't yet).  But I plan to visit the site to browse their creative products.

I was a bit dissapointed in this location, but will give them a chance since they just opened. I think their located on Campbell has things in order.. My friend ordered a juice, and the price on the board said 5.5.. but when she paid, they charged her 6.. She didnt say anything, but when we found out the guy who delivered the smoothie was the manager, she mentioned that they might want to change either the menu board or the computer.. He started to argue with her.. And then when he went and looked and saw, he offered the .50.. She didnt care about that, just wanted to have them make the change.. after all, .50 adds up! I love their iced tea and will go in for that, but last time the lid didnt fit right - so small and minor, but when you are driving and pick up the cup and the lid pops off, thats annoying. I went in the other day and no one even said hello to me, other than the nice girl working the registered.. It seemed like the group of guys standing near the bar were talking some serious business.... while the shoveled food in their mouths.. Oh well, I will go back, but not yet.

Took the kids for breakfast between soccer games, and to my surprise, not only did they behave reasonably well, but they now LOVE Ghini's and think she makes the best breakfast EVER. Why? Strawberry French Toast! I enjoyed my Western omelette too, and the coffee rocks. Yum.

Beautiful quaint feeling to the building. Romantic setting and kindly wait staff. The food and presentation of the food was good but be advised the portions are tiny.

I also saw a lovely little baby grand piano, although not in use during the lunch hour. :)

This is a solid neighborhood bar that is spacious and has MLB season pass (if that's important to you). I would hang out here alot except y'know the smoking. 

The liquor is well priced, the bartenders are on point, the clientele is diverse and welcoming. But dang do they smoke.

I've heard their trivia night is outstanding. And just as a note about the women's restrooms, they are spacious (not palatial) but you don't feel trapped and feature my all time dive bar favorite...plywood stalls. Love some industrious carpentry. PLUS they have old high school prom pictures to make you laugh. 

OK I just changed my review rating from 3 (because of the smoke) to 4 (because of the prom pictures).

Sometimes it's the little things...
Such a gem in South Philly!  I love getting my labneh and other Middle Eastern goodies at this place.  Fill your cart with homemade dips, breads, spices and sweets and enjoy a full Mezze dinner!

The fun part of a manicure and pedicure is trying out different nail polish colors. Unfortunately, many of the nail polish bottles here looked half to almost empty. This was a bummer. I noticed my nail polish selection was based on the amount available in the bottles versus my initial color preferences. Next to the till, there were plenty of brand new nail polish bottles to buy. However, I don't usually buy nail polish bottles at the salon. 

The lady who did my pedicure was nice. The pedicure tools looked like they were sanitized and clean. The manicure and pedicure set up looked pretty average. However, my main concern and turnoff here was an obvious breach in cleanliness that I witnessed. 

The lady who did my pedicure put on latex gloves prior to handling my feet. While my toenails were drying she was helping another customer pay at the till. I was grossed out by the fact she was still using the gloves she wore helping me! She handled the debit/credit machine while wearing the gloves. I know those machines aren't clean as a baseline but still! I think some people feel a false sense of cleanliness when they wear gloves. What other breaches in sanitation are happening here?

You need to wash your hands with soap and water before and after using gloves! Hand hygiene is especially important in a place where you're handling a large number of hands and feet. People don't want to get infections! We need reassurance that we're in a clean environment. 

I won't be back here and I don't recommend it.

Siam Elephant is a chill little Thai nook by the beach in Carpenteria. A friend of mine loved it and recommended it to me. The ethnic decor enhanced the delicious meal.

Our friendly server presented us with the most outstanding spring rolls. They were wrapped tightly with perfect lettuce and two dipping sauces. Spring rolls are take time to master and the flawless presentation demonstrated a high level of finesse.

My red coconut curry entree was delicious and I ended up eating the last of the broth with a spoon after inhaling every morsel.

I will be back, it may take me a while but it is on my radar.

When I was looking for dinner options in NO and came across Luke, I got excited in learning it was a John Besh restaurant! I am a big Top Chef junkie so I was really happy to have the chance to dine here while visiting NO for a day. Even better, it's a casual French restaurant (hubby likes casual, and I like French!). 

The service here is friendly and efficient. I wish the complimentary bread was warmer though. We started with a cup of the crab bisque, baked oysters, and the Flamenkuchen. Crab bisque was to die for. I especially loved the little kick it had. Bake oysters were also incredible. The Flamenkuchen, while highly recommended by other Yelpers, we thought it was okay. The flavor was nice but if the onion was warmer or closer to room temp, it would have been better. It was on the cooler side. 

For entree, we split the Steak Frites. We weren't given steak knives, not sure if we were supposed to or not, but we didn't even need them.
