This is no ordinary wine bar.  It is anything but ordinary with its exceptional montage of creative cuisines expertly paired with fantastic wines from their massive selection of old and new.  I am no wine expert so although I thoroughly enjoy sipping it, I will not even attempt to review it.  Cru Cellars is South Tampa's newest and best-hidden secret. Although located in a prime location on South Macdill with a clear street view and a large sign, Cru Cellars appears as a mere wine market.  Up until a couple of months ago, like many, I too was oblivious to the dimly lit, posh lounge nestled discreetly in the back of the market. This little secret has gradually been leaked to more and more wine and food-lovers alike who have been steadily making their way to wine and dine at this classy and quaint eatery.  Cru Cellars has only recently opened up their kitchen, enabling them to be part of Tampa's ever-growing culinary community.  Word of mouth has worked well for this up and coming food and wine gem and it seems they are responding well to the recent buzz.  Having visited the establishment twice now, both times a packed house, the ambiance, service and fare have been satisfyingly superb.  

With both visits to Cru Cellars, I have been blessed with wonderful service.  This wine bar may be refined, but in no way do the employees act pretentious.  Not only are they extremely knowledgeable with their wines and appropriate pairings, they are also friendly and very quick to please their guests. The carefully crafted menu includes a large list of chef-inspired eclectic small plates as well as a charcutterie board selection with a wide variety of tasty cured meats, exquisite artisanal cheeses and small bites such as olives and bruchetta.   These choices are accompanied by an array of delicious jams, mustards, nuts and crostini.  


My friends and I began with a charcuterie board.  We chose the two year-old gouda, the Cabot-cloth bound cheddar and the Kiev Russian-style salami. The board was presented attractively, though I did expect larger portions of cheese.  The salami had a nice salty bite and was particularly delightful with the gouda and crostini.  The cheddar was not as sharp as I had hoped and was slightly harder than I expected it would be.  The mustard and pecans were flavorful and added a perfect touch.  If I were to order a charcuterie board again, I'd probably lean toward the goats and sheep's milk cheeses instead.

We also ordered the half portion Roasted Mushroom Orzo.  Wow.  This dish was incredible.  Who knew orzo could be spruced up like this?  The fresh rosemary and thyme defined this glorious recipe and the bite from the Parmesan and the earthiness from roasted mushrooms was just outstanding.  The orzo came studded with bright red cherry tomatoes that served to add a pungent tang to the otherwise aromatic and rich ingredients.  Although not too complex, it was divinely rich and rustic with flavors my palate now constantly craves.  
Per suggestion of our server, we then ordered the Coriander-crusted Pork tenderloin.  This plate was beautifully presented with Spanish olives and Yukon Golds as its tasty accompaniment.  The pork was melt-in-your-mouth tender and had flawless essence from the coriander.  Refined comfort food with its meat and potato front, the scrumptious reduction and the salty Spanish olives make it a creation worth the "ohhh's and Ahhh's" it received.  A rather large "small plate," this dish was perfect for sharing amongst the four of us.  
To add to the already marvelous mix of cuisines, we ordered the flat bread with fig jam, arugula, bleu cheese and prosciutto.  The flat bread was delivered to our table bursting with colors.  The crust was crisp and tasty and the diverse flavors from the bold ingredients on top created quite the party in my mouth.  Intense bleu cheese, salty prosciutto, super sweet fig jam and the bitter arugula fashioned a brag-worthy combination I would recommend to all.  

If you haven't visited Cru Cellars yet, you are seriously missing out.  Delectable dishes are present as well as enough wines to satisfy the snobby.  They aim to please the hungry and the thirsty and do so with such eloquence; not a soul should leave disappointed.

I love this place.  The service is wonderful.  It looks crowded and difficult to maneuver from the outside, but once inside you will find wonderful people on both sides of the counter to help you place and receive your order. The food is great.  I loved the philly cheesesteak, which had a mushroom flavor from the ground up mushrooms inside, and the fahita.  We really liked the fries of course. Don't leave there without trying the orange flavored shake.  AMAZING.  Don't waste your time on the chocolate chip cookies; though vegan, they aren't really worth the calories. 

The location is great for anyone in Center City. Walk there, grab your meal and take it to Rittenhouse Park to eat. 

Here is the bad part: don't expect to go there for lunch with work colleagues in the middle of the day. Too crowded. No tables and chairs to sit in and no privacy. Oh, and no bathroom.  It is a take out place.  If you use it as that, you will not be disappointed.

I'm a little surprised at Alegro's lack of Yelps.  I love this place!  I used to go to Alegro for slices and a beer and sometimes for a study break to watch a bit of an Eagles game.  Given the variety of quality slices on offer, the reasonable beer selection, and the fun, casual and local atmosphere, I'm almost tempted to give Alegro that coveted fifth star!

A great place to get lost in!  If you love used book stores (and who doesn't?), The Book Trader is for you.  It's the quintessential musty, dim, cozy, with piles of books on the floor, bi-level treasure trove of previously loved books.  Aside from it occasionally being super hot upstairs, I always look forward to a trip to the Book Trader.

An amazing concept that delivers! 

I had wanted to try Luke for awhile now, but we couldn't get down to NO until this month.. Luke made it worth the wait.. 

My wife and I love France and the food, while Luke is a mix of classic French and German flair the French side is definitely the shining star here.. 

The decor is a bit simplistic, but in a good way. Light colored hardwoods and shared bench seating are both warm, comfortable and inviting.

The menu is is a bit German, a good amount of French and a splash of Creole added. 

We started out with the gumbo which was perfectly balanced and seasoned well. I'm not a seafood lover and I have to say this was the best gumbo I have ever tasted, my wife agreed. 

Oh before I forget.. The French bread and butter were done so well it would have made Lionel Poilane smile..

For mains my wife had the crab ravioli and I had the ribeye, both were excellent.

The pasta looked and tasted handmade and the sauce was creamy yet delicate, while the crab was fresh and large.

The ribeye I had was great, I want to address the comment below about  the ribeye being mostly fat.. Ribeyes are just that, a well marbled cut of meat which lends itself well to being slow roasted (Prime rib, Standing rib roast) when grilled the fat will be more prominent especially at lower temps.. Maybe he got a bad cut, but knowing your proteins is half the battle.. Back to the steak, I enjoyed my ribeye and the presentation on a wooden cutting board is a nice touch, however I did not care for the béarnaise sauce.. The fries were a bit salty for me, but I'm a hypersensitive to course salts so some might like them.. After brushing the salt off the taste was spot on and tasted like they were fried in a good oil not just plain ole veg.

For dessert we split the bread pudding and were pleasantly surprised at the souffle style presentation.. The taste was good, however the ice cream could use some work and I would try another dessert next time.. Even with the ice cream, it's still a very, very good dessert, I'm just more of a chocolate lover.. 

Drinks at Luke are AMAZING! It's not the typical NO drinks, these are high end fine cocktails.. The French 75 is well worth the price of admission and the brandied cherries that are put in random drinks are out of this world good.. Also, any time someone goes to the trouble to put a super high end Italian steam pump espresso machine in his restaurant I'm impressed.. The latte my wife had was better than I can make at home using peaberry Jamaican blue mountain.. 

For the value, concept and variety this is one of my favorite restaurants in New Orleans..

Five Stars

I normally refer to Honeygrow as the home of the $14 salad.  Yep, that happened the first time I was there.  Buyer beware: when you choose all of those delicious options for a build your own salad the price adds up fast!  That aside, I love HG.  I probably love too much for my own good and the good of my wallet.  It is a healthy oasis in the land of fried/mass manufactured crap that is City Ave.    

Honeygrow's ordering system is all electronic and you can even swipe your own card to pay.  Bonus- they remember your previous orders with a card swipe so once you create the perfect lunch you don't have to rack your brain to remember what you put in that salad.  Their turnaround time on salads is very quick - under 5 minutes even during the busiest times.  I'll admit that I'm a lettuce snob (if it's wilting at all  or dirty get it out of my face) and I approve of the quality of HG's lettuce and the freshness of the rest of their produce.

I'm not one for stir fry but many of my fellow lunchers rave about it as well as the smoothies.  

Only cons of HG:
-Can get pricey, fast
-Often hard to find a seat because they're so busy
-They don't have salt packets and their salt shaker is weak....

I love art stores, but this one is especially great. 

I went here because it was close to where I live and because I was really interested in getting into Screen Printing. I figured Artmart would be a better choice than Blick just based on the past experience with Blick stores and the reviews of Artmart. Artmart is a new type of art store for me. I've never seen one till I moved to St. Louis.

The first time I came here I was excited to see that everything was easy to find and everyone was easy to talk with for advice. I even found some bacon dental floss. Hardcore! 

I bought over a hundred dollars worth of art supplies, but had I known that I could get a discount for just creating an email account on their website I would have saved some $$. I realized after I left that I had bought some of the wrong materials and decided to go back later to do a quick exchange. Second time I came with my bf and the exchange was not so quick. My bf was full of questions about screen printing that he probably spent a good half hour quizzing someone who works there. The salesmen, however, did not seem bothered by the questioning and ended up being really helpful. I was real happy to see that the people who work at the store really known how to work their products. And it looks like they're not BSing you to buy unecessary tools for projects.

Oh, did I mention my bf was extremely excited to have found a .3 lead pencil for his work. Yes, that's the extra extra fine point. And, it's retractable, which is an added bonus so he doesn't poke himself while it's in his pocket!


This store doesn't quite get 5 stars, just because I feel slightly ripped off everytime I go into an art store, no matter which it is. At least at Artmart people who are college students in the St. Louis area can get a reasonable discount on their art project needs and I guess people will get an occasional discount in the mail if they sign up on their website. :)

The drive thru was quick, but the cashier was a true sweetheart. Although I didn't get her name, I loved her demeanor. She was so pleasant! My soy mocha was delicious and perfect. I'll definitely come back.

Some things I love:
  - eating with my hands
  - spices
  - being messy
  - expertly seasoned vegetables
  - trying new ethnic food

This Valentines weekend, Abyssinia provided me and my husband an opportunity to enjoy all these things and more.  As it was our first visit, our server took time to explain the menu, recommending the vegetarian Taste of Abyssinia option - a delectable combination of seven different vegetarian dishes, running the gamut from spinach and mustard greens, to potatoes, carrots, and cabbage, to both red and yellow lentils.  We chose the "for one" option, and it was PLENTY of food for the two of us.  We also tried the lentil and cabbage sambusas - both were fantastic with complex and well-melded flavors.

We used a Groupon, so not only was our meal delicious, warm, and flavorful, we got a fantastic deal.  Abyssinia - you rock my world (and my tastebuds).

What better way to spend a weekend lunch and hitting the mall, then at Tijuanas? Conviniently located across the street from countryside mall, Tijuanas is an awesome place to chill, eat and drink when at countryside. 

First, their food is pretty fresh. It doesn't have a generic  pre-prepped taste. I am a huge fan of their chicken tacos, their chicken or steak chimichangas! The 
verde sauce is stellar! 

Second,I absolutely love their hot bar. They keep the salsas exciting by changing them up ever couple of months. It's fun trying them while you wait for your food! Dare your friends to try the x_x faced ones. Lol.

Cons: I hate to admit that Tijuanas has had some pretty off days. I frequent here about 2 or 3 times a month on weekends or taco tuesdays. I will excuse them though because this place is often packed whenever my service is ho hum. Considering how popular this spot is, the food remained pretty consistent.

Overall, If your first experience at Tijuanas is not the best, please don't write it off. This is really a cool spot to eat at as an alternative to chipotle or the lame mall food. The vibe is good, outdoor seating is plenty. They have a limited but satisfying selection of wine and beer too to keep your weekend of shopping super chill!

What a great spot. My friends and I popped in here and I wasn't quite sure if we'd find what we were looking for. One of us is mainly vegetarian, one wanted bar food, and one wanted super healthy. Surprisingly, we all managed to find something we loved! The tables are tiny, but that just makes it more cozy and intimate. I liked it - we had a good time!

So one day I'm diggin gloriously delicious vegan food, and the next day I'm splitting a bunch of hot dogs. I do what I please, got me?

Actually, all the specialty regionally dressed hot dogs can be made veggie dog style... but I gotta see about all that another day.

Hot Diggity opened down the street, all clean splarkly fresh and new... we were curious and the smell of Sabrett's lured us in. Oh I do appreciate a them snappy dogs

They place them in Liscio's rolls to hold all the various toppings sans sogginess. Good move, I say. We split the Bronx Bomber, a winner with sauerkraut, spicy brown mustard, and pickled onion relish. I'll tell you something else, the Big Kahuna dog was good too. Everything Hawaiian themed has to be called, "The Big Kahuna," dontcha know. Guava mustard, grilled onions, pineapple salsa and habanero aioli made for some sweet tasty business on that salty dog. The Cincinnati Skyline, in my opinion, was only aight however. The whiz/chilli combo kinda gnarled me a little, but of course...there is the chance that I was just overly brimming with hot dogs at that point?

Now listen to me. If all this frankfurter talk isn't doin it for you, OK, but you need to know something about Hot Diggity's fries. Yes we got fries too. I'll tell you what's what. They are so good. Remember how I feel about dipping sauces? I'm for em. The curry mayo is a lovely.

Hand cut, frites style, perfectly crispy, perfectly salted fries!  They're served in a brown paper cone. The tables have cone holes. Good thinkin.

Fries goes in the cone, cone goes in the cone hole..you go in the cone. Fries in the cone. Our fries.

Stayed here on a few different occasions while friends/family were visiting. I love Holiday Inn's. Great wifi, clean rooms, comfy beds, friendly staff = win win win! There's also a great bar downstairs that often has live music, which is a bonus. It's right next to Vandy so it can get a bit crowded during game days but they have a massive parking lot in the back so parking really is never an issue!

After touring thrice, seeing what would become our new home twice, and a pocket or five of those warm, deliciously baked complimentary cookies in the lobby, we were pretty sure Beacon 430 was going to be where we'd be hanging our beads for at least the next 12 months! Cheryl was our guide & light-bearer through the paperwork & approval process; without her, we'd've surely been up the metaphorical creek! Jay, who I believe is the property manager, has also been nothing short of marvelous. Just this week while exiting the parking garage we were greeted by Jay & his crew handing out orange juice & Chick-fil-A biscuits! What a way to start the day! I mean, who has time for breakfast? That's going above & beyond! Period.

We adore our new home overlooking the pool. We've two large balconies, and the kitchen island is such a breath of fresh air! So much space! Huge rooms, huge closets, huge shower!

Now, let's address the elephant in the room... Or, upstairs I should say. Yes, the walls/floors are thin & I'm moderately certain a pachyderm lives above us, but it's apartment living & I'm not sure it could get much better than this, particularly in awesome DTSP. We meticulously combed & critiqued everywhere in downtown, but the deals, perks, and set-up offered by Beacon 430 couldn't be beat! Love it.

Wowee!! Didn't know it was there. Right in the stripmall with Book Rack. Opens at 11 a.m.

My dealings with Book Rack completed, I moseyed on down. They've been open as Stoogez since December 2015, per Cassie. It used to be Island Bar.

It's a bar. Themed after The Three Stooges, with a reel playing and sayings everywhere (as in Nyuk), as well as Moe, Larry and Curly statues on display. What fun!

Cassie was the attentive and friendly bartendress. I asked about a particular libation, and got olives with it!

I was the only one there for a while, so we had a lovely conversation. Then others came. And they're regulars. I was the odd man out.

So, I introduced myself to everybody and in so doing, found many connections, lots related to armed services.

Incredibly nice folks behind the bar (Cassie) and in front of the bar, who included me in their conversation, and were regular people.

Nice to find regular, friendly people. And good libations.

Love love LOVE this place. It's quaint and easy to overlook, but def a gem! Came here while a friend was in town and we started our visit at the bar while we waited for a table. The bartender was engaging and well versed in his cocktails. We felt like we were getting a mini lesson in classic drinks and their variations throughout history. 

Next we ordered appetizers and before they came we were pleased to be brought these little bread roll wonders. They were like little pillows of heaven. They were the perfect mixture of crisp on the outside and soft and buttery on the inside. 

Next up cauliflower soup and a dip that made me wish it was an entree on its on. Both were decadent and a little bit sinful and I can't wait to have them again. 

We all ordered fish from the menu, one has a very island flavor served over rice, the other a more classic spin with potatoes. Both were amaze. My guy and I will def be back.

Walking around and spotted some lovely jewelry and gorgeous purses so I had to stop in. Darling little shop with great things for gifts and for yourself. 

Cool items and for a good cause... check this out. Through the sale of their fair-trade products, Mushmina creates employment opportunities for women and men in developing countries. A company with a social mission, you have got to love and support that. They work mainly with artisans in Morocco and locally in Philly. 

I scored a gorgeous feather earring and unique string and metal bracelet. I love them both. Definitely check this spot out.

Layla's was the first place we went to as we began exploring Broadway.

I was only there for about 1/2 an hour, but I really loved it.  The band was great, and it really got the evening going for us.

The drinks were a little pricey, but that's okay.  The music made it all better.

It's a fun little country bar.  I would like to come back and take in some more music on my next visit.

Came here with a group of 3 on a hot summer afternoon. We came in looking to order some of their ice pops. The ice pops were so good! We couldn't decide on flavors so ended up each ordering two and sharing! Some favorites were the goat cheese and apricot. I think she does the creamy pops like avocado really well, but some of the fruity pops could use a bit more fruit flavor. I love the fruit and herb pairings she puts in the pops, and you can count on Whisk to have great popsicles for those hot summer days. 

Baked goods. I ended up trying the brownie and GEEZ. Not only is it huge, but it's also kind of to-die for. Highly recommend it. 

Happy Eating!

I love a good sandwich!  In Tucson, Baggin's is the best.  Every time I enter, I have this internal debate about the Unforgettable (turkey, bacon, avocado, sprouts) or the Prime with horseradish (roast beef, onion, tomato).  So hard to choose!  One of these visits, I must try something different...  

And everything comes with a fresh cookie. Score!

Following the whole Hibachi/Benihana idea, Something's Fishy is a place I've been to many a time when coming home to SB. Its somehow got a little homey attachment to it for me, but after eating here quite a few times you realize that without the whole SHOW and food Dance, the food is "Meh, ok" at best. 

Getting any hibachi dish will taste essentially the same, because they use about 2 spices for everything, while fancifully grilling it on a Hibachi stove. This place isn't somewhere to go for good food. 
Instead go for the action of the chefs, the volcano onions, and all other Kitschy disneyfied food creation.
Add in some Sake Bombing, and it makes the whole experience much more fun! If you've got kids, take them here they'll love the show that puts your food, literally, on fire! My friend recalled that in his childhood he thought these kinds of chefs were "the best in the world," go here and maybe your child will think so too.

If you haven't got kids, then knock back a few sake bombs and let the fresh food with a fire-y pizazz put you in a daze, while you munch on the fire's creations. 

Note: this place's prices have gone up quite steeply over the years, and probably will go up again. As of now, its pushing the limits of value for quality/food/entertainment, but I wouldn't go if it gets any more expensive.

Cash only which is why it's 4 stars! However I love the ice cream and it's an old fashioned dive. The milkshakes are delicious and they have lots of flavors. The soft serve is yummy and they have generous portions. It's a cute place to come with kids or as part of a low key date night.

I really love coming here with my mom and sister. It is gigantic, and there are always new things to see. The staff is really helpful and takes your purchases to the front counter as you are shopping so you don't have to carry them around. We always find cute glassware - drinkware, bowls, vases, etc. They also have great furniture and decorations. And trinkets galore.

Lovely place to dine. Great atmosphere, nice bar area, and just a fun time. Came here for restaurant week, and this is by far one of the better options this season. Their menu includes many of their normal ala carte items at a really great deal.

I had the kampachi crudo, the pork belly, duck breast and chocolate mousse. The crudo was probably my least favorite. The fish itself was fine, but I wasn't a fan of the citrus jelly and cream sauce. My friend got the raw beef, which I thought tasted much better.

The pork belly was my favorite. A succulent piece of fatty pork belly with a squid salad and crisped black rice. It was absolutely delicious. 

The duck breast was flavorful and tasty. There were one or two slices in the middle that was slightly too rare for me, but otherwise fine. I also tried a bite of my friend's mushroom papardelle, and it was equally tasty (though the portion for that was very small). 

I asked the waiter to recommend a dessert, and ended up with the chocolate mousse. It had sea salt and a bit of banana flavor. I enjoyed it more than I thought I would enjoy a mousse.

The plating here is beautiful and provides for an all around fun and visually pleasing meal.

Local Taco has a great happy hour and a nice outdoor porch. Happy hour consists of extremely affordable ($3) margaritas all night on Mondays. Outside of that, the food is average in my opinion. I love the creativity of the tacos, but no Hong really stands out. The fried mac and cheese with green chilies is probably the exception here. Get a side of that, a happy hour marg, and spend a few hours on the patio for a great evening.

Great asian food market with almost everything I loved to eat and drink while in Japan.  Still missing a few of the good bottled teas but huge selection none the less.  

Their bubble tea is also very delicious (I got avocado bubble tea)  and makes for a good treat while shopping. 

While I was there they surprised me by having tasting booths set up at multiple spots (I haven't seen that at a grocery store in a really long time.)

Wonderfully designed art museum!  With a fantastic collection!  The museum is free, but featured an exhibit of Georgia O'Keefe's work for a small price.  We choose to stick to the regular museum since we were on a time crunch!  
The museum is fantastically laid out and has quite the history!  One of the oldest general art museum's in the nation housing over 50,000 works, some that are 5,000 years old!  

Lots of great old European pieces, a wonderful contemporary collection, and a very large design collection as well!  I loved it!  Even though we did not have much time, we could move from room to room easily in a maze of amazement! 

It's was raining so we didn't get to walk the grounds and sculpture park but did enjoy the view from the top levels, windows! 

Very nice staff, super clean and comfortable and wonderful viewing experience!  Great Museum!

I'm not vegan or even vegetarian, but this place exceeded my expectations. In fact, I enjoyed my dinner experience here so much that I came back to try brunch the next day. The menu has plenty of delicious meat substitutes so even carnivores shouldn't miss it on the menu. I highly recommend the Korean BBQ Seitan High Fives, the Mac & Cheese Croquettes, and the Sweet Potato Hash (from the brunch menu). I'm amazed at how much rich flavor and complexity Three Carrots achieves in dishes without meat, dairy, etc. At both visits everyone loved their food and service was prompt and accurate. Local craft beers on tap and a bright, trendy atmosphere are icing on the cake. I can't wait to try more menu items from this great new spot!

Organized, clean, and well kept! Not the biggest Rack I've visited, but I loved that I could find everything easily. The staff was very friendly and on the ball, and they clearly take the time to put things where they belonged. The fitting rooms were a bit small but they were well lit and very clean. I overheard a sales associate giving a customer options for having pants tailored, and it sounded like they could do in-store alterations. 

Lots of shopping and places to eat in the immediate area and ample parking. 

Great experience today, and I found awesome deals!

Breakfast was swing and a miss for me.  I want to like this place so much, but despite being a diner with a huge focus on breakfast, I think they shine better at dinner.  Service was ok, nothing special, and kind of slow.  The quality of the food was average to slightly below average.  My hubby's grits were downright nasty. They were watery sludge.  

It's so close, reasonably priced, and I loved dinner the one time I went to a different location.  I'll be back to try them for dinner.  Fingers crossed!

When my visiting cousin wanted some good BBQ, I knew we'd have to give Edley's Bar-B-Que a try.  My coworkers had recommended it multiple times,  yet I'd still never been.  (Even if a restaurant has been around for a while, I like to review it when I go for the first time, in case my experience can add to the venue's track record.)

The ambiance at Edley's is very BBQ... paper towels on the tables, extra sauce, reclaimed wood everywhere, and the wonderful BBQ smell.  They also have a great bar area.

You order at the counter, then they bring the food out to you.  You can see the delicious desserts (like gooey butter cake and chess pie, oh my!) up there too, tempting you.  My cousin got the banana pudding as a side, and I was jealous.  But I had my hands full with my pork sandwich, cornbread, and macaroni and cheese.  The cornbread was good, and it had a little jalapeno kick to it.  I prefer plain cornbread, but still good.

The macaroni impressed me!  I love macaroni, but usually the sides at BBQ places are kind of bland and generic.  This macaroni was thoughtfully seasoned (I know that sounds so pretentious, but it's the only way I could describe it) and worth choosing.  I am lactose intolerant, so I have to take medication to eat mac 'n' cheese, and I'd deem this worth it!  The sandwich was top notch too.  I really thought the ratio of sauce to meat was perfect, and the bread was good too.

Dan got a half rack of ribs, as well as the brisket chili.  I got to taste both, and it was delicious!  There's great brisket meat and spices in that chili.  I'd recommend this option too, if you're into ribs.  My cousin got the ribs, mac, and banana pudding.  The sandwiches comes with two sides, but the ribs come with two sides and cornbread.  Bonus!

When you're done with the meal, you toss the trash away and put your tray on the pile.  Edley's is definitely my new "old" favorite for BBQ in the Nashville area!

Was my second time coming here and the service was amazing ! Love the cleanliness of the facility & the friendliness among staff . We were seen in a timely fashion especially for it to be a Saturday . We also were present many options in nail color choice which is important ! My mother and I left satisfied and have nothing but great intentions of returning . Prices were also super reasonable

Love that you can make your own smoothies here! This is the only place I have ever been able to do that. I had a delicious smoothie made with vanilla bean yogurt and tons of fresh berries. They blended in some tropical fruit juice. It was extra delicious! ;) I'll be back.

I can easily eat at this place everyday! Breakfast & lunch are soo good. Salads are great. I love to go here during my lunch. The food here is delicious and the menu offers a wide variety. The staff is friendly, the places looks clean and I never have to wait a long time. Fish taco wrap is out of the world, baja turkey panini is super delicious. Salads & bowls are yummmmyyy! Everything is so fresh here.

Super disappointed with their donuts. They are like bread not donuts, so imagine a slightly flavored bread, with some stuffed with crap in them. 
Now this was our cheat day so we went all out. We stood in line for 30 minutes or so. I got the blackberry lemon and the beignet. The beignet filling tasted like coffee which is not what i was expecting, so it ruined it for me. The lemon one tasted like slightly stale bread. I took 4 bites and threw out almost two whole donuts. My friend who is a donut lover and found this place took two bites  and threw hers out too. THAT IS CRAZY FOR US! Very very disappointed. Don't waste your time.

I was impressed.  That's really all I can say. It has the ambience of a chain seafood joint (loud, neutral, overall unattractive) but puts out some of the freshest seafood that I've had in a long time.

We ordered the steamed oysters, the cleveland oysters, the fried oyster dinner, and the steamer basket (which consisted of steamed clams, mussels, alaskan king, and shrimp).  All oysters were absolutely OUTSTANDING.  My applause goes to the chef who was not only fast, but did not overcook them in the slightest.  Loved loved loved them oysters.

The steamer basket was also very well prepared.  All seafood cooked perfectly, not even remotely overdone at all.  The alaskan king crab was succulent, sweet, and did not taste flash-frozen like it sometimes can even at my beloved Bob Chinn's.  There was actually a lot of crab and shrimp.  All of it was probably well-seasoned and had a hint of old bay. MMMMM, love old bay.  The price was OMG CHEAP - $23.99 and this bucket could have fed at least 2 people. They definitely did not skimp on portion here.

We did have to wait for an hour but in the end it was worth it. We will be back.
We ended with the molten chocolate cake. MMMMMMM.  It was quite tasty especially with so much whipped cream.

Moxies are pretty standard Canada wide.  This one is no different.  You can always expect good drinks and a decent menu.  I especially like this location as it is the perfect place to grab a bite either before or after seeing a film at Cineplex north!

They have a pretty good patio and their sangria is top notch!! Plus they have a great brunch menu and everyone loves a good brunch.  I had great service every time I visit this location.  I never have a hard time getting a table here but that may be because I come at non peak times? 

I can easily say that moxies may very well be the best restaurant in the complex there!

Seriously, you wouldn't think it about a Latin American restaurant in St. Pete, but this was fantastic.  I should point out that I give it 5 stars as far as Latin/Mexican places go - it is one of the best I've been to in FL - but it's not necessarily a 5 star restaurant over all.

Its a casual restaurant - inviting atmosphere, not fancy at all.  It was very busy when we arrived, but the service was fantastic and the server who helped us knew the menu inside and out.  She was excellent.

My girlfriend is 1/2 Latina, and extremely picky about her Spanish food.  I actually expected more of a Mexican restaurant, and while they have some Mexican items, the menu is much more of a Latin American menu than a Mexican menu.  She loved it (see her 4 star review under Melissa Z), and if she loves Latin food, then you will too.

Be warned though - when they say something is spicy, they are not kidding.  I got the Puntas de Filet Mignon.  To quote their menu directly, "filet mignon tips in chipolte chile butter with bacon, tomato, jalapeño, poblano chile and onion. served with black beans, rice and tortillas on request."  It is as wonderful as it sounds, but it made me sweat.  Okay, that's not saying much, I'd sweat sitting outside in a blizzard naked (don't picture it, you'll get sick), but this stuff was extremely spicy.  I loved it.

Check this place out - it's amazing and you won't regret it.

LOVE Metro Diner. The staff and the food..the food! So good! Ok, so I've only had the San Francisco benedict (w/o ham, subbed in spinach) and the veggie omelet, but if that was amazing the only obvious conclusion is that EVERYTHING is delicious right? It's how my brain works. 

I recommend you sit at the bar if you can. It's quite entertaining watching the cooks and wait staffs interact with each other.  And there are places that ignore patrons that are sitting at the bar, but not here. The gal that was serving us was very nice and attentive. Even though it was a full house (Saturday morning) we didn't have to wait long for our food. 

Another plus: it's right by the hospital where I work. A quick call and your order can be ready in 15 minutes for pick up.

Great place, great live music (not too loud, just right), and (mostly) great food. Make sure to call ahead for a reservation since this is not a "walk-in" type place; there's just no room inside to handle walk-ins on this very busy street.

We started the meal with some mixed drinks which were pretty solid, if not a little girly looking.

Our food order (all as tapas size):

- Three Muses Fries -- Really good feta on top of this with a great texture to it. Fries were really well cooked and crunchy.

- Roasted Root Vegetable Salad -- Really good falafel crusted goat cheese, I could eat that all day. Pretty creative use of falafel as a container for the goat cheese to give it a lot of crunch and change of texture in the salad.

- Two Run Farms Lamb Sliders -- Super, super delicious. These were by far my favorite part of the meal. It was perfect.

- Louisiana Strawberry Tart -- We're stealing this and claiming it as an old family recipe passed down from our great grandparents. It was that good. Really solid execution. The basil ice cream was clearly made with fresh basil and packed too much flavor on it's own, but when eaten with the tart it was really well balanced. The tart almost tasted like it had a little custard in it and was really delicious.

- Gulf Fish Tacos -- The only thing we ordered that we didn't love. It reallyyyyyyy needed something crunchy in it to give it texture/bite since it was a bit soft and squishy. My fiancée actually couldn't handle the texture and ended up having to spit it out. The lime they gave with the fish was almost completely dry so they lacked a lot of acid as well and made it fall very flat on taste. The saucing was a bit uneven since only one taco had enough sauce to really punch through and give it a vibrant flavor; the rest were just mushy and bland.

First I want to start by saying that I truly applaud these guys for what they are trying to do. Local BMX and skateboard shops have completely disappeared in the Reno/Sparks area due to major retail stores like Scheels, Zumies, and Tillys. I wish that this was not the case. For me, walking into a bike shop that carried BMX supplies was like going to Disneyland. There is so much potential for Forever 2 Wheels but I'm just not sure that they know how to capitalize on it. I hope that the owners read this review and use it as constructive criticism in order to prosper.

The bike shop couldn't possibly be in a better location. Located directly across the street from Burgess Skate Park there is so much untapped potential. I was riding the park and asking the people there if they knew of any good places where I could go to find a new bike tire. Turns out that all the riders there just referred to purchasing them online. Nobody even knew that this shop existed, let alone that it was right across the street from where we were! They should really work on reaching out to the community. If I worked at this shop I would get in contact with the City of Sparks and apply for a permit to hold a park jam where I could bring awareness to the demographic in which is their ideal customer base. Hold contests and give away some things for winners, throw out swag, and build up facetime with the kids.

Now for the shop itself. Walking into the shop it feels more like an old garage than anything. There is way way too much used equipment. It seems to be a second hand store. The frames, wheels, and even shoes that they have are all so antiquated and gross that I wouldn't even be able to give them away for free. All that stuff would be given to Goodwill without doubt. who is trying to buy old beat-up skate shoes?  The pictures they have posted on their Yelp just go to prove this point. There is new equipment but there is also problems with their inventory of that. You guys are located across the street from a skate park but you are not carrying park equipment. I was in there for a street tire and there was only one. The tire was mangled and there was no chance that it would have even been up to manufactures standards, plus they were asking way too much for it. I could order the same tire online, have it overnight delivered, and still end up paying less. I love to buy local but that doesn't mean that I am willing to overpay for it. You have to offer competitive prices to your biggest competitors like Danscomp.com

Overall I just feel that the guys at this shop are not up to date with sport. I believe that they once had a passion for riding bikes but have since been separated with the current trends. I really do hope that they succeed and learn what the bike community is looking for. As for now Forever 2 Wheels just isn't there and I think that they are going to end up losing more customers than they can attract. I will try back in a few months to see if anything changes but until then, online shopping it is. Hopefully I can change this review in the future.

I went to Jasmine Rice on a Friday at 8pm. It was empty when we got there, but boy did it fill up! There were three of us at a very cozy table. We had the spring rolls and the ginger scallion dumplings. I loved both. The lighting wasn't great, and the door kept opening and it was COLD in there. They have a curtain, presumably to keep this from happening, but it was open and not in use while we were there. I would imagine (and hope) that they use this as we get deeper into winter. I hate eating when I'm uncomfortable. 

I had green curry, which was good, but not the five pepper spice I had requested. If you really like your Thai food spicy, ask for more than the five on the menu. I couldn't taste the spice at all. The food was good, and the portion appropriate. None of us had leftovers, which happens to me more often than not at Thai places. My dinner mates also noted that the spice level was extremely low in their dishes. We probably won't go back, but it was fine and the location was super convenient.

i love this theater.  it's older, which is why they have older run movies, but it's kept well cleaned, they have a full concession bar, and the staff is really friendly.  Tuesday their prices are even cheaper!  I love popping by in the middle of the week.  This past Wed afternoon I was the only person in the theater - it was like my own private screening :-)

Came in for my 5-6 month prophy and saw Kara - who is a new hygenist and TERRIFIC.  She took text-book perfect bitewings (digital, baby!) and Dr. D is great as always. Plus I love LeeAnn (sp??) - the office manager.  Such a well-run place!

Plus I got strawberry prophy paste.

Wheeeeeee!

Finally an interesting place in Hermitage. I would love to live in Nashville, but don't have the money to. That means I am stuck in the burbs, in this case Hermitage, which means I have to drive into Nashville to eat interesting food. But this place opened up and gives me a great place to go. The place is not a decorators delight, but the food makes up for it. If I didn't have a heart and corresponding arteries, I would eat the Bosnian burger everyday. It's delicious. I have a had a few other things, but nothing compares to it. The owner is really nice, and talked with me and my family for a long time one night about how she got here from Bosnia, and where all she has cooked. Take a peak behind the counter and you'll see that she is cooking all this great food on a closeout stove from Sears it looks like. She closed for the whole month of December to go back home to Bosnia, which wasn't good, but hopefully she will stay open enough to stay in business.

Ahh! Another favorite spot of mine in Florida. We absolutely love Hellas in Tarpon Springs! I haven't been here in years and this visit back did not disappoint. My husband made the comment beforehand how he 'wasn't a Greek fan' well... he sure kicked himself after he had dinner here because he loved it!

My cousin came with us and he ordered for the table; large Greek salad, two Opa flaming cheese, combo platter and the BLT (silly, I know) the BLT is packed with tons of bacon, fresh tomatoes, and we even had feta to make it better! The Greek salad comes with potato salad in the middle which adds excellent flavor and a different spin on the traditional Greek salad, and the dressing is out of this world. The combo platter had many Greek traditional dishes, with decent portions. My husband loved trying the different Greek dishes. 

Everyone treats you like family! The servers are all so friendly and fun. Even the Bakery attaches which is excellent and always very busy, they are so nice. The cannolis are out of this world! 

Must try if you head to Tarpon Springs! The BLT is my favorite as well as the Greek Salad. Yum!

This place has me torn. I love nothing more than burgers & fries, but this is just a little off from being a great burger place. 

I dinned here on a Sunday afternoon, around 1:30pm. The restaurant was pretty busy, a large church crowd present. I entered the building & was greeted by one of the two unfriendly, female hostesses. I didn't know if she was a hostess or not because I had to say hello first to her. I thought by the look she gave me that I was just talking to a teenage girl that was standing near the hostess stand. 

We were sat at a high top table & was greeted by a friendly waitress. The restaurant is furnished with a lot of wood & natural colors. The feel is very comfortable. The menu has a lot of burgers & sandwiches. Bottomless fries are served with a lot of the burgers. I decided to get the mushroom & Swiss burger, cooked medium with fries ($11). 

The food - the burger was cooked well done, not medium. The beef was nice, I would guess 93/7 beef. Burger Up! prides themselves on using local meet & produce. The beef was nice, but didn't have much favor, it needed a little salt & pepper & maybe a little more fat for flavor. The mushroom & Swiss comes with onions with horseradish sauce. The sauce didn't have much flavor, which I was surprised by, because horseradish is a very intense flavor. The fries were okay. They are cut from the potato with the skin on, which I like, but they tastes too greasy for me. The fries also didn't have much flavor other than grease. 

Overall, for 11 dollars, the burger tasted like a 6 dollar burger. It didn't have much flavor & the fries had too much of a grease taste for me. Would I eat here again? Yea, if friends wanted to eat here I would go along, but I'd never say to anyone that I wanted to go there first.

I was here for the first time last week.  I'm going to keep this short.

It's good.  It has a feel of one of my favorite coffee spots in San Francisco.  Lots of light wood and just a home feeling about it.

The folks that work there are really friendly (probably friendlier than the customers.)  

I walked in recovering from a sore throat and decided to order tea.  They have a great selection of teas.  My father loved tea.  I spent 8 years abroad and traveling and have tried some great teas too.  The Gryphon doesn't disappoint because you have a range of herb, white, green, and black teas.  I chose the orange chamomile, and it was excellent.

Plus, they have wifi and plenty of plugs.  I hope I have a chance to spend more time there before I move on to NYC.  Check it out if you're ever in the area.

First of all the ambiance is really lovely! I love the interior design- it just feels so classy but still cozy. 

The gelato is pretty good too. I went with a friend and her biggest complaint was that they didn't have very many flavors of gelato. It was funny because they didn't have a single fruity flavor when we went, but they had oranges in their case. But overall, the gelato I had was tasty.

I love supporting small and locally run businesses and this is no different. It is *so* good to get a legitimate Mexican restaurant in the downtown area; no need to always schlep to the Bench or Nampa to get my fix (though that's great too, if you have the time). Service is consistently friendly, helpful, and expedient -- the people here are super nice and it goes a long way!

My coworkers and I usually come here for the Taco Tuesday AYCE special and it has yet to disappoint. Their carnitas and adobada is probably the best I've tried here in Idaho so far, and you really can't argue with the price. Just come down for lunch, eat your heart out, and do a few jumping jacks before heading back to the office to ward off the contented post-lunch sleepies.

It's also a great choice as a late night spot, as they are open until 2AM. I'm so grateful there's another option in the Pie Hole price range, which gets a little too rowdy with the runoff from Fatty's. Sometimes it's late and the only solution is a taco.

With the small exception of once seing a dead body in the water there, this is by far my favorite place.  Period. I love to hike the trails early mornings and just be.  And these are no sissy trails if you go on the right ones.  Trust me.  They'll kick your but.  There is nothing like a serene time in the woods to put things in perspective.  I used to go alone a lot, but fear of death dictated that I bring a buddy now, not as serene but hell, at least I'm still alive.  I totally recommend - just don't be on my trails when I want some peace and quiet!

I loved my stay here! It was nicer than the last Hilton I stayed in and you get the added bonus of not having to pay extra for all the crap "higher class" brands charge - like wi-fi. The bed was really comfortable, the room spotless and the staff was incredibly nice. 

To alleviate the hassle of making a left from Grant into the parking lot, drive about half a block more, turn left at the light on Forbes and go around the back way. Easy peasy.

The location is convenient to the University and the other areas I needed to be while visiting.

My favorite diner to have breakfast. I love their breakfast sandwich platters, scrapple, omelettes, and the service is quick and efficient. They also have a great bakery case. Brownies and cake delicious. I wish they didn't take away the chicken and bacon pita melt though.

Came for happy hour at the recommendation of friends. (Happy hour is not just at the bar, by the way!)
The 75 cent raw oysters and half off drinks are an awesome deal. The oysters were huge and delicious, freshly shucked right in front of us at the bar. The rosemary Gintelly lace drink has a nice flavor. We also had the crispy brussel sprouts-- definitely recommend. The service  was spot on. We did not try the shrimp & grits entree since we were just in for a drink and a snack, but several friends raved about it, as did the customer next to us at the bar.  
Overall, we loved everything and felt like we got a great value and a memorable meal.

UPDATE: Came back again and had another stellar experience. I stand by my previous review. Sit at the bar-- the bartenders are super nice.

We came for Sunday Brunch and though none of our party ordered "brunch fare" per se, we did enjoy the 2 for 1 drinks during brunch. I had the Jackalope Bearwalker, good as expected!
We were a fairly large party (8) but were able to get a table without wait. They don't take reservations so we did get there on the earlier side to secure a large spot.
Staff was friendly and attentive. 
Most of us ordered burgers and those were very good. I had the NashVegas, medium well. It was cooked just right though my husband's medium well burger was a bit under what he prefers. Love the sweet potato bun, the pimento cheese could have been spread a bit as it was sort of lumped in there but a good burger. I had the sweet potato waffle fries and they were good. Crispier than some waffle fries (I don't really like the 'mushy' waffle fries) which is good but some of mine leaned toward a bit overdone.  
Nice place. Sound level was good for our large party who was talking and catching up with each other.

The Paradise Café was so fresh and delicious. We went during lunch time. I had a special for steak tacos that came with a fresh salad that resembled a Caesar salad yet it wasn't drenched in creamy dressing. The dish also came with some fresh pico de gallo and this cilantro flavored guac sauce that was amazing! The flavors were so plentiful and fresh. I really loved my dish and would recommend this restaurant.

I come here quite often and really enjoy the place.  The owner's wife is such a sweetheart and makes amazing coronaritas and margaritas.  The service is always fantastic as well.  It is always very clean and the servers are friendly and efficient.  Your basket of chips will never be empty.

I do love that they serve chicken mole (unlike a few other Mexican places in the same area).  The mole is great.  I love their shrimp cocktail too,  It is a huge portion and is just fantastic.  I have tried their ceviche which is also very tasty.  The fish tacos are really great and very authentic as well.  The chicken salads are yummy too. 

The only complaint I have is that I hate the low-backed booth seats but that is just a personal preference of my own.  Anyhow, if you haven't been here, definitely check it out.

Chipotle never fails me! I can count on them for a meal that is fresh, fast, delicious and affordable! I LOVE having the option to go all out with meat, cheese, and sour cream if I want, or straight veggie style, and never feeling like I'm lacking anything. It's one of the few places in town that I can think of that always works for everyone in our family, especially If we are out and about and not wanting to spend too much, we almost always end up at Chipotle. I agree with others as well about the consistency of the food quality and taste.  It's good stuff!

This place is a music to check out for music lovers. I came with a friend who found this place and I am glad she did. This is one of those places where you have to pay a cover but they don't hassle you with a one drink or item minimum which is nice. There is also a long line waiting to get into the place so get in line and start waiting but it is worth the wait. They have different acts all the time and it is constantly changing. I went to one of the later shows and I just loved the feel and the environment of it. It was pretty cool how the band was from all over and I liked how it was a smaller more intimate venue. Even I liked the music and I know nothing about music.

Gotta love Ted Drewes. As many-a-yelper has mentioned, don't be phased by the long line -- it goes very very quickly. They have a ton of combinations. The Great Pumpkin is good -- they blend a piece of pumpkin pie in with vanilla custard -- but my favorite is the boring chocolate malt concrete. A must stop for a visit to STL. 

Pros: great custard, a STL staple!
Cons: not a whole lot of seating available

Show some love to Yogoluv! My friends and I went on opening day, and they had free frozen yogurt until 10PM to draw people in! I'm happy to say that I'll be returning even though it'll be 40 cents per ounce the next time I go in. 

The setup is the same as other places like FroYo and Red Mango, so my strategy still remains the same. You have to go fruity or chocolatey. I decided on fruity and tried out their peach, blueberry, raspberry, mango and vanilla flavors. I liked peach and raspberry best, but the best part was that the toppings you add at the end were all fresh! They have the fruits: blueberries, raspberries, strawberries, pineapples, etc. And the also have all the other normal toppings like nuts and whip cream and syrups. 

On top of that, Yogoluv offered different types of mochi, which I haven't seen elsewhere. They had the plain mochi, but also green tea and strawberry flavored mochi as well, which went very well with the fruity-frozen-yogurt combination. 

All in all, I recommend this place if you want to stop in for some frozen yogurt! There aren't many around the Creve Coeur area, so especially if you live around Yogoluv, it's definitely worth checking out.

For the price ($125 including tax) I'd give it four stars.  The room itself was very spacious, with a separate seating area and a small kitchenette area with sink, microwave, and refrigerator.  We were traveling with another couple, and liked that we each had an area in our room where we could comfortably entertain our group for a drink in the evening.

The bathroom (just a toilet and shower -- the sink is out in the dressing area between the bathroom and closet) was (very) small, but having a shower versus a tub was nice, although I'd recommend they reverse all the bathroom doors to open outward into the dressing area instead of inward.  It's very awkward to have to slip into the small space in between the toilet and shower in order to open and close the door.  And as mentioned in another review, it seemed curious to me why they'd dedicate so much extra space to the room itself, and leave so little for the bathroom -- It's not like use of that room is optional!

We'd stayed at a competitor's similar-tier hotel the night before and loved the free breakfast there, so in contrast we found this one disappointing.  The breakfast sandwiches were pre-assembled (English muffin with egg, meat, and cheese), so if you didn't like something on them you were out of luck.  There weren't any other hot items provided, and not much else to choose from.  The breakfast area was also messy and picked over.

The front desk staff was great -- friendly and efficient.  We asked for a dinner recommendation because we'd seen two barbecue places nearby, and we weren't sure whether to go to one of them or another one we'd been to before a few miles away.  She sent us to Judge Bean's BAR-B-QUE, and we had a wonderful dinner as a result.

Would we go back?  For the price, room size, and location, yes.  But we'd go in with our expectations appropriately set about the bathroom and breakfast.

Excusez-moi, was I just transported to a Parisian bakery? The Cake Bake Shop sure feels like it! The pictures Yelpers have posted just don't do it justice. It's ADORABLE. So classy and elegant, especially with the lighting and baby pink & white color scheme. Did I mention there's a twinkling Eiffel Tower in the window?? This place is like every little girl's dream place to come with her stuffed animals in tow and have tea time.

The shop is more spacious than I thought it would be - and they have a lovely patio area. If you want the full fancy experience, sit inside! 

In love with the decor, environment, and concept, but not quite the service. The young girl working the counter seemed baffled that we wanted to dine in just for coffee and some sweets, but we were told to seat ourselves and a server would come. It was slow as molasses and kind of confusing as to who was waiting on us, in all honesty. 

The espresso my friend had was apparently amazing, and we split a blueberry cinnamon scone. It was good, but disappointingly small. I was expecting a whopper of a scone to match their large cake slices. And since it's fancy, it's pricey.

Service issues aside, I want to return for tea time and get my hands on a slice of that delectable cake. Next time, I want to dress the part a little bit - they don't have a dress code and most people were casual, but I would have felt like I fit in more if I had on a sundress vs. a tee shirt and shorts.

Meh it was okay. 

The girl behind the counter was not helpful. I asked what was in the burrito because I had never been there she points to a sign on the register & said "this". Inside my head "okay sunshine" it read olives, jalapeños, lettuce, tom, beans & onion. Asked for a veggie burrito no beans & extra lettuce. She rudely asked what sized I said I'm not sure a normal size? Never had a size option on a burrito so I was thrown off. We sit down the food comes there's beans in my burrito & a pleasant surprise of rice which miss sunshine forgot to mention. 

I will try this place again only because my boyfriend loves it but if that girl is there & rude again I'm asking for a manager.

Al's is a landmark in Plainfield. The shop is small with 3 tables, loyal locals and the girls behind the counter could not be friendlier or nicer. You need to drive behind Dairy Queen to get to the parking lot. It's worth the trip if your close to Plainfield but get here EARLY. The donuts are delicious. I don't care for cake donuts but our server said I was passing up one of the best. So of course I topped off our dozen with those. They were light, fluffy cake donuts topped with a rich, dark chocolate icing. Thank you for that recommendation! 

They, like many small shops, sell till their gone. At 8:30 the tables were full of locals visting over coffee, enjoying donuts. The cases were close to empty with folks hurry in to grab what remained in the case. I now understand why Al's donuts are a staple for all these years. Even though Al has retired, the shop still honors and respects his love for donuts. He has a new fan as of today's first donut.

This is one of our favorite spots to go wine tasting in Santa Barbara. It is a little touristy just because of the location (out on the pier) but as soon as you go upstairs to the tasting room all it is easy to forget where you are. The view is amazing. You can take your wine tasting out on the patio and just venture back in when you are ready for your next pour. The inside is lovely too, nice couches and seating + it is a little cooler on a hot day and warmer on a cool day to sit inside. 

The wine is really good. I've done both the regular tasting and the reserve and enjoyed all of the wine. Pro tip: 2-for-1 tastings with the Axxess Pass. 

There is a restroom in the tasting room and also a public restroom on the pier. The pier also has parking but it is an easy walk out to the Deep Sea Tasting room from the main streets of downtown Santa Barbara, so no need to move your car if you are already parked in the area.

Best parts of the tour -- tour of the Clydesdales and that it's free! The packaging plant is also pretty neat. Definitely worth a stop on a visit to STL or if you want a free beer or two! Tip: take the "pony tour" as I like to call it, if you are just interested in the tasting -- the first stop on the tour is to see the Clydesdales, at which point they will ask that if anyone needs to leave this is the only point you can do that before the end -- at this point, head on over to the tasting room and enjoy your two complimentary pours of America's flagship beer (deal with it Miller-lovers).  

Pros: free, complimentary tasting, Clydesdales, pony tour option (see above)
Cons: not the best brewery tour I have ever been to

My husband and I haven't been to the restaurant, but we have ordered Uber Eats on several occasions. The selections we have ordered: coconut shrimp, pizza, burger, and the shrimp pasta. Everything has been delicious! The pizza is very thin, so it wasn't my favorite, but the flavors were excellent. The pizza would be better suited for people who prefer it to be very thin. I absolutely love their shrimp pasta with the fresh tomatoes and sauce. My husband loves their burger and you can't beat the price for the size of the burger, and the included side. The coconut shrimp and sauce were also cooked to perfection; the sauce was sweet and flavorful as well. The menu is eclectic with an array of modern and European cuisine. We will definitely be stopping in to the restaurant one day to fully enjoy all it has to offer, but are excited to have a nice bistro close to home!

I love fancy burgers. Garce's simple $11 burger is something you will crave and want to come back for. The crispy brioche bun and the thick patty makes me salivate when thinking about it. 

Duck fat fries were pretty good but did not surprise me. Cheddar dip tastes great, but it was drippy and a little messy. 

Lastly, I didn't like the other groups diners around me. Some were very loud and blatantly talking about strangers around them, like they thought they were better than the people around them. Weird. Just didn't expect the restaurant to attract these type of people.

The thing about Kanella is strange. The restaurant is only half a block to my apartment, so I pass by it all the time and after trying it for the very first time when it first opened. I couldn't honestly call myself a fan. What can I say? I ordered the kebob and everybody who knows anything about Greek/Turkish food is that kebobs are the most generic thing on the menu and can't really reflect the skills of the chef. On top of that the restaurant is popular and the space is small with tables arranged very closed to each other and I'm a bit claustrophobic. At the end of the meal I freaked out  a little and had to run out of the restaurant to catch a breath. After that experience I was a bit afraid to go back. Then there was a pretty long and angry respond to a newspaper review that got pasted on the window of the kitchen, I'm sure I'm not the only one who got weirded out by it.

It wasn't until Food Network's The Best Thing I've Ever Ate that got me pay more attention to my Greek neighbor. I went back for the Cyprus breakfast promoted by the program and it was good, real good. Everything on the plate was done perfectly; Eggs are fried to a crispy edge with the center remains raw, bread is toasted to a crunchy goodness, lounza ham is salty and dry is a good way. and can I just scream how I love the Halloumi cheese especially when it's fried to a crispy outside and a melty inside? I can have that everyday and be content. 

A second visit to the same plate proves that it's better to visit on weekdays when there are less patrons and the cooks can pay more attention to the food. On weekends, the quality can suffer because of the rush. The wait staff is knowledgeable and friendly, the decor simple and homey. I think they took the kebob out of the menu and I remember the dip being stellar. They also seemed to have a cooking class held on weekends sometimes, check their glass window. Even off-putting at times, a grouchy Greek chef may signifies a chef of standards. Now only if they can find a bigger place to host their restaurants.

I have seen various reviews on Tavern.  Some very negative.  Others slightly positive.  Most complimented the food but nothing spectacular. 

So, this past Friday night a few friends and I got together for dinner and I wanted to try some place new.  I put out a list of 3 new places (new to me anyway) I'd like to try - based upon the Menu.  I listed Red Pony in Franklin, Burger Up and Tavern.  I sent my friends links to the restaurants and ultimately we agreed that Tavern would be the place.  

We arrived at 7:30 and ended up having to wait an hour for a table and they don't take reservations.  That was fine.  We figured about anywhere we went on a Friday night at this point we would encounter a wait of similar length.  So, we waited and ordered a couple cocktails while we waited.  

This is probably the biggest downside of the restaurant.  They don't have a place for you to really wait.  The bar was jam packed and there was no seating up front.  There was seating outside on the patio - but no one was out there because it was raining and cold.  So, we stood inside near the door for an hour.  

When we were finally seated the server asked us if we needed any more drinks and if we wanted any appetizers.

We decided to go with the 'Bazooka" Guacamole Appetizer.  I pretty much hate Guacamole and never order it anywhere.  I've tried it several times many different places.  Never liked it.  But, this was supposed to be 'different' with some goat cheese and other stuff in it as well.  The presentation of the appetizer was very cool.  They bring it out in a 2-3" deep round cake pan lined with parchment or wax paper - I don't really remember.  Inside there is a glass jar with one of those hinged glass lids on top and its filled with this guacamole concoction.  They have a few chips out on the pan, however, there is also a small, brown paper bag with the logo of 'Tavern' on it - and it is filled with chips.  We took the small server spoon and each took a dollop of the guacamole and put it on a chip.  Wow!  Absolutely incredible.  I don't know if it qualifies as guacamole or not (I'm sure some purists would say it doesn't) - but whatever it is or whatever you want to call it - it was incredible.  I couldn't get enough.  We were scraping the bottom of the jar trying to get every last ounce of this wonderful, tasty spread.

Moving onto dinner two of us go the Tavern Burger.  This burger is made with Prime Rib and Filet.  2 excellent cuts of meat - ground up and made into a burger.  I had mine with White Cheddar and bacon and was incredible!  Everything was good.  The meat, the bacon, the cheese - even the bun was tasty.  My friend had his plain and loved it as well.  Both burgers were served with fries.  He had the regular fries - I had mine tossed in Parmesan and garlic.  Either way they were good.  Apparently they serve them several different ways.

Another friend got the 'Mama Sans Fried Chicken'.  He was blown away by how much food he got.  He also was surprised at how well the chicken went with the cold noodles he was served as the side.  He said the cold noodles were a good juxtaposition against the hot chicken. 

My other friend got the "Salad of Little Gems".  It looked a bit small to me but he claimed to really enjoy it.  As far as salads go it did look great.

The food was all served rather quickly but the pacing of the meal was on point.  The appetizer was served and finished well ahead of the meal making its way from the kitchen.  Too often I feel rushed and sometimes the appetizers and entree arrive within second of each other.  Sometimes even together!  I think the pacing of the meal was excellent.  Also, our server was great and our glasses were never empty.  She made sure we always had plenty to drink.

4 Cocktails, 4 entree's, 1 appetizer = $94 bucks after tax and everything.  So, around 20 bucks a person for a night out.  

So, to review:

Long wait - no place to really sit.  They DO take your phone number and will call you when your table is ready so you can make your way back to the restaurant.

Service was excellent.  Drinks were never empty.  Pacing of meal was great from the appetizer to the main course.

Price was fine.  We could have eaten for less if we didn't get cocktails, appetizers AND the main course.  If we'd just had water and our meal - we would have spent a lot less.  The cocktails were pricy - but pretty stout.  They didn't skimp on the alcohol for sure.

I think it was wonderful and we are already planning our next trip!  I think you should too.

Lovely ambience and view! I had the lobster salad for lunch which was great.  The crab cakes were not that good.  Not a lot of big lump crab meat or spice to give it flavor.  One of my least favorite crab cakes I have ever had.  The day I went I also felt like the service was less than stellar.  I didn't get the level of service and attention I would except from a higher end establishment. Overall I enjoyed the view and salad, but I would have to think twice about coming back here.

Kind of a cumbersome set-up, food was not that good, but drink menu is great. 

The place is itself is a nice place to hang-out with a good vibe. The annoying thing is you order your food at the counter, chipotle style, but if you want to look at the full drink menu, you have to go to the bar and ask for that menu, or press the button on your table to get the drinks-- either way you have to pay two separate bills for being in one place.. silly set-up.
The beer menu is great though, with tons of local options. They have a few margarita choices that all sounded interesting and I loved mine. 
However, the food was just not good, especially for what you can get in this town for Mexican food. The tacos and burrito both just tasted dry, to the extent that we didn't even finish the burrito despite being voracious eaters normally. Free chips & salsa bar were good though-- in fact I mainly just ate the chips and salsa since they were better than the food. 

Come check it out for drinks, but I'd go elsewhere for better mexican food

When a hipster friend of mine suggested we meet here for a drink, I figured I was in for something worthy of note by simply the name itself.

I was right.

The bartender looked like a gypsy and I sat between someone who appeared to be a pimp (feathered hat, martini and all) and a granny drinking a glass of merlot, joined by a woman with wild hair eating an ice cream cone.  Yes..an ice cream cone.

**I think it is important to note at this point in my write up that it was roughly 11:00 PM on a Saturday night. What in the world was a granny doing drinking merlot in a hipster dive bar at that hour of the night? Where did she come from? And where did that lady with the wild hair get the ice cream cone? Jealous, kind of.

This place never fails to disappoint on the people-watching front, which is a huge plus.  Ever since my first encounter here, I make sure to bring any and all visitors of Philadelphia whom I feel have a strong enough appreciation for what I would consider top 5 dive bars I have ever had the pleasuring of boozing in.  

It's a lively scene that is good for: conversation, darts, eavesdropping on others' bizarre and offbeat conversations, affordable pitchers of PBR, classic rock, Philadelphia memorabilia, BYO food (what?! yes.), gin & tonics, and decorative wall art.

Remember cash, people. No credit cards in this hole-in-the-wall..and I say "hole-in-the-wall" with a lot of love.

This would be my choice for parties/events in town! It's very spacious you could fit 3000 people there easily. I love the outdoor courtyard perfect setting for candles and flower arrangements. Everywhere you look there is something eye catching to see. 
I think the food is primarily contracted with Pigeon Caterers. Their food is good. I especially enjoyed their mini fries and lemon tart. 
I look forward to having another opportunity to attend an event here.

Can every Mexican restaurant please take some cues from Jose Garces on how to construct a perfect frozen Margarita?  I thought my beloved Distrito margaritas were unmatched but the frozen Prickly Pear at Buena Onda was PERFECTION.  It struck the balance of sweetness, icy goodness, and nuanced prickly pear flavor.  The tacos are also excellent.  Each iteration of fish taco was great and the carnitas were also quite good.  

This place is great for some casual food and excellent margaritas.

Came here for the first time last night. FYI Cash only! Had a hard time getting a drink at first, seemed like the bartenders stayed in one corner for awhile, but after the first time I had no problem. Love the dirty franks special - 2.50 for kamikaze and 7 oz beer. Bartenders were super friendly as were all the patrons. Very familial feel. Definitely divey which I love, but weird to look on one of the walls and see high quality art work. Interesting dichotomy. Love that there's darts! I found myself talking to people I didn't know and vice versa as people really got into it. Definitely want to return here!

Great concept - Convenient location with ample parking - No complaints!

This is the Panda Express of Mexican food. If you haven't been, you should definitely swing by. I openly acknowledge that the "knockout" tacos here anything but authentic, the concept used to be owned by Jack in the Box. 

Food - Anyone who loves tacos and is not a purist will agree that their tacos are BOMB. They seriously pack so many randomly awesome ingredients in each! (see menu below)

Restaurant - Super fresh, reminds me of Chipotle meets Noodles. Apollo bought Qdoba in December 2017 for a little over $300M, around $400K/location, probably how much you'd have to spend to build out a similar joint!

Pro-Tip: They send BOGO (buy one get one free) coupons every so often which make this place one of the best deals for a chain fast food joint!

Knockout Taco Menu (my fave is the 2 timer aka Double Decker):

Drunken Yardbird - Tangy tequila lime chicken, hand-smashed guacamole, salsa verde, cilantro, minced onion, and cotija cheese. 

Mad Rancher - Grilled chicken, bacon, hand-smashed guacamole, picante ranch, lettuce, pico de gallo, and cotija cheese. 

Two Timer - Pulled pork, salsa roja, shredded cheese, lettuce, pico de gallo, cotija cheese, and a crispy taco shell wrapped in a flour tortilla spread with 3-Cheese Queso 

Triple Threat - Steak, bacon, 3-Cheese Queso, fajita vegetables, pico de gallo, and cotija cheese.

The Gladiator - Steak, bacon, pico de gallo, lettuce, Mexican Caesar dressing, cilantro, and cotija cheese. 

Bohemian Veg - Shredded cheese, black beans, corn salsa, hand-smashed guacamole, salsa verde, minced onions, cilantro, and cotija cheese.

Bought my tickets in advance so I would be sure to have seats.  Gregg Stafford performed on trumpet, only thursdays and sundays early shows.  It was the MOST amazing Jazz experience we have ever had loved every second of it.  Will be back every time I am in NOLA.

I absolutely love this Petsmart! If you've read my reviews then you know I despise the location on Grant. We just became the proud owners/parents of a beautiful German shepherd puppy. The El Con location isn't open yet, so we drove quite a way to visit this one. Wonderful, friendly employees, everything was so easy to find...it was a great shopping experience. I was so impressed that I have made my baby's first vet appointment with the clinic there. Another review in the making! Seriously, I think we'll keep driving to this location even after the El Con store opens, which is literally 3 minutes away!

Another Starr creation, Jones does a good job recreating the shag carpet-y, tater-tots and meatloaf nostalgia of a comfort food diner, but with a hip edge. The offerings here are straight throwbacks and Starr does a wonderful job w/ both the menu & the decor. I love the drinks menu, with its gummy worm inspired drinks appealing to the tackiest moments of our youth...a great place to kick back with friends.

Wish Stephen Starr would expand to DC or Boston!!

Recently had a great lunch here.

I can only comment on the fare since it was a workday, but both my mom and I were pleased! We ordered the shrimp quesadilla and fish tacos. Enjoyed both dishes! There was plenty of shrimp on the quesadilla and they provide you with homemade salsa and several hot sauce options which I love. Those weren't homemade, but that's no biggie for me. I will definitely be back here again. Next time, I'd like to try their margaritas! They have a ton of different specials listed on the wall too. Wish I lived in walking distance. Seems like it would be a great happy hour spot.

What can I say, I love No Anchovies. Over the past 10 years I have seen NA only get better and better. New decor, new outside seating, new TV's, new bar area, new service counter, new awnings. However, the one thing that hasn't changed is their pizza recipes (and a few familiar faces). There is no reason to change them. They are delicious. Every time I am on university, I stop and get a slice of Mediterranean. And some times, when I have a craving, I make a trip down there just for a slice. This place definitely has a following, and regulars always feel at home.

I love the pizza but the service left a whole lot to be addressed. Lost pizza, employees standing around doing nothing while the line backs up, pizzas being given to the wrong customer and pants sagging on the employees. They should have a dress code that requires a belt!!!!  The pizza itself was great. Love the gluten free crust option and the flavor of oven baked pizza. Will try again but maybe a different location.

I spent most of my college experience being a "Box Rat" at HotBox West Lafayette (the BEST HotBox)  and I really do love Hotbox to death. They have great specials if you join the text club, and the people who they employ are always pretty stellar. You cannot beat a place that is open this late with quality food. I also enjoy collecting the wide array of colored cups. I wish they would recycle the super high-quality cups though!

My favorite pizza will always be the "HotBox" with buffalo sauce and dipped in the nectar of all that is holy, ranch dressing. You must try the Stix with cheese. Or else I will just Jedi mind trick you into doing so. 

Also any place where you can make so many jokes from their name and laugh at people who don't understand that is pretty okay in my book.

I figured it made sense to grab a quick bite/drink here, as I was staying right across the street at The Alexander. It was a good idea, as the experience was great.

We were seated immediately in the upstairs area, had menus right away, and a drink order placed within two minutes despite the buzzing crowd. Very nice! Sunday is a good time to stop by, as their "Sunday School" specials are excellent (both in price and selection). 

We ordered several small plates to start...roasted beets with feta, wild mushroom and raclette fondue, and butternut squash with bacon and goat cheese. All were very tasty, especially the fondue. I knew this place was special when the supply of toast for the fondue was dwindling, yet more fondue remained...I thought of asking for more toast, but was almost expecting some sort of "umm, sorry, we can't blah blah". The idea of eating fondue with a spoon crossed my mind when out of nowhere our server appeared with a plate of more toast. Without us asking. Bonus!

We then had a cheese plate (an Italian truffle cheese). It was soooo smooth and delish, and came with a little extra bit of squash...it allowed for a completely different, yet intriguing taste combination. 

Did I mention they have Dogfishhead 120 Minute IPA on tap? Well, they DO. I love that beer more than any other, and even though they limit you to one 5oz glass per person, I was thrilled to find it on the menu. I'd be more thrilled if I could've ordered another, but oh well.

The only thing keeping Tria from 5 stars is the music selection/noise level...too mainstream, too loud. Put on some Michel Camilo and treat some of the hard surfaces and you will match the vibe perfectly. Still, highly recommended.

Dinner Feb 13
  Busy Friday night, bar area was hopping.  We sat in dining area.  
  This is a place that every time I leave there, I always say, why don't I eat here more?
  She Crab Soup - delicious, thick and creamy
  Bread & seasoned Olive oil dip  - ask for it - the bread is fresh baked and a great freebie!
  Fried Grouper Sandwich - Its my favorite in Tampa, always fresh.  A bit pricey, but Grouper is - unless you are ordering grouper's playmate. Love their French Fries too.
  I am a terrible creature of habit and the above is what I get EVERY TIME I go to Ballyhoo's and it is always outstanding.

I have always loved buddy brew coffee! This is my first time at their new location and it is super nice. The staff is very efficient and knowledgable! If you haven't tried their coffee yet it is a must have in Tampa if not everywhere!

Absolutely loved this place!! My husband, 8 mo daughter, and I came in on a Sunday for some football, beer, and wings. We each had the beer sampler and the wings are phenomenal! Loved everything about this and definitely a must go!
